If you love pupusas, or if you've never had one, GO HERE.
Beans and cheese and pork and cheese are my favorite.
Gluten free goodness! Enjoy :)
author: Elizabeth L.

description: Good location, good food, ok price. The service is slow. But it is still the best pupusas I have tried in San Francisco so far.
author: Mel V.

description: The food is very good.   We had plantain empanada tonight that was amazingly delicious.  But the service was soooooooooo bad.  We placed our order at 7:45 PM tonight.  At 8:15 PM, we asked about it and we were told that we were next.  We saw a few more orders come out of the kitchen and we asked again at 8:25 PM.  Once again, we were told we were next.  the next order went to somebody else.  We asked again at 8:30 PM and our Salvadorean  fast food was presented to us after waiting 45 minutes.  It was sad seeing all the people waiting, children crying, people who paid for the food just walking away from the place.  The cashier was the rudest guy I have ever seen work in a restaurant.  There was no apologies to any of us.
author: Brad L.

description:
For $3, Panchita's is a solid late night snack.

After wandering around the Mission for a bit, my friend and I stopped in at 1 AM to split a bean and cheese pupusa. The place was pretty packed, but there were a couple of open tables, and we managed to grab one.

It was actually a decently long wait for our pupusa. Our table was missing the jar of cole slaw, but we grabbed one from another table, and. My roommate, a Panchita's regular, claims that there is a hot sauce I missed out on, but our table didn't have anything on it, so I was clueless (in retrospect, that's probably why it was open). :(

The first bite was pretty unimpressive, but by the time we were done, my friend and I both agreed we'd happily come back and try another pupusa (this time a different flavor!), though there are still probably better late night options in the Mission.
author: Kelly R.

description:
First time having pupusa

Been a picky eater my whole life

Loved them! Will be craving until I visit the city again! Must have! Shout out to the spinach and also beef!
author: Jill F.

description:
Came here with a large party and they got the food out to all of us really smoothly! Food was amazing -- got the pork chop with rice (amazing!) and beans, plantains, and beef pupusa, which were all amazing!

10/10. Bring your friends. Eat. Have a great time
author: Cherie L.

description:
A little disorganized for a Sunday evening; seems like they're adjusting to their well-deserved popularity. 

They didn't get my to-go order entirely straight, but the pupusas still made my night.
author: Cooper B.

description: I love Panchita's! And I love bringing friends here. It's authentic and has a homey feel and I appreciate that. Most times it's always packed when I go, but reasonably so.
author: Ashley G.

description:
Walked by here a couple of times but always full from other missions fine Mexican joints but today finally made it here to try the pupusaria!
Love that they are only $3 and has 12 different fillings to choose from
The only negative is that service is super slow  and wish they had blue corn

Perfect place after bar hopping in Valencia to soak up the booze

Value 4.5/5
Atmosphere 4/5 picnic bench style seating
Service 3/5 slow in line slow in getting the food
Quality 4/5

15.5/20
author: Nina S.

description: I ordered the mushroom and garlic pupusa and felt pretty sick after. The pupusa went down like a slick pocket of grease. Way too heavy for my taste.
author: Marianna M.

description:
I was waiting for my friend to meet up but I was feeling a little hungry. Initially wanted a taco but ended up walking by Panchita's. I hadn't had a pupusa in a long time so I figured I'd grab one. 

I got the basil and cheese pupusa for $3 and an alfajor. The alfajor was yummy but not formed well. Pupusa was extra cheesy and filling. 

Overall okay. Service, food, and atmosphere all average.
author: Sofia R.

description:
If I could give this place 10 stars I would. I waited three months to write a solid review for this place because it deserves it. First off, you have to find street parking because of its location in the middle of the block. Second, when we walked in, we were lucky to find a big table free because this place filled up fast after we sat down on a Monday night. This place is considered a pupuseria with authentic Salvadorean/Mexican food. 

We ordered beer and they gave us 1 liter. Awesome. We waited for a little bit but it was so worth the wait. I had carne asada and we enjoyed a great meal. I ate everything I could because it was the one of the best food spots I've been to. Everything was super tasty, authentic, and I can't wait to come back to San Francisco to eat there again!
author: Del R.

description:
Pupusas, pupusas, pupusas!
These little things will make your belly and taste buds very happy! Not only are they handmade all the way but you can watch the lady upfront cook it up fresh from scratch! 

At just $3 a pop, it's enough to satisfy that belly of yours (grab another one to be full)!
They've got both vegetarian and vegan options as well. Add some pickled cabbage and salsa to your plate and you're good to go!

Take a couple to go and people watch down the block while you chow down!
author: Roger M.

description: Everything is made by hand to order. The beans were sublime and the cheese and spinach Papusas were just the right amount of crispy (barely just enough not to be soggy) and filling - not greasy. The price for the Papusas plate was only 7$ so good bargain.
author: Skinny Coach u.

description: DELICIOUS papusas. Probably my favorite place for papusas that I've been to so far. Good customer service, polite, friendly, and family owned. This place has character too! They must know a painter/artist who they've given free range in their restaurant to explore their creativity from the main eating area to the bathrooms. It's casual dining with picnic bench type seating and paper towels and a pitcher full of clean forks and container with cabbage at each table and serve yourself water. Which I don't mind when the food is this good and service is friendly!
author: Sandra Z.

description:
Having spent a lot of time in Guatemala, the El Salvadoran dish of pupusas is something I'm quite familiar with. And often long for. They're tasty, they're a little greasy, they're cheap and they're filling. Having been disappointed in the past with Latin American food's US version, I didn't know what to expect here. And I was very pleasantly surprised. Fast, friendly service and delicious food. All the cabbage slaw and salsa topping you want, served over hot and tasty pupusas.

I only knew to ask for fried plantains because I saw someone else get them to go. Maybe there's a secret menu or something, because the only things up for offer on display were pupusa varieties. The plantains were delicious, too. Get them!
author: David B.

description: I've been here about 5 times and 4/5 times my orders were forgotten about to the point where I wait at least an hour until I mention it to the workers. Even on slow days like today I waited too long for 4 pupusas. At the same time one of the workers is too busy flirting with a customer in the corner of the store. I get it, it's a family owned small business but that's still really bad service.
author: Josh N.

description: Love to hit this spot while I'm in the city. Awesome pupusa among other things. for pupusa Beans with cheese, & the basil with cheese are my personal favs and I cannot resist yucca.
author: Moon S.

description:
Sad face. I was craving pupusas (because I am obsessed), and we walked into this place, which has 4 stars. We only ordered one pupusa because we were so full.

I was a bit disappointed in the pupusa; it's definitely not my favorite (see my list for Salvadorean favorites). It was nice and round, the meat inside was decent, but I couldn't taste the cheese and the masa dough surrounding the pupusa just didn't taste right.

The salsa and curtido were good, I'd come back for that, though maybe not the pupusa again.
author: Christina L.

description:
Panchita's pupusas are good, but not quite El Zocalo's. Ever since El Zocalo closed their doors, I've been on the hunt to find a fulfilling, greasy, yet slightly crispy in texture pupusa that will blow my mind during the wee hours of the night. My boyfriend was craving pupusas and brought me to Panchita's on a Friday night at around 10pm. Luckily for us, there was parking right around the block, which is a rarity in the Mission. Since it was Friday night, naturally Panchita's was packed with a ton of people, but seats were plenty available once patrons finished their pupusas. 

We ordered 2 chicken pupusas, 2 pork pupusas, and 1 beef pupusa plus an alfajore because why the heck not? I believe the total was under $20. The curtido and sauce is readily available on the tables along with utensils and napkins. Our orders came about 10-15 minutes later, so if you're in a hurry to get something quick, Panchita's might not be for you. The texture of the pupusa was fine, but the meat to cheese ratio was off for me. Unlike most people, I like my pupusas cheesy, so I was a tad bit disappointed to find that there was more meat than cheese. Also, the pork used was mostly fat, which was off putting. 

Overall, the pupusas are good, however, I'll still continue my hunt for something that is similar to El Zocalo.
author: Joyce E.

description: So delicious! Lots of options for pupusas, chill vibe, and great food. What more could you want?!
author: Lex B.

description: I finally have discovered it - the best food to eat after a night of drinking. Papusas!!! And even better $3 papusas! And to add the the fun - they have tons of flavors (the beef was great and so was the mushroom and cheese). Now the final element of fun - a mariachi band came in and played (midnight snack and a show)!
author: Nikita K.

description:
This is a review of their VEGAN pupusas, which they made especially for one of the Very Vegan Sundays at SoMa StrEat Food Park. They don't usually make vegan pupusas at their restaurant, though they said they might begin to because they seem to be a popular item at Very Vegan Sundays. Let's support them and hope they do it!

I tried all three kinds they had that day:

- Potato Roasted Tomatoes, and Chipotle
Pretty good. Relatively average and boring.

- Green - Lentils, Spinach, Kale, and Chickpea
My least favorite. It was dry and starchy, lacked flavor. Tasted like mushed peas.

- Beans, Eggplant, Mushroom, and Garlic.
My favorite one. Very flavorful and savory.

All were slightly dry. I was surprised they didn't attempt to use a cheese substitute, which would have made it much more pupusa-like. I hope they try it one day, as cheese substitutes are readily available in the Bay Area.
author: Vegans Eat 2.

description: This is based on the Popusas.. it was Mediocre Popusas,  the Popusas got soggy and the cheese was not thick and just plan..    still looking to find the best spot for popusas..   Since Amelias closed, not one place comes near it..
author: GalloStar X.

description:
Pupusas! At $3 each, these make for the perfect low-budget meal. I had two and it was enough to fill me up. The pork pupusa was flavorful and cheesy, but there wasn't much pork in it. The mushroom and garlic pupusa was my preferred pupusa.

These are made fresh and served hot. Each table has unlimited hot sauce and pickled cabbage to pair with the pupusa. Both are highly recommended to add acidity and texure to the pupusa.

The pupusas take a while to come out (about 20 min wait). If you want a faster option, consider the food stand they have outside of the restaurant where they also make pupusas on the spot. You can even take your meal and eat inside the restaurant.
author: Alice T.

description:
Nothing and I mean nothing ruins a great Monk's Kettle burger like a Panchita's #2 Popusa...

Let me explain.
Two weeks ago, a good friend from SoCal visiting the city wanted a good burger.  I suggested Monk's Kettle (they make one of my fave burgers in the city).  However,  the wait was a hefty 1hr and 45min. (Yes the host said this with a straight face.)  So we headed straight to Panchita's to have a little "amuse-bouche".  Popusas it would be... as we have all decided unanimously.  What had transpired next was nothing less than "amazeballs" as a friend would say.  The popusas here are phenomenal. I mean the masa is soft, tasty, cooked perfect and the thickness is consistent.  The ingredients inside are fresh and the cheese savory fried.  The cabbage salad that comes with the Popusa along with the sauce is also very very good.  Just beware of the spicy sauce because it's got a little bite..

I got the beef Popusa and the melted cheese inside it was super.  My friend got the Loroco and that was tasty, wife got the bean filled and that was great as well.  All in all it was so good we all had a bite of each other's Popusa (the technique is share two quarters and save the half for yourself).  When we got done we actually got a little full since the size of the popusas are substantial (or perhaps the cabbage salad contributed to the fullness of the meal).  

So getting to Monk's Kettle full and ordering the burger was not optimal for enjoyment anymore.  But I'll tell you it was worth it since Panchita's #2 has really great food.

PS: I saw fried plantains on the menu and I'm sure that will ruin another dinner of mine next time....unless dinner will be at Panchita's which I recon is a better idea...Cheers!
author: John G.

description: Wish I had seen the health score. I got food poisoning here two nights ago :(. I knew looking at the salad in the containers, it would be a risk... but went for it anyways.
author: Diane I.

description: This is the place in the Mission for pupusas.  Very pleased with the service, the cleanliness, and the pupusas themselves were phenomenal.  Just get one with some rice and beans and you are looking at a full meal for two.
author: John D.

description: Panchitas is my go-to in Mission District. This family run business has incredible food and very friendly service. I highly recommend the carne asada plate or the pork rib plate. Pupusas are delicious and a must-try of course, but so are all their other side dishes, especially the plantains! Big portions that are well worth the price. Every time I go, I can't wait until the next time to come back!!
author: Sam H.

description: Tried Pupusas for the first time ever here. Never tried Salvadorian food before this. I'm not a vegetarian really, but I ended up ordering vegetarian pupusas even though I was leaning kind of towards chicken (only because it was shredded). I ended up getting the jalapeno pupusa, and a mushroom and garlic pupusa. With the salsa and salad on top of them, they were amaaaazingggg! I think they might replace tamales on my list of favorite foods. Still below burritos though.
author: Kavya T.

description: Best pupusas I've tried so far, lots of cheese and nice veggie options too, plus the salad and salsa available in each table are great. Delicious fast Salvadorian food in the heart of the Mission :)
author: Martino P.

description: Mmm the papusas are amazing! I ordered the combo, 2 papusas with beans and rice, plus a side of plantains. Everything was wonderful. I had one chicken and cheese papusa and one mushroom garlic papusa. Delicious.
author: Jess R.

description:
I hope this review is for the right place.

We went out for a friend's birthday nearby and stumbled out of the bar around 1am.  Obviously, we're going to grab some late night eats before heading home to satisfy both an instant gratification for food and a preventive measure for the next day's productivity.

Luckily we spotted the Panchita's Restaurant No. 2 aka "The Pupusa Lady / Pupusa Stall".

I had the chicken variety and obviously added the extra fixings:  Cabbage and Sauce.  My wife got the cheese version.  The whole order cost less than $7.00, which is amazing and also makes me wonder what Panchita's margins are on both a fixed and variable cost basis.  I suppose the volume and operating leverage makes up for it.

This was a strong finish to a fun night.
author: Sebastian N.

description:
I love pupusas!  So when I learned that there was this actual Salvadorean pupuseria just off the 16th St. BART station (which I apparently always walked by without noticing) I had to give it a try. Yelpers were right - these are some really delicious pupusas. 

With just the right amount of stuffing and just the right amount of fluffiness to the masa, these pupusas are a great dish to nosh on. Made to order and served to your table with a small bowl of mild salsa, you then top these yummy things with as much curtido (Salvadorean cabbage relish) as you'd like. They provide a a bin of it at every table, along with an entire roll of paper towels and a basket of utensils. 

I wasn't too hungry, so I only ordered one each of the pork and bean pupusas.  The flavors were subtle but great. The pork was perfectly cooked and juicy. Each had a hint of cheese in it. Just enough to balance the flavors. Topping them with the curtido and salsa gave the pupusas a nice textural, tart smokey element. 

You have a choice of beverages when you order and chips n salsa are extra. There's enough clean seating too. Service is great for a family run place. I'm definitely coming back to try more flavors!
author: Eileen P.

description: Delicious pupusas.  5 stars for that alone.  2 for $7.00 is the going rate as of a couple weeks ago.  First time I came back in the last few years, but the food is as solid as ever.  Cabbage slaw and hot sauce at the table are on point.  I ordered a spinach and a bean pupusa, both of which were fantastic.  Street food vibe, but they accept credit cards and modernized their interior a bit since the last time I had been here.  Open late and tastes great.  What more could you ask for?
author: Alan C.

description:
We were lured in by the lady forming, filling, and flipping fresh papusas outside. My friends never had papusas before, so we grabbed a couple as appetizers. 2/$5. We tried the pork/cheese and beef/bean. Pork was the preferred flavor in our group, but they were both pretty good. I wish the lady had left the papusas on the flat top longer though -- the dough didn't seem fully cooked and toasty.

It was kinda confusing, but you order at the counter and hope someone pays attention to you. Then the papusa lady will give you your papusas on a plate or in paper sleeves. Then you find your slaw, they didn't offer us any but there were big buckets of it on other diners' tables.
author: Vivian H.

description:
Kudos to the nice man who let us cut in the very very long line on a Friday night as we wanted to pick up some papusas before we headed to BART!

Tip: the meat papusas (pork, chicken, beef) are good but the mushroom & garlic is probably the best. I've had them all and that one in particular is just so much more flavorful. Try not to put too much sauce because the tanginess is a bit overpowering. 

Great location and stop for our giant taco crawl, ending with papusas. Need to come back!
author: Sally C.

description: First you have to stand in line to place your order. They don't have any traditional drinks like horchata. We had to clean up after someone else because no one was cleaning them. If I am going to be charged $3 each. I shouldn't be eating a burnt pupusa! Smh so many other places that give better service and better quality of food.
author: Sila C.

description: I ordered the jalapeno and cheese papusa.  Very filling but slightly too greasy.  I would have given 4 stars but the wait was over 20 minutes to prepare food and the restaurant was not very busy.
author: Angelina G.

description:
Came here with some friends and wasn't really sure what I was in for when one of them suggested that we should go get some pupusas. But I was definitely in for a pleasantly tasty surprise! They have a cart outside the restaurant where you can watch them make the pupusas. The pupusas comes with an unlimited amount of cabbage and hot sauce. 

I ordered two pupusas which were filling, and also got to try some of my friends. Below are the pupusas that I tried:

1. Mushroom and Garlic - my favorite! This was the most flavorful out of all the one I tried. I don't remember tasting much mushroom but the garlic taste was definitely there. 

2.Chipotle - bleh. not a fan. Tasted like dough with cheese and hot sauce. Nothing special. 

3. Chicken - it was good. The chicken wasn't dry, which is always a concern of mine when I order chicken.  

4. Beef - good as well. The beef was in a form of a thin patty, just like the chicken.
author: Michelle T.

description:
This place is so bomb. Haven't had papusas in years so my friend took me here while I was visiting SF. We chowed down before going out in the Mission. 

The papusas were freshly made outside and brought to your table where you have your own bucket of cabbage mix. So much yum. 

There's not much to look at inside and the picnic table seating was kind of uncomfortable, but the food is just so worth it. 

Will force my friend to take me back when I visit again.
author: Daphni E.

description: Bargain meal of  two pupusas  beans and rice for just $7. Good flavor but almost no meat. Good selection of cold beer and favored fruit drinks.
author: Helen M.

description:
Pupusas are pretty good! I asked for them well cooked because they're often not cooked enough. There "plates" (Meaning chicken plates i.e.) are not good at all. 

I ordered a tamale de elote, they severed it with plain sour cream. This is supposed to be a salvoadoreno restaurant and they serve it like that. Oh nonono ...

AND THEY HAVE POOR FOOD SAFTEY THATS FUCKING DISGUSTING!!!!!!!
author: Anna L.

description:
Late night munchies are attacking me once again! But I want something good! I'm in the mission, and I just finished a little haunted house tour at the armory. On my way to the Armory I was driving down Valencia and saw Panchitas pupuseria. They close late and pupusas would be a great late night treat!

Outside of the restaurant is where two ladies were making pupusas! A cart with all the ingredients is where one lady was making them and another cart with a grill where the other was cooking them. Talk about freshly made! I ordered the cheese pupusas. Omg! Sooo good! The tortilla was nice and thin and filled with lots of cheese! It was a perfect ratio. Right off the grill and just oozing with cheese. It had a wonderful velvety buttery taste in every bite. Top that with the vinegar based cabbage slaw and it was even more heavenly. 

I think I ate about 4. I probably could have eaten more but didn't have enough room in my belly! I just hate when something tastes so good and you don't want to stop eating it but are forced too, due to lack of space! Well it just gives me another opportunity to come back for more. Can't wait!
author: Roger P.

description:
It's ironic this is restaurant#2, but this is more better known than the first  one (in Excelsior, had to look it up). 

This is NOT a grab and go food place.  Came on Black Friday late afternoon, and it was not busy at all.  Still, I had to wait a good 15-20 minutes for my food.  Ordered to-go so that I could catch BART, but it took so long that I just ate in.  The people didn't give me any hassle with doing this thankfully.

Pupusas are $3 each.  I went with the combo which costs $7.50 and includes 2 pupusas with rice and bean.  
The worker recommended that I get mushroom & garlic as well as pork and cheese.

The food hits the spot with filling me up but the flavors were really unforgettable.  The stuffing in the pupusas are also minimal that you don't even notice the flavor inside.  
Lots of free AYCE condiments: pickled cabbage, hot salsa, and water.  

On the weekends, they usually have someone making pupusas outside.  Maybe those taste better.  I would give this place a second try but it's not high on my list given all the other restaurants in the Mission I have yet to check out.
author: David W.

description: Best pupusa place yet. It used to have a truck outside at front and lined up pretty long but I don't see anymore. I'm coming back for spinach and mushroom pupusas at least once a month.
author: May Y.

description:
I would like to dedicate these five Yelp stars to the papusas made fresh at the cart right outside. For just $3 each, you too can enjoy the taste of El Salvador in your mouth. I even had to take a picture of my papusas to make my El Salvadorian friends jealous. I tried the pork papusa which is apparently very popular, and I can't imagine them tasting any better than that. You can ask for them either plated or to-go, though I recommend eating them right away while they're still hot. My friend suggested sitting on the curb to eat them, and it was such a good idea. No shame.

There is a bucket of cabbage and bottle of salsa available which only enhance the flavor of the papusa. Everything about the ingredients and texture and freshness was perfect. YUMMM... What a simple but delightful pleasure!
author: Stefanie C.

description: I absolutely love the pupusas here. But I wouldn't say they have the best customer service. They are a bit rude.
author: L G.

description: Ehhhh it's aight. I love Mexican food, but not sure if pupusas are for me. I tried the chicken pupusa and it was okay... Just tasted like chicken with thick tortilla and some filling inside. The place was surprisingly clean and they had free cold slaw. I don't really have much to say about this place because it wasn't a good or horrible experience. I didn't really eat much of it either because I wasn't hungry, but it wasn't that great.
author: Esther Y.

description: They lost my order then when I asked about it they struggled to figure out what happened. The order finally came 15 min later and it was mostly cold.
author: Henry B.

description: I waited over an hour for my order while everyone after me got their food. The first time I asked the server what happened to my food she said it's coming. Waited a few more minutes and asked her again. Turns out that they lost my ticket. No apology from the server whatsoever. Every time I come here the wait time is ridiculous.
author: Jhina A.

description: The food is pretty good, if you ever get it. I just waited 40 minutes for a pupusa, and it's not an unusual experience. Don't come here if you're in a rush.
author: Christophe T.

description:
So much cheese!!!
My friend felt so puky after the dinner. We came back home and couldn't do anything rest of the evening.  Disgusting food.
author: V V.

description: I have heard of pupusas, but never tried them. Kept walking by this place off Valencia and finally went tonight. I got a chicken and a zucchini pupusa and they were $3 each. Good with the salsa and cabbage. However, I don't know what the big deal is. It's like a quesadilla. The bread isn't that amazing, but they are fun to snack on.
author: Denise C.

description: Food was amazing! I've never had pupusas before until a few friends recommended it! However, don't actually come here if you're actually trying to have fun and just laughing! My friends and I were just having a good time (and sorry our laughter is a little on the louder side) when the guy from the front came by and told us to keep it down! Oh sorry, we were just actually having a good time, my bad dude! It was the Asian dude with the thick black glasses. Besides that whole weird thing about minding our own business and having a good time, the food was good, but that was really all that was going for the place. It's a shame since it's probably the only time I'm ever going there and I'm definitely not recommending this to friends!
author: Katrina C.

description:
If you love pupusas you'll love these pupusas!  I fell in love with bean and cheese pupusas back in LA.  While a few places have other varieties down there, Panchita's offers such a great variety and several are vegetarian friendly, too.  Plus they have a great sign.

If you love pupusas you should go here unless you hate yourself.  If you hate yourself, you'll probably want to punish yourself by skipping such a great meal.  If that's the case, get some therapy and when your self-esteem is back (presuming you had any in the first place) you should celebrate by eating pupusas at Panchita's.  When you need to feed your newfound confidence and equanimity, nothing fits in your mouth hole better than a hot, greasy pupusa from Panchita's.
author: Adam D.

description: I had chicken and pork...very tasty. The cabbage and salsa brought to the table were pretty good also. I was skeptical of the cabbage container, though, which was shared by everyone at the table and with other tables prior. I hope everyone using the tongs had washed their hands prior to eating, but even so, that's a great way to spread germs. :(  I would give the food 4 stars but I have to give a 3 star review because of the cabbage containers, and the bathroom was disgusting too!
author: Olwen C.

description: Beware: I do have high expectations of pupusas. But for 3 bucks they're good! Try the empanada - although in Guatemala it is called rellenitos. SO GOOD. Wish it were warmer ...
author: Albia C.

description:
Best Papusas in TOWN ! thats all i gotta say.

yes there is a long wait, so call in your order like i do and walk in and out after paying, no wait no hassle, just good ol yummy papusas

so many flavors and at $3.50 you cant beat it

when they make them on the side walk they are ONLY $3.00!!!!!!

Peace! IM OUT BXXXXES!!

(Drops Mic)..........................
author: China D.

description:
Always down for a pupusa at 1am (The Yelp Hours are WRONG)

Can't really beat the prices here.  So cheap and if you're not a big eater one pupusa is enough for 2.  For anyone who hasn't had one it's like a fried stuffed tortilla with cheese and other meats/veggies.  After drinks at the club this place is my go to like 80% of the time.  

It's a hole in the wall so don't expect anything fancy.  Just go for the good/cheap/authentic late night food
author: David P.

description:
My group of friends and I passed by (by chance) on the way from the BART to the ever-popular Monk's Kettle bar.

We were craving some small eats, and were immediately drawn to Panchita's like flies to a light when we saw their stand on the street with a public display of handmade pupusa dough and the grill that is used to cook them. You might be confused at how to order, so refer to the street "menu" from beef to mushrooms and spinach...just to name a few. You can ONLY get one ingredient inside the pupusas--the lady who was flattening them with her hands spoke limited English, but it's possible to get your order across with smiles and basic hand gestures.

We didn't actually sit down and eat inside the restaurant, but if their food is anything like the street pupusas we had, I'm sure it's delicious. I've never had Salvadorean food, but it tasted very flavorful, yummy, and I have no complaints about the quality. The store inside is pretty colorful and makes you feel like you're not in SF, for a change. I'm sure I would not mind coming back here again if I happened to be in Mission...late night drunchies sound pretty good here.

All I gotta say is...dem handmade street-sold pupusas doe!
author: Jodi H.

description: All you need is $3 to be the happiest person in the world! I'm telling yah. These papusas are filled with cheese goodness! I ordered the chicken and pork and it did not disappoint.
author: Grace V.

description: ICONIC! So delicious. I am dead from how amazing this is. Highly recommend the plantains because 2 bomb
author: Erin W.

description: I ordered a small plate of pork ribs and rice. The food came out quite tasty, I would give them a solid 4 stars for the price, but it took them 30 mins (no joke) to get the plate out. Not particularly a busy night but the lady told me there was a big Take out order right before making a lot of eat-ins folks wait much longer. Overall not a bad joint but think twice if your in a rush.
author: Ben N.

description: Panchitas has the best pupusas in San Francisco. The service was great and the food was AMAZING.
author: N R.

description: Uhmmm seriously, when it comes to this LaMission staple, FCK your bad health rating score.. their pupusas are FIRE!!!
author: Melanie D.

description: I love these pupusas. Lots of choices and yummy sides. Their sauce is particularly good. I've had pupusas in a few places around the country and these are my favorite. I used to live a couple blocks away and I miss it tons. I always make the time to go here when I'm in the neighborhood. If you have wheat allergies (like I do) or Celiac's, their pupusas are wheat and gluten free.
author: Elizabeth P.

description:
pupusas here are great! I would recommend eating in instead of taking these things to go because the sauce and slaw make the pupusa A LOT better.  However, they are still great without.

quick note- this store sometimes has a cart outside where they make the pupusas. It's a little deceiving because it makes it look like you can order something and quickly be on your way, but in reality, this is just where they make the pupusas for the restaurant.  You still usually need to order inside and the pupusas will take 10 minutes.
author: Patricia K.

description:
If you are going to get pupusas, you should get them here, freshly prepared in front of you on a well-seasoned grill in front of this store by a very friendly woman who must have been doing this for years, she was so efficient and deft. 

And unlike other pupusas that I've had, these were not glistening in grease and delicious. And so inexpensive!

I gotta go back...
author: Glenn H.

description: Stopped into Panchitas on a pit stop heading home. Walked in placed my order for a cheese and a revuelta pupusa. The food arrived in little wait and tasted good. I have tried many pupusas in my day and rate this one pretty high on the list. If you desire a pupusa and want to try the gambit of types they have I'd recommend it!
author: Roje D.

description: Horrible customer service,  food has nothing special and place is really dirty. I bought their famous pupusas and instead of packing them on a to go container,  the food was wrapped on aluminum foil.
author: Malena P.

description:
Panchitas has the best pupusas I've had to date. They're cheap (2 for $5) and offer many fillings (that you can combine) that I have not seen at other Salvadorian restaurants. Some fillings they offer include: spinach, basil, mushroom, garlic, beef, pork, chicken, etc. 

Although Panchitas is quite a walk from Dolores Park, it makes a perfect portable meal that you can eat at the park. I also appreciate that they individually wrap each pupusa when you order out for eating on-the-go! 

Downsides include, the lack of service. This is a pay and sit down type of restaurant. It's also disappointing that they don't serve chips and salsa when you dine in anymore. I try to refrain from dining in because there were a couple of occurrences where homeless people would wander in and sit next to me. One time, a homeless man was sitting across from me trying to pry off his home-arrest ankle bracelet...awkward! 

I would recommend Panchitas for their cheap and tasty pupusas that happen to be gluten-free!
author: Juliette R.

description:
Three and a half stars.

How can you say no to $3 pupusas?? The spinach & cheese one was delicious. The one with mushrooms was okay, but I was glad they had vegetarian options. I got an order of pupusas to-go, but it took them FOREVER to make. The restaurant was pretty empty at that time too. I waited about 20+ minutes for my order..blah.
author: Tina C.

description:
I love pupusas...well, I thought I did until I tried the ones here.

We drove passed this place and my eyes immediately lit up with joy.  PUPUSAS!  I've only had the ones from Costco so seeing the pupusa lady toss these stuffed tortillas on the grill made it look so authentic.  

I ordered the mushroom and spinach for a friend.  His was ready in less than 2 minutes.

I ordered cheese.  Yup, just cheese.  The pupusa lady looked at me like I made a mistake ordering.  I guess no one orders just cheese.  My order took about 7 minutes.  Took the first bite and my excitement quickly died down.  It was....bland. I guess that's why no one orders just cheese.

On the plus side, it's made fresh and very inexpensive.
author: Linda N.

description:
The GF and I were just passing by, and she noticed their cart located outside the busy restaurant.  There were two people prepping, and making pupusas.  They looked pretty good, and we have always wanted to try an authentic one.  After much debate, we decided to get one to share.  One must order inside, and present the ticket to the people working outside.  At $3 a pop, there are a little under a dozen different fillings to choose from.  We decided to get mushroom and garlic.  The lady outside already had one on the stove.  It was slightly broken, but that just meant that the cheese was oozing out, making it crispy, which is always a good thing!  

I can understand why this place was so packed.  They make really good pupusas, and attract people of all walks of life.  I would come back to try their other pupusas.
author: Victor L.

description: Great Name. Great Place. If you're looking for great Salvadoran street food in the Mission, this is your place. You'll find yourself in Pupusa heaven (I've been there and eager to go back).
author: Dan A.

description:
Really like their pupusas. I more or less tried all the kinds they have, my favorite ones are pork, loroco and beef.

My only complaint is that it takes too long to get the food.
author: Xavier R.

description:
$3 fresh made Pupusas of all varieties
It doesn't get any better 

Pork, beef, Chicken, Zucchini

And coleslaw as well
author: Peter K.

description: Pupusas are soft masa filled with delicious cheesy filling of your choice eaten with pickled vegetables and a red salsa. Each Pupusas are $3 each we also got the guac and chips which were $5 but not that great. Might as well get another pupusa. I love the pickled vegetables here without them the pupusas would feel to heavy but its perfect with the pickles veggies. This place is definitely great and I believe everyone should try!
author: Eileen H.

description: This place is the bomb.com. The pupusas were amazing, especially the mushroom one. Add a little vinegar slaw and red sauce, and you are good to go. Throw in a Mexican coke to sweeten the delicious meal.
author: Andrea M.

description:
Not the best pupusas out there, but definitely good.  Plus they offer lots of veggie options which makes me happy.
They stand outside with their stuffings and the grill and make em right where you can see...which gives you that street style food fix feel.
author: Kinjal N.

description: Family ran and owned for over 20 years. Authentic pupusas, made fresh and absolutely delicious! Everything on the menu is fresh and tastey. The prices are great. This place has changed very little since back in the day, they've  stayed true to their roots and themselves,  A beautiful thing in San Francisco. Bravo! I love this place.
author: Terese V.

description:
They raised their prices :( so I had to lower it a star. 

My favorites are probably the pork and jalapeno papusas. I always get it with a side of beans and rice to complete my meal. I had menudo once and that was pretty good! Though the next time I went in to order it, they didn't have it anymore.

Only issue is sometimes their rice is SOOOOOOOOO oily that it's inedible.
author: Angela L.

description: OMG THIS IS THE BEST PLACE EVERRRRR THE pupusas are sooooo bomb!!! Best night time spot when you're drunk and want something bomb afffff!!!! 6$ for 2??? SET! This place is soo good foreal go! I got the beef and pork and both were so good. If you love cheese this is the place to
author: Marilee A.

description:
Pupusas. El Salvadorian cuisine. They have tamales. Service is kind of, well,
very slow. And there's not very many people here. I can't imagine how it would be if it was packed. Took about 20 min to get 4 pupusas out.
author: Candy F.

description: I thought the pupusas themselves were pretty delicious and inexpensive. But the rice and accompanying sauce were really bland. Sadly I don't know enough about pupusas to compare to others in the city - I would come back, but I guess I'd be happy to try some others too.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Yessssss .. This place has amazing pupusas.. You can't go wrong ordering here, whatever you pick will be delicious ...

Bad side of it... All the drunk, homeless and scums that lies on mission are sitting around here ;( not good to eat inside but if you order to go.. That will be the right choice ;)
author: Liz G.

description: Happy to eat here after a few or several drinks in the mission. The pupusas are flavorful and made to order. Jalapeno is the best, buy one.
author: Mike S.

description: Being in the restaurant industry I've only had papusas for family meal. So, when I was in the neighborhood and saw a papuseria, and for only $3 each, I had to try. I had a chicken and a pork, washed down with a Mexican coke. So incredible. The molten cheesy goodness was amazing. Topped it off with their pickled cabbage for some nice freshness and crunch. Highly recommend
author: Ryan W.

description:
Mountains and mountains of pupusas. I definitely should not have had three of them last time I was here, but you won't understand until you walk by the two smiling women sizzling them away on the grill outside.

You can opt to get beans and rice on the side, and there's plenty of pickled cabbage and salsa to cut the cheesy goodness.

Ample seating for big groups!
author: Kevin L.

description:
I was spending a day thrift store shopping to help a certain fellow shop for new-used furniture (oxymoron, I know).
 
I forgot to eat prior to our adventure to the city. Therefore, when I arrived, I was famished. I wanted to wait until we got in to Mission in order to eat; the selection around the last Caltrain stop is rather small and expensive. When we finally arrived, we walked into the first Pupusa restaurant we saw.
 
It was truly a hole in a wall kind of place, which is to my liking. The menu was straightforward and simple, yet I mistook the pricing as five dollars for each pupusa - which in reality it as two for five dollars. I ordered two, beef and spinach. The staff was friendly; they ensured that they wanted us to relax and have a seat and that we can pay afterwards. We finally got our pupusas and they were flavorful. I had pupusas in San Jose before and they didn't leave an impression, but these ones did. I like the spinach one the best, it was so creamy inside (okay, I have a dirty mind - my mind went there when I typed this out).
 
We finished and paid. It was such an amazing bargain for a nice portion of food. I ended up buying a cookie of theirs and I am glad I did. It reminded me of the Filipino dessert that is called Polvoron - it's one of my faves.
 
The only funny part was when a pigeon made himself at home inside the restaurant. I took pictures because I have never seen such a brazen pigeon before.
author: Elsvette B.

description: This was my first time coming here, at the time i was not feeling well (stomach wise) but decided to still try one at least... OMG, i must say it was warm and delicious! My whole family loved and we will def. be coming back to this spot. Even though it was a bit crowded they still served us in a timely matter.
author: Vanessa T.

description:
1. Summary:
My first time trying El Salvadorian food. I thought the papusas were decent, but was not impressed with the taste, did not find them flavorful enough.
Great value for money though.
(Points: 6/10)

2. Food:  
Had the garlic mushroom, as well as the chicken papusas.
For my taste, they were too cheesy and bland.
Liked the chicken papusa more than the garlic mushroom, because the chicken one had a decent tomato flavor added, the mushroom garlic one was very bland.
Also tried their shortbread cookie, but I thought it was pretty ordinary - very dry.
(Points 5/10)

3. Ambience :
Very bare-bones - go here only if you care about food.
(Points 5/10)

4. Price: 
Very reasonable
(Points: 9/10)

5. Variety:
They had a good mix of vegetarian and non vegetarian papusas, but it seemed like papusas was the only thing they served.
(Points: 7/10)

6. Service:
Slow. The papusas were made outside, and the server would go outside and get them. Might have been better had we stood outside and eaten them instead of sitting inside.
(Points: 5/10)

7. Value for money: 9/10

8. Wishlist: 
Would love to see richer, more complex flavors.

***Note - I personally care about food the most and hence my overall rating is more biased towards food and less towards other factors like ambience, price, service, etc.
My taste buds are more used to Indian flavors, so I'm not able to always appreciate foreign flavors, although I love expanding my horizons and trying out new foods.
I am mostly a vegetarian, and occasionally eat meat, so my orders have a heavy bias towards vegetarian items.
author: Tejas B.

description: Cheap and Delicious! Most people probably only consider this place after leaving the bar which is a shame. If in the area I recommend very highly. Not very filling with just 1 so prepare for at least 2-3 pupasas.
author: Joe L.

description:
Went on a Friday night, expected it to be busy and it was. A bit of a wait to order at the cashier but the food didn't take long to arrive, maybe 10 minutes. 
Ordered 3 pupusas between the 2 of us, basil, spinach and one garlic and mushroom. Neither of us was extremely hungry so the amount was just right. All 3 were tasty though the garlic was a little burnt. Great tasting sauce and cabbage on the side. Will come again. 
Oh and it was fairly loud, louder with a small mariachi band who came in from the street.
author: Krista G.

description: Waited over 45 minutes for my food for it just to come out burnt . . . Didn't complain because I figured it was because they were so busy &&&&&&& still ordered 4 more to go & GUESS WHAT ?! They're burnt as well!!!!!!!! Notice the alert on Yelp for poor food health score !!!!!!! Stay away from this place !
author: Stephanie B.

description:
This place sho' is cheap! Definitely a hole in the wall and only about 3 blocks away from the BART station.
I came on Friday for dinner and there was a never-ending line outside (not long at all though at 7-8 PM at least) and lots of seating inside. Not the cleanest or newest interior but that's not what you should expect when you come here anyway. It's clean enough is how I'll put it.

I like how there's a grill outside, I'm guessing it's better ventilation for the cooks, but also helps lure people in. The only gripe about this is that the smoke goes INSIDE the restaurant so I kinda wish the grill was "more outside" but I'm guessing they can't do that for some kinda sidewalk regulation of some sort.

Onto the food. GODDAMN IT'S CHEAP. We got 6 pupusas and a beer for $21 ish (before tax) and we were both HELLA stuffed. Pupusas are $2.50 each.
I think my fav was probably the spinach one, I want to try the loroco one next time. They were all pretty good though and hits the spot for a cheap price. I like how you can actually taste the corn in the dough too.

Overall, I think Estrellita's Snacks (at the Alemany Farmer's Market on Sat) makes better pupusas but this place is cheaper and more accessible on the daily.
author: Emily C.

description: The sorriest plantains in the Bay Area; burnt to a crisp like a pilgrim at the stake. The lack of culinary conscience is appalling.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Really good pupusas!  My girls and I were craving some pupusas and were in the area. The food was great.

It was also a pleasant surprise that the restaurant (and bathrooms) were very clean. The young woman taking our order was extremely friendly.

The pupusas were $3 each. The selection was excellent, and there were many choices for vegetarians.
author: Mike K.

description:
quick update - there is still no wifi here (buy xfinity users can access that network and the speed seems fine right now) but if you are looking for a quiet place to work this is a great choice. it's never too crowded and all the tables are 4 seaters with plenty of room.

If you need power - there are outlets up high on either side of the front door so if you can get those nicely lit front tables you can get power for your laptop, phone etc.

also, i just realized the walls are painted to look like bricks and corrugated metal!
author: ari s.

description: Yes, they need to pay attention to cleanliness & the condition of the kitchen. Hopefully they'll correct all their problems because this can be a neat joint. Simple, homemade food straight from Central America. The papusas seem a little bland until you squirt the house-made salsa on them. I'm rooting for this place to get its house in order. It's affordable & delicious.
author: Jason L.

description: Ordered a spinach papusa and a couple of their "irresistible" cookies. The papusa was slightly bland and needed salt and their cookies didn't live up to the name. The cookies were pretty good but not good enough for me to stomach more than one. The atmosphere there was also interesting. One of the customers was making me uncomfortable. He kept trying to speak to me but I struggled to understand what he was saying. Another customer rudely just snatched our salt away immediately after asking for it, not even waiting for a response. The service was also absurdly slow.
author: David N.

description:
Delicious hot pupusas!  I love how they have it outside on the grill.  How could you resist?! 

I had the chicken one and the pork one... chicken is better!!  

Service = friendly.

Prices = reasonable.  I think it's cash only.

They have seating inside but I love the idea of "sidewalk" food.
author: Fannie S.

description: This place is incredible... so delicious! Unbelievable that each pupusa costs only $3. My husband and I shared 4 pupusas and had to take one home since we couldn't finish everything in one sitting.
author: Sabina K.

description:
Came here to try and I paid, I told the woman outside that I would like a chicken pupusa, she told me no, only pork...I said why? Do you have chicken she said yes, but she wouldn't make one for me. I went back inside annoyed and told them I wanted a refund, the lady inside had to get the people on the inside to make me one. Idk what it was with that lady, she also skipped over me in line...who knows, all I know is I won't be back.

I appreciate the person inside for fixing it and making me what I paid for.
author: Imani T.

description: LORD this restaurant gives me life. The pious as here are just so freaking BOMB. I love the whole vibe of the place, it totally feels like the marketplaces and street food areas that I visited in Mexico. The service is really great and everyone is so sweet. The guy who brought us our food (they cook the pupusas right outside on a mobile griddle) was cracking jokes at how much food we ordered. He was so cool. Love this place, def will be coming back for the amazing pupusas + their DELISH hot sauce and cole slaw.
author: Kyle D.

description: Godsend at 12:30 on a Mission Sat night. Probably best to order inside and take a seat because it can take a while and you wouldn't want your hangry friend to try and talk you out of this for quicker albeit inferior option nearby. Any pupusa is going to be great. I had the zucchini. Be sure and smother in the red sauce that comes on the table and try not be (too) afraid of the cabbage curtido-- it's lightly fermented so it probably going to be the healthiest thing you eat here. I can't wait to come back, and truthfully, I cannot wait to visit El Salvador someday because of this food.
author: Brian J.

description: I don't really like pupusas that much. I just think they're not nearly as good as tacos. But when they're made to order and hand pounded in front of you, the texture is noticeably better.They do that at Panchita's.
author: Misha T.

description:
In the past year, I feel like I've watched Panchita's blossom from an awkward, wallpaper, acne-faced teenage girl into a beautiful, confident young woman.

Last summer, this place was mostly empty, but had delicious pupusas. Then, earlier this year, they had the brilliant idea of placing a cart outside and making them fresh. All the passersby from the 16th and Mission BART station would stop by and wonder what they were because they smelled so delicious. At 2 for $5 (or 1 for $3), it was worth finding out! The crowd and lines started growing and people loved that they could watch them being made. Then, recently, they got a see-through display case that goes over the cart, which was fantastic because now all the people waiting for pupusas no longer have to smell like grease, and it keeps the heat in to help them cook faster! Now, this place is poppin every weekend night.

As a lactard, sadly, there are few options for me. One night after going out, La Cumbre ran out of Carne Asada, so I came here instead. The pupusas were so big I couldn't even finish my second one, but they were so delicious. And cheesy. My stomach was not pleased the next morning.
author: Cynthia W.

description: Great pupusas, great service, hate the crowds from the bars. They have veggie options that are great and again, the service is great.
author: Raul G.

description:
I was walking to the 16th Street BART station when the waft of yumminess stopped me.  And then I saw was a big 2 for $5 sign with a bunch of options for pupusa fillings.

They're genius for cooking them fresh right outside the restaurant because you can grab 'n go in literally less than 1 minute.  I would recommend eating it around there anyway because they have a big tub of hot sauce and a big tub of pickled vegetables that make the pupusa even better.

Because it's so hot, it could be a little flimsy in the paper wrapper and it could also burn your mouth so eat with caution.  I would say that this is one of the better pupusas I've had with flavorful meat, the right amount of cheese, a crispy outer, and a soft center.
author: Shannon L.

description: They were pretty fast, but the pupusas were very average I've definitely had way better! We came here during a break while we were performing so it was a quick lunch very filling but like I said very average pupusas and the beans and rice were not good!
author: Kayla W.

description: Yum! Delicious Papusas open late. Plantains are a little greasy, but everything else is on point. Try the cookie. I'll be back.
author: Marina H.

description:
$3 papusas with all the cabbage and salsa you desire. There are twice as many veggie options as meat at this low key authentic spot. I had the chicken papusa while my friend at the basil. Yes basil! 

I know I'll be back to try them all!
author: Jacqueline S.

description: Don't eat here late night . I recently got a stomach virus from this place and will never go back. I'm salvadorian go to Balompie instead .
author: Erica A.

description:
I travel a lot for business all over the US, and Pupuserias seems to find me!  I had been sitting in traffic for 90 minutes at rush hour on a Friday, just trying to get from the east Oakland area back to my hotel in the city.  Crooss the bridge, moving slowly through the Mission District, and I look over my left shoulder and BAM! Panchita's pupuseria was screaming my name!  took me a while to circle and find a spot to park.

Once inside, I ordered a variety of pupusas to go, and turned some friends on to them. One look at the cheese and bean pupusa, and I saw the handiwork of someone who has amassed years of rolling.  I expected good taste to follow and it did.  I tried some with some ingredients I was unfamiliar with, and it and some interior texture and spice that was unique.  Was in a hurry, so I didn't write down what it was, however I know there are spices and ingredients that are indigenous to various central and south american foods, so I never know what to expect, except that it will be tried and true, passed down through the centuries as a solid staple of the family meal.  And for $3.00 each?  Its a beautiful thing.
     I have been to El Salvador 3 times, have stayed with local families, and pupusas were served at every home cooked meal.  You know a good pupusa through taste and vision.  It takes years to get a really good feel for the corn dough consistency, and to be able to shape the dough into a little bowl or nest, lay in the proper amount of flavor and ingredients, then folds the nest over top, totally enveloping them, and then flatten with out leaking everywhere.  Only takes about 5 minutes to learn how to make a pupusa, a lifetime to perfect the technique, so I have a pretty good idea of the experience level of the cook just by their outward appearance.  
   This establishment has survived 30 years on this spot, so that tells me the experience level is there to create a perfect product.  Estas pupusas son perfectas!!   

Muchas gracious!

I keep practicing with my Salvadoran friends, so they taste good, but now I need them to look like I really know what I'm doing.  Same with my pie dough....truly an art form.
author: Tim S.

description:
Please read!!!! 

Worst Pupusas ever. The place is very nasty. I mean, this place is filthy!! The table and menu were sticky like if they never clean it. And they have their salsa in a big paint bucket. Gross. 

I asked for a cheese and bean Pupusas and OMG the inside of the Pupusas had all this little black stuff ( from when they scrape the grill and all that dirty burnt stuff come off) all mixed in the beans. 

Hell no I didn't eat it. I went back and showed the lady who cooked it and I told her I wanted my money back, and she got mad like if it was my fault. Worst customer service ever. Please don't go there. 
Oh and they are pricy took.
author: Karina G.

description: Dios mío! The pupusas were delicious! Stopped in while looking to kill 15 minutes over a quick bite, and were blown away by the incredible flavors of this traditionally simple food. We ordered the chicken and the jalapeño pupusas for this wondering. Will definitely plan on returning.
author: James D.

description: Killer pupusas.  Good thing I don't live nearby; otherwise, it'd almost be like FasTrak, walking past that food cart, with the only difference being I'd gladly pay that toll. My favorite: pupusas revueltas (chicharrones, cheese, and refried beans).
author: Tyrone V.

description:
In this city, we're pretty inundated with news about the latest overhyped, bougie cocktail haunts, brewpubs furnished with exposed beams and metal stools, the ten thousandth iteration of yet another eggs benedict, the new vegan-gluten-free-farm-to-table-raw-fresh-pressed eatery...and although I admittedly subscribe to it (I'M HUMAN OK) I'm pretty snoooozed by it all. How ironically San Franciscan of me to feel. 

Enter: Panchita's. I wouldn't even know about this little gem if my mission-dwelling beau didn't insist on stopping here EVERY time we walk by. Not that I have *ever* said no. Rather, I practically encourage it. I've probably consumed 2 dozen pupusas in 3 months. Ok maybe more. 

Bottom line: I need you to know that pupusas are stupidly good. I don't care what's in them. I don't care what time of the day it is. I don't care who was stabbed 5 minutes ago at the corner. All you need to know is that these little doughy pockets oozing (calm down I know that word is disgusting but it's too apt) with melted cheese and a variety of fillings so just go go GO and eat a few. They're usually cooking them up out on the sidewalk and will flip one right into your paws. 

They've quickly replaced my cravings for burritos, a feat I never dreamt possible. I simply love this place and all it's carby, dairy-filled glory. Break the cycle of the dumb food trends and go treat yourself to a simpler, better thing in life.
author: Meredith C.

description: 25+ minute wait for three pupusas to go. :( sadly not worth the wait unless you're in the mood to sit there for a long while. Poor service, but good pupusas.
author: Sabrina R.

description:
The pupusas are fantastic. The ladies cooking them on the street are amazing.
I can't wait to return.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description: Came here with a large group of people. So happy I didn't eat breakfast beforehand because this food is bomb! The carne asada, chicken pupusas, and plantains were fantastic! Can't wait to come back again :)
author: Eliana A.

description: These pupusas are great! I have had them several times now and they're always so good. I get the chicken, sometimes pork. The loroco is good too and I really love the curtido (pickled cabbage) that comes on the side. Price-wise, it's super reasonable and the service is always nice.
author: Amber F.

description: Panchitas knows how to make a pupusa. Stuffed enough to ooze out and give you that crisp cheese on the outside. Located on grimy 16th, but just like the block it's even better after 2am!
author: Luis L.

description:
Hot 
FRESH
Papusas 
HERE!!..
At Panchita's - Delicious loroco and cheese papusas are made fresh upon your arrival! The pickled veggies are nicely acidic with hints of sweet, & the beans are deliciously rich. The rice was nicely buttered and not over cooked, a definite Salvadorean staple! No Rice = A No Go! Panchita's offered fresh late night food made right in front of me which was a HUGE plus! They are open late for the night owl in me & located close to BART for those rare but drunken nights ; ).....
So whether you are roaming Mission for good eats near lunch, 
Or on a late night munchie quest,
This is your new Salvadorean go to place!

Totally affordable & fully satisfying! 
You wont be disappointed!
author: Honey B.

description:
After getting drinks at Blondie's around the block, we decided to step out and grab some delicious pupusas at the urging of my friend (she's done this many times in the past). It's literally only a couple minutes away from Blondie's and their pupusas are cheap! $2.50 will get you one deliciously hot, cheesy, filling pupusa. They have different types (beef, chicken, beans, spinach, etc) and it's served with a cole slaw and a mild hot sauce, that's slightly sweet.

The first time we came here tonight we got four chicken pupusas and brought them back to Blondie's to share with our friends. After Blondies we decided to return, but found they were closed (this was after 12 midnight on a Tuesday). They saw us standing outside and actually opened the doors to let us in! We ordered 5 chicken, 3 spinach, and 1 steak.

They gave it to us in take out bags, but after we asked if we could stay, they gave us 10 minutes until they had to really close. Good enough! It turns out we didn't get a steak one and ended up with 6 chicken and 3 spinach. A friend ordered a Corona for $4 to go with her grub.

I'll admit, if I can, I'll add the cole slaw and sauce to my pupusa because it makes it even that much more mouthwatering! Good, cheap food! Gotta love the Mission!

Would I return? Heck yeah! Especially after a late night of drinking, this place is spot-on. I think I prefer it over pizza.
author: Leana L.

description:
Had the pork and beef pupusa tonight! Soo good with the curtido and the salsa... Washed them with Modelo.  Friday night is complete! 
Will def return.
author: Nelce S.

description: Pupusas here are very fresh, cheap, and the place is open late. Whenever I go bar hopping in the Mission this place is my go to when the bars close. It says they close at 2 but believe me I've waited in line at 2:45 salivating over their tasty fare
author: Alex P.

description: I pushed boyfriend out of the car to pick me up papusas so this is my curbside review. The wait time was ages, this could be because boyfriend ordered five different papusas but most likely because I was sitting in the car salivating. Boyfriend reappeared with a steaming bag of deliciousness. Pork and cheese had me like woah; topped with pickled slaw and hot sauce I had a coming to Jesus (HAYY!-sus) moment. Panchita's makes it onto my personal Mission Food Tour list.
author: Skyla C.

description: Terrific little place.  Quick service, authentic food, totally affordable.
author: Matt M.

description:
This ain't your mama's kitchen, but it's pretty damn close. the only difference is that your mom would dote on you. pero La Señora es muy simpatica tambien! (she's just into her soap opera). ¡no hay problema! If you're above fetching your own glass of water, then don't bother.

but the FOOD is amazingly authentic! The fish was fried perfectly, the soup was full of good old fashioned flavor, and the portions...mucho gusto.

I would love to take mi mama here, but she might get jealous.
author: eVa J.

description:
Mediocre pupusas, 2 for $5, that take 10+ mins to come out.

Pour some warm cole slaw from a pitcher on your dirty table on them. Definitely add some hot sauce. It might kill some of the bacteria.

Ta-da! http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=eTZwHYcgs2zXnxqRu393ZA&userid=VCYtRcED5pBCZBwhEUI8Nw

There might be some miscellaneous charred bits from the grill on or inside your pupusas. 

See where I'm going?

Come here drunk.
author: K M.

description: I'm sad, I used to love this place sooo much and I loved their Pupusas.. but no more.. :-( The pupusas are subpar, the cabbage salad is dry - it really shouldn't be. I also ordered the fried plantains this time.. wahh they were sooo dry and not sweet at all. I'm really bummed but I just can't come here anymore..
author: Monica S.

description: Halloween night in the city, so what great way to end a good night with some papusas?! The line was literally out the door once we got there, but it didn't take too long. They have a great variety of papusas. I tried the chicken and the spinach and mushroom. It was pretty bomb!! It didn't take too long to come out either even though it was so busy. Hot, fresh, texture is perfect, and it was pure deliciousness! I don't remember how much I paid but whatever price it was, it was definitely worth it!!!!
author: Katrina M.

description: Prior to moving to the Bay Area we had never been exposed to pupusas. This place is PHENOMENAL. Pupusas are $3 each, and the quality is great. I would highly recommend this place to anyone. It's great for kids and families.
author: JB A.

description: This restaurant is ridiculously delicious. 10/10 would recommend to anyone looking for an authentic Salvadorian vibe and amazing food. Everything is pretty well priced and the service is great. If you have a chance to try this place, please do.
author: Kaya G.

description:
This is place legitimately amazing--the truest and purest of hidden gems. I don't understand why anyone would want to eat anything other than these papusa ever for the rest of their lives. It's a pretty long wait once you order, but they are hand made and worth the wait like you wouldn't believe. 
Yeah, the bad reviews have some solid points. It's kind of dirty, but are you doing to die? Probably not, and if you do, you would die happy.
author: Rebecca A.

description:
I think I'm in love.

A friend had a hankering for pupusas and Panchita's did not disappoint. I think I had the garlic and pork one... wow, so delicious. The masa to filling portion was perfect with not too much of either. I think we just spent a good 10-15 minutes just watching these pupusas artists work out in front of the restaurant because the speed and efficiency was nothing short of amazing.

There will be a wait and takes a good minute for your food to get there... but believe me, it's worth it.
author: Lorena M.

description: THE BEST PUPUSAS IN THE AREA! I think I go here once a week. They have plenty of vegetarian options too which is appreciated. The spinach one and the such ones are my favorite and every pupusa has cheese in it. They even have a beef option which is rare for pupusas. The staff varies. They have nice people there usually.
author: Eliza B.

description:
I LOVE THE PAPUSAS HERE!

Came here a few times with some friends and the quality of the papusas is great each and every time.  They fill and grill the papusas right outside the restaurant and you can see the whole process.  The folks here are super nice, and you may even get some entertainers who come in to serenade guests (please make sure to tip them!).  I like the spot, and it's quality stuff.  

The price for 3 papusas and a bottle of soda cost around 13 dollars so it's not the cheapest meal but well worth it!
author: Bernie C.

description:
I've only ever had the papusas at Panchitas... they are pretty good for the USA and super cheap which keeps me coming back (especially before I head out to the bars in the area).

I would normally never recommend a veggie option anywhere but I am in love with the mushroom and garlic papusa!
author: Alex W.

description:
My wife is from El Salvador so I have tasted my fair share of authentic pupusas. My favorite kind is plain queso. I ordered two of them and they were amazing. Very thick and stuffed with tons of cheese. They also give you a big tub of curtido and salsa de tomate. 

It took awhile for them to come out but I didn't mind too much since my food was being made so fresh.
author: Matt O.

description:
Starving on a Wednesday night around 9pm, I passed by on foot.  Just at the doorstep of this restaurant was a woman frying up pupusas made-to-order on a flat top grill, and a few people crowding around, waiting.  Well, I couldn't not try it!  I walked up to her to get a closer look, and she asked what I'd have.  I guess there's no line after all!  Not like she can't cook a dozen of these at a time on her fryer.  2 for $5, I ordered the pork-cheese, and the beef-cheese pupusas.  

After a couple minutes, she gave them to me, piping hot, on a paper plate.  I chose to eat-in though, as I was really in no rush.  You can eat these pupusas with some pickled vegetables, which makes it a reasonably balanced meal.  The pupusas reminded me of Russian peroshkis, except with cornmeal wrapping.  Perhaps I was starving, but I found them very satisfying.
author: Gerald C.

description: This place never lets me down. I'm all about the easy bean and cheese pupusa.
author: Josie C.

description:
This place is amazing after a night out. The ladies are so sweet and nice .. they must have a lot of kids at home because I would go nuts with a bunch of drunk ass hipsters coming at me at all directions. 

There were at least 4 different flavors.... chicken and cheese, cheese and fish, cheese and veggies..etc. The slaw is amazing, vinegar and tart that went perfectly with my hot pupusas. They are very filling with lots of meat! $3. Get the bananas, we missed out but they had them 5 minutes after we ordered. 

 The indoor seating was kind of dirty but I guess I cant expect much at 1:30am in the mission. They have plastic forks if you ask them nicely. People were super awesome and fun to hang out while we waited for the pupusas. It's made fresh so expect to wait. :)
author: Suzzie B.

description: This is a good Salvadoran restaurant. This is the first place I tried Bistec Salvadoreno (Salvadoran Steak). It is absolutely fantastic! I love their tamales too.
author: Peter K.

description:
In my opinion, this is the best, most authentic pupusa place in the city. They have a wide variety of flavors, and you can get 2 for $5 or 1 for $3. 

When you go to Panchita's you can either sit inside or just pick up some pupusas outside at the street cart. If you sit inside on the bench seating, there is slaw and salsa on each table and they have beer for sale. If you choose to grab your delicious pupusas from outside, there is a brand new set up. Panchitas recently upgraded to a nice outdoor cart with glass windows, which is a nice improvement. The pupusas just take a few minutes to cook so you're out pretty fast. They provide plastic forks if you need them and slaw and salsa in little bags to go. 

My favorite type of pupusa is called "the mix". It's a delicious mix of meats and cheese that is to die for. All of the pupusas are delicious though. They also have a bunch of vegetarian options. 

The ladies who make the pupusas are the sweetest ever. I always walk by on my way to and from work and they always smile and wave at me even if I don't stop by.

I usually get one pupusa, but two if I'm starving. My boyfriend get's three at a time he loves them so much. 

I only took off one star because I think they could make the inside restaurant a bit nicer. The food is delicious though. 

Must try!!
author: Juliet S.

description: Yummy, delicious  & fresh Pupusas. I was not familiar with the dish, but they made me a convert. Wonderful!
author: Renan R.

description:
I've never had a pupusa before, but I passed by on my way to visit the Missionary nearby and my friend was hungry.  You can't miss this place while you walk down the street.  You can smell it before you see it and it smells STRONG, to the point where I gagged a little (I'm sensitive, okay?).  I'm glad my friend stopped me and told me to get inside so we could try the restaurant because he was starving.  We ordered a beef and chicken pupusa without really knowing what to expect.

Lo and behold, it was delicious!  We scarfed it down and debated on whether or not to order more, but we were in a hurry and had to leave.  It was cheap and delicious.  I loved the corn dough and the filling was just the right amount and very tasty.  The bathrooms were clean and the atmosphere is very friendly and colorful.
author: A V.

description:
I don't know why I come back here:
The tables are stick,
The servers never smile,
and the food takes a really long time.

...It's probably because they open late and supply you with endless cabbage slaw. I always get pupusas with just beans and a plate of fried plantains with beans. I wish they could make loroco or spinach/mushroom pupusas without the cheese. I have only come to like plantains in the last 4 years after living with an Ethiopian roommate but they are pretty inconsistent with the texture of the plantains. Either way, I'll lick the plate clean! If you can eat spicy, look for the small bottles of XXX hot sauce.
author: Justine L.

description:
They raised the price and didn't create a better product or decrease the wait time - pupusas are now $3 each rather than 2 for 5. The business is not suffering because of the price increase, but the owner clearly wants to cash in without making the additional cost seem worthwhile. Customer service is still atrocious and you'll be met with hostility on any feedback or if you encounter any issues. 

This place is worth avoiding if you prefer courteous human interaction and value your time.
author: Jan S.

description: A friend recommended me to try papusa, since I've never had one, on our night out. I went there some times later and finally got to try. I didn't see a lot of variety on the menu so I ordered a simple pork papusa to try. It's delicious and good with cabbage and the sauce. $3 each is not bad for snack between meals or after some drinks. I completed my dinner with their beef and veggie soup (don't even know the name, just picked out from the picture outside). It's absolutely flavorful and tasty that made my feet want to dance lol
author: Yanakon D.

description: Pupusas were not that good & very so-so effort.  Come here if you're starving like I was but if you like pupusas like me go somewhere else.  The tables were dirty.  Horchata not very good and grainy.  Chips stale.  Sucks should've went next door to Pancho Villa.
author: Michael G.

description:
I tend to find Panchita's around Last Call or later. You know what I'm talking about, when you leave a bar and you're hungry, but not too hungry, and you want to take advantage of being in the Mission before going home. For this, Panchita's is perfect. It's super cheap, food comes quickly enough, and pupusa's can be eaten quickly while still being delicious. 

Wide selection of pupusa's here, of which I recommend Spinach, Loroco, Jalapeno, and Chipotle. These aren't the most amazing pupusa's you'll ever eat and it isn't the nicest restaurant I've ever been in, but it does the trick when you're out past 1 AM.
author: Eric L.

description: I highly recommend the pork pupusa over the chicken pupusa. The pork pupusa was moist and well flavored. The tortilla complimented the pork, and the hot sauce/pickled veggies gave everything a nice kick. On the other hand, the chicken pupusa was well seasoned but dense and dry. The chicken was packed, and seemed to separate from the tortilla.
author: Sam W.

description: They are open late for club goers, bar files and locals. Pupusas, Salvadoran beer, and don't forget Salsa Roja and Curtido which is available on the tables. They even have a cart outside on 16th St. for when you want to eat on the run. Go here for lunch, dinner or a late night snack.
author: Kevin S.

description: These papusas, when eaten with the salsa and the slaw that were available on the tables, were so incredibly delicious! I've never had better. $3 a pop, piping hot, and full of flavor. I shared a basil, a chipotle, and a mushroom & garlic one with my boyfriend -- all were so tasty! Such an unexpectedly great find.
author: Jen T.

description: After taking part in our umpteenth Great Urban Race scavenger hunt, the bestie and I decided to indulge in some pupusas. Many moons ago, this Panchita's was a sit-down place but now they are focusing on what they do best and that is hot off the grill pupusas. I had a spinach and a chicken and both were gooey goodness. We didn't mind sitting at the benches or the no-frills vibe.
author: Julie C.

description: Delicious and cheap pupusas! Great for late night bite to eat and friendly service. I had the beef but there were so many fillings to choose from. Comes with slaw and red sauce. I ordered it to go but it's messy to add the sauce on the go and it's pretty dry by itself. Next time, I'll eat in.
author: Semuteh F.

description: Such good food I can't even explain... how much I love their pupusas. They're real big. 5 bucks for 2 big ol ones is a good deal. And the inside is so cute and clean.
author: Robyn K.

description: This place is so good! It hits the spot and is always on the itinerary for night life in the mission.
author: Alex S.

description:
First time having a papusa and it was delicious! 2 for $5 papusas with so many varieties to choose from. They also have the little dessert alfajor at the side of the register which was delicious as well

A decent cheap eat
author: Dorris W.

description:
At Panchita's #2, every table hosts two large, uncovered jars filled with homemade slaw and hot sauce, and a roll of paper towels. There's no telling how long the jars have been there, how often they're refilled, or whether the long ladles in each jar have ever seen a dishwasher. This is Panchita's way. This is not somewhere you go if you're highly susceptible to mud butt.

The pupusas are cooked on a grill by the door and arrive at your table in a smeary mess on a paper plate. Do not expect the pillowy, immaculate pupusas of Balompie, with all the contents sealed neatly inside. Panchita's pupusas taste like the grill, via skidmarks of cheese crisped brown.
