When it's really busy, your pupusas might be undercooked, oozy and separating lengthwise. The center cannot hold. On New Year's Eve, a stranger will sit down and fall asleep at your table. When it's empty, no one will rush to serve you.

Panchita's is a worthy drunk bite after visiting what John Waters called the "many alarming bars" in this stretch of the Mission. You ladle out the slaw and the hot sauce and dive in. While the pupusas may arrive unkempt or not quite done, they generally taste very good. One time my friend was enjoying her meal so much that she ate part of the paper plate.
author: Ly C.

description: We first stumbled on this place during a "Sunday Streets" event in the Mission a few months back.   There was a grill set up curbside of the establishment and people were in line ordering. We opted to eat inside.  Best Papusas on town if ya ask me.    There's at least a dozen varieties but I always get Chicharrónes and a Queso Papusa.  I always want to try more but they are very filling.   Curtido comes in a huge jug with tongs so you'll never run out as also with the salsa.  The Salsa also comes in an obnoxiously over sized container and is a mild almost pasta sauce consistency.  Service can be a little slow sometimes but it's worth it.  You'll have to wait a couple minutes more when your food arrives anyway... the papusas come piping hot!  There has been recent upgrades on the aesthetics as well.(Note:  Yelp has the name spelled wrong,  it's Panchita's Pupuseria)
author: John W.

description:
I usually only get pupusas here. And my rating is based on the pupusas and the service. 

The service sucks. It's awful. I know serving people isn't fun, I get it. But this is a family business and everyone that works here is related some how to the owner. If I were staff I would serve with more enthusiasm. Instead my server always comes at me with a pissed off attitude. I only come back cause I miss having a real pupusa from El Salvador and it's close to my place for now. 

The pupusas are not too bad here. Obviously in El Salvador they are better. And Panchita's fills my need... But flavor wise it could be way better. And the pupusas always come to me more burned than they should. Guess it could be worse.

By the way, they no longer serve chips and salsa before your meal.
author: April A.

description: Um, this is amazing food to have while you're bar hopping in the mission. Puerco for the win!!!!!!
author: Patrick T.

description: Waited forever for 2 beef papusas, but man was it welcome on a chilly night! Would love it if they had more beef though.
author: Boris K.

description: The food is just OK and the place is seriously filthy. Tables, pitchers, walls, pretty disgusting!
author: E M.

description:
Stopped here about 10 pm tonight because they smelled so good.  Who can resist this set up, they are cooking right on sidewalk

We stood there quite awhile, thinking we were in line to order.  Thank goodness someone standing by us finally told us, you go inside, order, pay, get a ticket stub, and another lady gives ticket to ladies cooking in front.

 It's kinda not organized quite right and the wait can be long . I really just wanted to hand her five bucks and get our pupusas in one step.

I ordered the mushroom one, which was okay. I'll try the spinach one next time. The hubby got the pork and it was Dee-----lish

I also think what's a lot of fun is that you are right in the middle of Mission street and Valencia street. We had homeless asking for money while we stood there, we had drunks  coming and going from bar next door, singing, etc. we had well dressed tourists from England, asking us why are you queued up and what's a pupusa, ???!!!   It was drizzling and the umbrella protecting her grill blew down etc etc It was quite the experience!!!

We saw Julia Jackson's  "Children Are Forever. All Sales Final. " over at Stage Werx prior to stopping here on way to Bart
author: Foodlover B.

description:
2 pupusas with rice and beans on the side for $5!!! 

Absolutely delicious, made to order and so filling. Service sucks, you're pretty much fending for yourself. 

Bathroom was gross...pee all over the floor and toilet. They make the pupusas at the front door so expect your hair and clothes to smell like smoke/food.
author: Lydia L.

description: Best drunk food at an amazing price ($3 per pupusa) but DAMN, the inconsistency. I would've gladly given 4 stars but had to knock one off due to my last experience. Normally I come in late at night when it's packed, but I stopped by for a cheap lunch one day and waited at least 20 minutes for two pupusas, to find that they got my "beans and only beans" order wrong. I ordered the chips and guacamole as well and it was hardly even mashed, completely different guacamole than I've had on my nights here. The restaurant was hardly busy, so I'm not sure what was going on. I will absolutely be back but just be aware of a lack of consistency - maybe stop by later in the night.
author: Emily A.

description: This place is my go-to spot in the Mission for delicious papusas. It's only $3.00/papusa. The beef and loroco papusas are my favorite here! It gets a little rowdy late at night but still a great spot.
author: Nike S.

description:
Oh what happened to this place? Ever since they renovated, I feel like the quality of their pupusas have lowered immensely.  They went from fantastic a year ago to great six months ago and now they're just "meh". It takes forever for them to make them even if it's not that busy and the last few times I've visited, they are squishy and doughy.  I'd like to be able to taste the spinach, loroco, or beef in my pupusa. But now all I taste is mush.  It's also 50 cents more expensive here for one pupusa than at a different pupuseria. 2.50 for one. 

I do however love the people that work here.  They are extremely hard workers that stay open as late as people are hungry.  You could potentially come by for a pupusa on the weekend here at 4am.  I know on Halloween night they were open until close to 6am. I really do commend their work ethic.
author: Jodie L.

description:
This place is no frills down right delicious Salvadorian eats. For a yummy and authentic meal, I highly recommend pupusas con queso y loroco (flower buds). Two or three pupas should fill you up. Don't forget to ask for the cabbage! 

Don't let the drab decor fool you. This hole in the wall spot is solid.
author: Matthew J M.

description: If your big fan of pupusas this place is for you! Prepared on the spot outside in the front of the restaurant. I lived in the Mission for 2 years and for some reason I never ate here. Finally tried it out and I was very impressed. I ate two of them and I was full! The plantains are pretty good as well here. Very affordable and fast service! Thumbs up for Panchita's.
author: Black Frankenstien ..

description: Horrible customer service I suggest never coming here the place is dirty as well never come here on a weekend because they will treat you as you don't exist and probably wait for hours to get food. Better off going elsewhere.
author: Reynaldo G.

description:
Came here for some late night pupusa's after a comedy show at Stage werx.

service was confusing, but who cares, the pupusas were delicious and CHEAP!

2 pupusas for $5, you can't go wrong. they also have veggie options. will definitely come back here when im wandering around the mission late at night! bring CASH!
author: Aunik B.

description: The best $3 meal at midnight you can get! The pupusas here are fresh and delicious, and they have so many varieties to choose from. One pupusa is more filling than it looks, yet I always find myself getting two then struggling to finish the second. The wait for pupusas after you order can take a while on a busy weekend night, so get an alfajore as a snack while you wait, they are delish!
author: Lauren G.

description: Visiting SF for the weekend and this was one of the first places I wanted to eat. They have remodeled from the last time, but food still just as good as I remember! Always get the 2 pupusas meal for only $8!
author: A J.

description: Not 4 star for sure!! Puposas are very oily and tamale was the worst I have ever tried. Place is clean though and they definitely try to keep a cool environment.
author: Blerta K.

description: $3 for fresh pupusas.  That's perfect for my student budget.  A bit greasy but definitely hits the spot.  They're pretty filling so don't be a fatty like me and order 3.  I felt like death for the next couple of hours.  Be reasonable and order 2.  I recommend chicken and pork.  That's plenty, trust!
author: Tammy N.

description: Just had the best pupusas in town. Bomb diggity!!!
author: Della M.

description:
After a night out in the area we couldn't decide on what food to eat, with all the carts and restaurants open.  We came across this place and decided to give it a shot, especially since it wasn't too busy with only 2 other tables there.

So we came in and sat at a table, no one gave us menus or paid us any attention.  So I went up to the counter and the woman pointed to my table to try and tell me that she'd be right with us.  She couldn't speak much English, and neither could anyone else there.  Which made things very difficult.

She came over with our menus and as she began to walk back to the counter another party came in.  She handed them menus and went back to the kitchen.  She came out after about 10 minutes, which by then we had BEEN ready to order.  She approached the other table first and took their order, which kinda irritated us since they had came about 10/15 minutes after us.  She then walked back to the kitchen, came out after about 5 minutes then took our order.  The other table, of course, got their food first and ours followed about 5 minutes after.

The language barrier made it very difficult when we were trying to ask questions and requests being that it was our first time eating pupusas.  And in the end I believe that I would've given this place 4 stars if the service was better and 5 if the place looked clean.

But hey, if you just want some good pupusas and don't care about service or anything else I listed above then this is the place for you.  I'll probably only do take-out at this place from now on.

Oh, and if you do come here ... try their hot sauce.  It's delish!
author: Pia V.

description: So this place decided to charge $3.00 for each pupusa. These are usually  1.25-1.50 ea anywhere. This is ridiculous!!! There isn't even no special technique on how to definitely make these, i even know how to make these. definitely outside of the average price range. A true abuse of you the new Comer to SF. As a true Salvadorian and San Franciscan is a complete abuse of customers. This price clearly serves the need of the ownership whose kids drive around in Mercedes Benz. let's unite as a community and show these people that taking advantage of clients is just not right. Feel free to visit the numerous other pupusa places in the city who keep their prices fairly to You. Feel free to support the family  kids luxurious life style I f u desire
author: Jeannette A.

description:
If you don't know what pupusas are supposed to taste like, then this is the spot. As a Salvadorean I'm upset that this place has gotten the attention that it has as of recent. It's not that it's horrible, it's just not that good.

The Curtido (cabbage slaw) is under-pickled and they use the include the shitty parts of the cabbage, like the core and the outer dry leaves. They also give you very little, which makes you keep asking for more. Additionally, their cheese is pretty shitty, and not what I've had at almost every other pupusa place. They are average, and I will only go to this place if I don't want to walk to the nearby Balonpié or Los Panchos. They leave them on the plancha long enough that they're toasty, so they have that going for them, but other than that these subpar pupusas.
author: Erick R.

description:
The giant writing on the window in front saying "pupuseria" grabbed our attention as we passed by this unassuming spot. Well, who isn't a sucker for a pupusa (sorry lactose intolerants and vegans :(...) Yes, the service was slow, so don't think of this place as a fast food place. It's more like a Sunday stroll, get-my-pupusa-on type of place.

 The pupusas were exactly what I expected. Delicious! I had the cheese and pork pupusa, and randomly tried the plantain empanada which wasn't what I expected. I was expecting an empanada with a plantain filling. What I got was an empanada made of plantains with some mystery white sugary frosting filling. Not extraordinary and not worthy of ordering again. Next time I would order the fried plantain! The chips and salsa they put out at the beginning were very lack lustre. Chips weren't made from corn tortillas (I think they were broken up pieces of tostada) and the salsa was just a spicy red sauce... Turns out the salsa ended up being perfect on the pupusa and the coleslaw they brought of with the pupusa was also a great companion to the pupusa. I would come here again if I were in the neighborhood, had time and wanted to pig out on pupusas! 

Note: as I continued writing this post, the word pupusa got increasingly more fun to say, and a giant smile broke out on my face. Try it *PUPUSAS!*
author: Gabrielle F.

description: Simply the best. Home to the first papusas I ever tried and still the standard by which all other papuserias are judged.
author: Ryan N.

description:
Would be a 5 star for sure if it weren't for the ridiculously slow service.

You sit, you wait, you order, you wait even more, you finish your meal you wait even more to pay it.

I came in here today and saw a girl sitting at a table looking sad.  She had a Pepsi.  I sat down with my girlfriend.  We waited.  We ordered.  The girl still looked sad.  We waited.  Our beers finally arrived but no chips and salsa to tie us over.  The girl still looked sad.  We waited.  Our pupusas arrived, we begin eating, the sad girl is watching us ravenously eat our food.  We just about finish and her burrito FINALY arrives.  We finish our food.  We wait.  We get our bill and pull out cash.  We wait.  We pay our bill, we wait.  The girl finishes her burrito, her waiting continues.

Seriously, the food is great and well priced.  The waiting is just god aweful and almost makes it not worth it.  I've been here a few times and will come back, but I don't have enough free time to be a regular.

A side note; this place really needs a trash can in the bathroom, seeing a pile of wet paper towels on the ground in the corner where the trash can should be really makes one question their sanitation.
author: D D.

description: I got the beef and chicken pupusas. Kind of a let down. Tasted like bland not very good pancakes. Definitely needed the sauce.
author: Heather R.

description:
Nothing crazy about this hole in the wall in the mission. I came for the pupusas and was not disappointed. Good selection of fillings and always made on the spot. 

My favorite is always the pork, but the bean and spinach are excellent too. At $3 a pop, you can afford to experiment too. 2 is good for a normal human. 

The cabbage and salsa are standard for the salvadoran experience. Use liberally and tip well.
author: Chris C.

description: I didn't need food just before going to bed on a work trip. I didn't need a pupusa. I didn't need to stay up any later, it was already midnight. But I did. I saw those pupusas grilling on that street cart and I stopped. And I waited. And I burned the hell out of my mouth and tongue when I took my first smoldering hot bite. It was delicious, painful, and of little regret. Carpe diem.
author: Adam C.

description:
Yes, my friends. These puspusas are the absolute best thing in San Francisco. Frankly, God could hit the delete key on the rest of the 7x7 and you'd still have yourself one hell of a town!

I like to eat there only when the ladies are out front with their pupusa-making cart, frying up the hottest freshest pupusas this side of the Andromeda cluster. 

I like the pork & cheese or bean & cheese (the cheese crisps up brown on the hot grill emitting that "I don't know what" flavor that consistently cause my eyes roll back into my head as I shout expletives for 20 minutes into a bucket).

We accidentally got a zucchini one too and I hate to say it son, but it was also fantastic! 

An essential part of the pupusas is the toppings and let's be honest folks -- at most of these places -- they chintz you on that. Even when you say "EXTRA" and gesture real big (round-tummy, happy-customer)...not because of any language barrier, mind you, but just because you're just  a really big pig who knows how these things work!

Well, here, they just leave a bucket of the toppings on the table for you to empty at your discretion. I think I may have taken advantage of this situation but I'm sure it all balances out in the end.

Either/either come here at night when they're frying outside and you will not be dissapointed! Accompany with drinking at the nearby bars like Amnesia or Elixir or the secret bar behind that one bar...whatever floats your boat, there's a ton.
author: Ryan S.

description: The pupusas are delicious. Not greasy like others I've had. Will definitely return here next time I'm in frisco.
author: Jesse V.

description:
The papusas here are awesome.   It's the perfect meal to eat after a late night of drinking.  I'm not sure what time they close, but I think it's pretty late.

Not only are they good, they're cheap.  Most of the times when I come here, I get the pork.  The pork is tender and seasoned perfectly.  Make sure you add the slaw into your papusa.  It makes it that much better!  I only wish the hot sauce they have was hotter.  

Come here, you won't be disappointed!!
author: Eddie F.

description:
I am not a Pupusa expert, but wow are they fantastic at Panchita's. I ordered the Pupusa Revuelta, which contains pork, cheese, and beans. I used to work with a couple of people from El Salvador. They always used to tell me about Pupusas, but I never got around to trying them until now.

I should also mention the people who work at (or probably own) this place. They are extremely friendly. You just get that Mom and Pop vibe when you're eating here. It's tough to describe, but you definitely know it when you experience it. I'm definitely a fan of this place.
author: Paolo D.

description:
After grabbing dinner and drinks close by and mindless walking around, we were tempted by the lady making pupusas by the door. It doesn't take much to get us to eat some more, as apparently there is always room for greasy fried food or ice cream (we got both that night).

The lady by the door was hand rolling each corn ball with your choice of meat and/or veggie with cheese before placing them on the grill. Greasy, crispy, meaty, and cheesy goodness...need I say more? Stuffed to go, we walked and ate in the San Francisco chill evening with an amazing meal.

I'll be back to confirm if these bad boys are worth it, but my stomach is already waiting for the next time I can consume these pupusas when I'm in the area.
author: Casey L.

description:
This place is a tourist trap. It caters to the bridge and tunnel crowd who come to Valencia street to get drunk. 

Above all, the service is poor and the food is not that great. Try one of of the pupuserias in the Mission.
author: Carlos C.

description:
So good! I have to say the pork was the best choice! The chicken was too cheesy and flavorless but edible! The staff is nice but I think forgot about us cuz they are slammed with people walking by stopping in to order (I mean how could 
You not stop?-the aroma fills the air for blocks)! 

Worth every penny! It's one of those places you just have to try for 2.50 each it would be a shame to walk by and not try one!!
author: Raina S.

description: Pupusa heaven.  If it's greasy, cheesy and meaty eats you crave just pop into here!
author: Carmel U.

description:
Ok went to check this place to see what the fuzz is all about. Keep in my mind I am a true Salvadorian and expect the best from El Salvador. I come from the street of "LA" where  they truly have the best pupusas restaurants in the U.S.  The day started with a S.F. Giants game. And headed off on 16th st after the game. I'm new in town and went sightseeing and wanted to end up at Pier 39, but I glanced over and saw this place and remembered the reviews it had, so I had to, just had to see what the fuzz is all about. First of all, I locked my keys in my truck and took me several minutes to break into my own car.  Ha-ha, yes I am and have had a bad boy reputation. Any who, I noticed it's not a very good neighborhood to have a simple no alarm type car. Right-a-way I saw some wanna be thugs eyeing my truck...  

Okay now for the food part, "What the F**K"  happened????????  This place needs a major, and I do mean call up Chef Ramsey for a "Major Remodel"... place is a dump.... Chairs look like a 70's car with chipped paint.  They need to hire a steam cleaning professional for those floors.  And the tables are so sticky, that you have to yank your arm off them..  Now parking is ridiculous  here, so I was only able to find 30 mins so I took my pupusas to go....... The ladies, "and I am being nice here', look like they are fed up of this place and probably need a 30% raise in order to see a smile from them. , and yes they need to block off that ghetto kitchen in there, it's so old, that they hire a wineno to pick up the cervesa bottles. .and  the menu handouts are so fucking dirty...and missing a lot of pages.......


For those of you that don't know how to reheat a pupusas at home, here's how..

You use a tortilla griddle thingy to heat them up at medium... You flip them often for about 3-5 mins should do, unless you want them crispy, than flip them for  about 10 mins.... 
Any who, even if I ate the pupusas there, I would still give them a "3" out of 10....   The chicharon is not quite smashed properly cause you shouldn't bite on pieces of pork, it should all be melted with the cheese as it cooks, trust me, I know how to and have made pupusas myself....The curtido I give a 6 out of 10.  Not bad.........but seems like 3-5days old, and curtido should always be crisp, not old.....  the Salsa has to go....4 out 10 here. It's not supposed to be mild at all in order to allow those that don't like hot stuff..... bad decision on that part, but for me personally I like the mild stuff, but it needed more flav of flav to it.. Maybe some chicken bullion would have done the trick......


Overall,  luckily I was in town chilling and sightseeing,  otherwise this dump is not worth my time coming from the Tri-valley area......
author: JJ C.

description:
I've passed by this spot on multiple occasions and probably would have passed it again had it not been for the lady freshly grilling the pupusas at their door.  I spun back, and got myself 2 for the road.

I can confidently say the best pupusas I've had (or at least #2).  As of late, whenever I've gotten a pupusa craving, I've been pretty let down.  I honestly wasn't expecting much here, but it was too tempting to ignore.  Plus 2 for $5 is a pretty sweet deal. So I was very pleasantly surprised on the outcome here.

The Loroco was a veggie that's common in Central America, but I hadn't seen it before so I gave it a shot. Not bad, kinda nutty flavor, but I'll probably stick to meat the next time.  The Pork one was the real star here: SO FUGGIN' GOOD. Plus they are not shy about loading up on the cheese. Surprisingly, the paper bags holding them didn't become see-through, so it wasn't as greasy as it probably could have been and still managed to be super cheesy and savory.
author: Alan W.

description:
So hard to walk past that papusa grill on the sidewalk without taking a detour to buy 2.  I love those things!  The papusa with BEAN, CHEESE, and PORK is my favorite.  Bean and Cheese is good too.
 I haven't aquired the taste for the Salvadorean greens.. kinda like squash blossom or spinach.
The rest of the menu is a little underwhelming, and their Papusa isn't quite as good as B@lompie, but I like them just fine.

If you are going out hard on 16th or Valencia, this is a good place to fill your belly before you have those 5 vodka-sodas.
author: Christian W.

description:
Yes, the service can be slow. It's a family run business that employs two people....what do you expect?! It is also amazing food. The Loroco is my favorite. (It is a type of flower, that is picked before it blooms). For 5 dollars you can get a whole lunch here...I challenge to you to find any better deal than that! 

Don't forget to eat your pupusas with the "slaw" that they come with.
author: Abby M.

description: My friends and I were waiting for her boyfriend.  While waiting, the guy claiming it was his family business came... Grabbed our bag (yes our outside snacks) and he threw it outside the restaurant saying since we hadn't bought anything we had to leave. He was a tall guy wearing a shirt reading "I love pupusas". Not only did he lack customer service and professionalism, but he also pushed my friend. Not only was is she short, but also she's was a girl. Nothing to compare with when in the event of a self defense case.Terribly disappointed with a joint where not only did my family, since almost 15yrs has gone and saw how the joint has changed. But also, If you want to show up off your family business off, that was not the way to do it.
author: Tatiana C.

description: I'll never say no to Papussas at midnight, at dinner, at lunch, at breakfast, or at even 2am. At least if I'm going here. Dont look any further than this place. You cannot go wrong! from different varieties of papussas to a nice atmosphere to chill in. Bascially we orered every papaussa on the menu. Except the pork. Spinahche and cheese. Chicken, Mushrooms and Garlic, and some others i really can't remember. Made fresh, and served hot. Tale has unlimited helpings of cabbage pickled salad and hot sauce. Eeat them with our without the condiments your choice. Whatever you do, just come here dont searched any further.
author: Lina M.

description:
Came here for some pupusas last night. I usually get the Cheese & Loroco and Spinach & Cheese with the Pupusa Plate order (comes with rice and beans). Very yummy...definitely hits the spot each and every time!

Whenever, I crave pupusas, this is the place that comes to mind. The first time I came here was several years ago after a drunken night next door at Skylark and remember the food being so good! I always wondered if I thought it was good only because of my intoxication food craving that night or if the food was really that good. The next visit, I was sober and the pupusas still did not disappoint! I can't speak for the other food items on the menu because I always get the pupusas whenever I come here.

Like most reviews mentioned, don't expect a fast and attentive service here with only one person taking the orders, serving the food, and working the register, especially on a busy weekend night.
author: Barbra C.

description: their pork and zucchini pupusas are the best around!! and they're very generous with the curtido which makes this place even better
author: Ariel A.

description:
I went here for the first time today and just had some pupusas. They ranged from somewhat good to meh - good for a quick bite since I was in the neighborhood, but nothing to rival my go-to pupusa spot Balompie Cafe.

The espinaca y queso was the best - a little messy, but tasty - especially with a little curtido (relish). The pollo y queso was still good, but not quite as good as the spinach. And finally the bean and cheese pupusa, while tasting okay, smelled bad - I think it was just a little burnt.

I wouldn't mind giving them another try, maybe tasting some of their other items, but I'm not in a big hurry to go back.
author: Seth N.

description: My friend and i drive 30 minutes from palo alto just for the pupusas... since they're made to order, you have to wait a little but TRUST it is worth it. its cute af and open pretty late, which makes it the perfect late night snack after a couple of cocktails at blondies or skylark.
author: Little S.

description: Very delicious, not because is from El Salvador but Salvadorean food is the best for me of course.
author: Karen F.

description: Dear god thank u for making this deliciously and cheap food for me to eat when I'm drunk.  Every papusa I tried was amazing here!  Great snack or drunk food, highly recommended to any one I'm the city looking for a good tasty snack at a great price.  Can't wait to come back and try it again sober so I don't throw it up like the last time.
author: James F.

description:
4 or 5 stars for food, 3ish stars for atmosphere.

Really good pupusas in the Mission District.  They serve burritos and Mexican food too.  I think the polo y queso pupusa was really good, while the chicharon was so-so.  The portions of everything are huge, though.  3 of my friends and I all ordered 2 pupusas, and were stuffed.  3 other friends with us ordered burritos, which were, quite possibly, the largest burritos I've ever seen in my life.  They.  Were.  Huge.

When I walked in, I feel like the whole restaurant stopped to look at me.  It wasn't because I was the only white person or anything (the restaurant had a good mix of people in it and SF is an accepting place anyways...).  The place was just dead quiet.  When my friend and I walked in, one of our other friends was putting songs on the jukebox to break the awkward silence in the restaurant.  It felt kind of odd to have a conversation at our table, since it seemed like everyone was being forced to listen to it as a result of the weird restaurant atmosphere.  Eventually, we ended up with a party of 8, which in itself made the place a little more lively and inviting.  One of the guys with us had brought his guitar, which also helped the atmosphere a bit.

Service is slow and occasionally you might feel a little ignored.  I'm still not certain if you're supposed to order at the counter or wait to be waited on.  Speaking Spanish helps a bit, so if you can, do it.  All in all, a tasty place to eat and, as long as you bring the party, you should be fine.  I wouldn't necessarily recommend eating here with any size group larger than maybe 2, though, if you have something to make it to (like a movie, show, or whatever...like we did).
author: Brian B.

description:
Puerto Alegre was too crowded, so we walked back over here.  I'm so glad this was the case!  You order your food at the counter, they serve a variety of beers.  I had a papusa plate, which came with three cheese and bean papusas, rice, and beans.  I haven't had a ton of Salvadorean food, but I have had papusas from four different places and these were by far the best!  They weren't too greasy, they were crispy and super yummy.  

I wanted a tamale, but they were out, so I settled with a carne asada taco.  The meat in this carne asada taco was so damn good!  It was AMAZING and super yummy.  It came with guacamole, no extra charge, which was fresh and yummy as well.  

I was with a couple of other people and we shared the plantains with beans and sour cream.  These were better than Cha Cha Chas!!
author: Sarah B.

description:
Horrible service- had to ask for our drinks after 15 minutes, and our  food arrived 45 mins late! The waitress was young and chatting it up with her teenage friends...

That said, the popusas were the bomb.com- I would suggest ordering to go as many had.
author: Candy A.

description: They can make the pupusas vegan, just ask. Loroco + beans. Hold that damn cheese.
author: Katherine F.

description: Great pupusas, cheap prices, and as much pickled cabbage and salsa as you need. The plantains were also delicious. Their mushroom and garlic pupusa is definitely my favorite!
author: Jessica L.

description: Came here by accident but was pleasantly surprised. Their Papusas are the best specially the mushroom one and  they come piping hot from the pan. No frills just a great place with authentic El Salvadoran food.
author: Nisha A.

description: Yummy late nite papusas! Sometimes the line is long, but who wants to go home hungry after a night of drinking, not this girl!!
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Delcious pupusas.  Great red sauce that they serve with them.  Fresh/hand made

Family run

Went in to catch the end of Belgium vs. USA in the World Cup and no one could be bothered to take my order until there was a lull in the game.  I found this super charming. 

Very low key.  

They often have someone out front on gorgeous Mission nights grilling pupusas.

An awesome neighborhood staple.
author: Meg M.

description: Best place to come eat pupusas after a night of going out to one of the near bars/lounges. Very good prices and the food doesn't disappoint.
author: Abraham G.

description: I seriously don't know what all the hype was over this place ! The cashier was beyond rude . She was demanding and trying to rush us to hurry and order. The pupusas were 3 each which is reasonable but the drinks were 3 dollars each for a can of coke.. Ridiculous !!!! The actual pupusas were okay nothing special !!! Defiantly not coming again
author: Nabille S.

description:
Came here after a good night. First time having a Pupusa and it was great.

They had jars of pickled veggies at the tables which I thought added a nice welcome effect.

I remember there was as jukebox too, which is kindda cool.

Cash only from what I remembered, they have a stand outside so you don't have to go in and sit down but that option was open to us even though it was late night. Good place to get to know people post hanging out.
author: Thanh T.

description:
Good: A wide variety of tasty papusas for cheap.

Bad: Slow service and greasy food.

The quality is what you would expect for the price - cheap cheese and ingredients, but it will push a turd out and it is probably worth 4 stars if you're drunk.
author: Meow S.

description: I don't know what the big deal is here. I ordered a loroco pupusa and jalapeño pupusa and they were just mushy inside. I don't know if it was actual cheese but it it didn't seem like it. The curtido had no flavor, and the cashier was rude.
author: Jenny M.

description: This place is a JEM! The food was so good, and tons of veggie options. The woman working was so lovely and dealt with all of my obnoxious behavior and even started a duet with me! Swoon! I will be back.
author: Jourdain D.

description: Simple and basic and AWESOME! Loroco = pumpkin flower blossom, straight back to childhood, in an odd sort of way! Try it.
author: George L.

description:
*consistently good pupusas great for drunk snack or meal 
#pupusanation
#pickledcabbage

One of the first places I ate drunk in SF and I was wowed. Being from San Diego I thought California burritos were the end all be all drunk food. Pupusas here give them a run for their money. 

4th time I've been here and spotty service. Amazing pupusas and great salsa and pickled cabbage. Haven't tried anything else but I think they have a stable business of just serving these.

Worth overlooking for the mediocre service
author: Kevin T.

description: If the pupusas served here are the pride of El Salvadorian, I'm embarrassed for the palates of El Salvador. The pupusas were excessively greasy, overly salted, floppy pieces of mess on my plate. There is something to be said about having texture contrasts in food - these were all mush and grease. If only the food matched the eagerness and outward pride shown on the cook's faces showcasing their nation's food..
author: Henry W.

description: This place is awesome!!! The food is great and I lost my wallet here and I called and they had it for me.  The mushroom and garlic pupusas are amazing.
author: Matthew E.

description: The pupusas here are good as are the beans. The best are beef, zuchini, and mixed. Plenty of slaw and sauce and water refills. Service was okay. Great location for after party munchies and open late.
author: Adrian A.

description:
First visit, very good food, had the combination #1 which consisted of a beef taco, chicken enchilada, rice and beans, and also ordered a chicken and cheese pupusa. Some of the best Mexican food I've had in a while. 

The vibe of the place was up people were pleasant, music was playing and it felt like a Taqueria in Mexico.

Only complaint was service was a teeny bit slow, probably because there seemed to be only one woman doing almost everything. Can't fault it too much for that. 

Will return!
author: Jessika H.

description: Delicious and fresh.  Vegetarian options that are amazing and filling.  Perfect place to stop in for a quick snack or meal
author: Emily P.

description:
Kind of hiding behind that news press box out front Panchita's finds you wandering around the Mission, wondering which taqueria to choose.
Pick me! Unassuming, but entirely authentic, this location caters to it's regulars and wanderers like me.

The lunch was good and well priced. Home made corn chips and Chipotle Salsa, are served up. 
Beef hard shell Taco's and yummy beans and rice sustain us through the afternoon.

The place itself is like a bit of an architectural museum, the floor tiles seem to tell a story that takes you back in time. This isn't a romantic spot. No, it's more of an adventure.
author: Roanna Z.

description:
I don't often do double takes while walking in the Mission.  Absurd sights are to be expected.  However, when I see a grill smoking on the street and Spanish being spoken, I cannot help but wander my body back in the direction of such potential sensory stimulation.  I have never had a pupusa before.  What has my life been?  What a waste of 24 years?

I was given the option of spinach and cheese, beans and cheese, pork and cheese, or chicken and cheese.  I first opted for pork and cheese.  Like any bad Jew, I love pork more than I love half of my living relatives.  Alas, a pork pupusa had not been assembled yet and I was in a rush.  I instead went for a chicken and cheese.  This delectable beauty set me back a mere $2.75.  Pennies!  Not only did I get a griddle corn cake sammy stuffed with melted cheese and shredded chicken, but this saucer of savoriness came with a small salad erupting with fiery salsa.  My mouth has not felt such wonders.  I gobbled my pupusa along 16th street and thanked the Gods of Fate for sending me on a path past Panchita's.  

Shall I be back?  Do bird migrate every year?  Do gay men drink red bull vodkas to dance all night?  Do 6th graders constantly talk at all volume that is far too loud without being aware of it?  Your answer is simple.
author: Jeremy G.

description: I love pupusas! My Salvadorean friend said that they're not the best, but that they're pretty legit. We both love this place because it's good and they stay open late. If you're bar hopping in the Mission, this place has someone out front making them - best late night food ever.
author: Kelly B.

description: Walking to BART the other evening, walked past Panchitas as a few of their cooks prepared pupusas on an outdoor grille. Smelled heavenly, but needed to catch my train. Got to BART, and it was going to be a 15-minute wait for the train. Oh, hell no! I walked back to Panchitas and put in my order for two of the best pupusas I've ever tasted (bean and cheese and pork and cheese). Washed them down with a Mexican Coca-Cola (real cane sugar, thank you). Red sauce served with the pupusas was spicy and perfect. Liked their service too, although they weren't that busy. Stopped by Panchitas again last night for an appetizer pupusa on my way to dinner at another restaurant. Oh yeah!
author: David G.

description: Their papusas are so tasty.  Every time I'm in the area, I always pick up some papusas. They do take a little long to make, but it's very much well rewarded after.
author: A M.

description: it really has good, cheap food and nice vibe. what really disturbed me is that I saw one waiter coming out of the bathroom without washing his hands (I could tell from the timing of the toilet flushing and him walking out).   So PLEASE watch your hands if you do not want your patients to get sick...
author: Shuting Z.

description: Food is awesome, first time having Salvadorian food, they are so proud of their food, they just want you to try everything.
author: Alan P.

description:
I should've looked elsewhere to eat when I walked in and was greeted with:

1. Sticky, sticky floor
2. Pretty shabby menu with written-in prices
3. Dirty table

But I was starving, so I just decided to roll through it and give it a shot. We took our order fairly quickly (this place had like maybe 2-3 other people sitting around when we came in)

We sat there and waited. And waited. And waited. FINALLY our Horchata comes out, which wasn't very up to par. It wasn't really refreshing at all, and I fought to sip it slowly... I've never had bad Horchata before so this was a first.

Then we waited some more. And more.

OVER AN HOUR LATER -- the 2-3 other people who had ordered their food FINALLY got their orders. Another 15 minutes later, we got ours. I'm not the type that would walk out on a restaurant, but I was really reallly tempted this time..


Their food is alright, it wasn't amazing and I actually got nauseous while eating for some reason -- it might've been that Horchata from earlier. What got me was that, for what they were charging us, they sure need to make certain that their food comes out quickly and that it's even GOOD to begin with.

Ran into a friend afterward and told him where I ate. "Dude, that place sucks... and is super expensive..."

I wish he told me this earlier, so be forewarned !
author: John B.

description:
The pupusas were good but, but the service is terrible. I had to wait over 40 minutes for my food while two large to-go orders were filled immediately. We ordered our drinks and after 10 minutes had to remind the server for our drinks. In addition, the chips served were completely stale and not edible. The pupusa plate was a great deal, but waiting and the terrible service is not worth it. 

The pineapple juice tasted like kool aid or jello even after we asked the server if it was fresh juice.
author: Cynthia A.

description: I'm really sad I can no longer come here and get 2 for $5 pupusas. they're $3 each now. they're not the best pupusas but they're pretty damn good. I agree with another review I saw, the slaw and red sauce could def use more flavor but damnit they were only $5! looks like I'm on the hunt again.
author: Alyssa L.

description:
Gooey, cheesey, greasy fried pupusa goodness!  I love how fresh their sauce is and tasty too!  

Their spinach pupusas were super yum, great cheap spot to grab a bite to eat in the Mission!
author: Jaime P.

description:
Two things you don't complain about when you're eating in the Mission:
1) the filth
2) the service

And if you're unhappy with the cleanliness or the wait staff...don't eat at a one money sign joint in the Mission....I'm sure they'll greet you at the door at Gary Danko's and the floors are definitely not sticky.  
You get what you pay for.  

There's only one thing I come to Panchita's for and it's late night pupusas. 
When you're shit face wasted, hungry, have blown all but $2 on drinks you bought for people you don't know, and when you've gotten sick of dancing in a humid room that smells like sweaty ass next door at Skylark (what the hell were you doing there in the first place?)...run next door to Panchita's for a warm saucer of savory awesomeness served with hot sauce and a tangy slaw.  

You won't regret it.
author: Bridget K.

description:
I come here (literally) every single time I'm in the Mission. Often, I bring friends along with me. 

The food is just that good. Although I usually stick with the spinach and cheese pupusas, when I came here Saturday my friend helped me venture out of my comfort zone. We ordered the pollo con mole (chicken with chocolate sauce) , which was a great end to a long night.

While I do love the food here, I really enjoy the restaurant because it has a cozy, down-to-Earth kind of feeling. It's one of those places you can go to with a close friend and have all sorts of great conversations. 

Only complaint, as with the other reviews, is that the service is a little slow. There's usually only one waiter/cashier. I would complain more about this, but the guy who works there is so friendly.
author: Jean F.

description: Maybe it was because I got them to go..but the pupusas weren't as good as I thought they'd be. But, big portions, free chips and salsa, really cheap.
author: Lilian K.

description:
I love Pupusas!!   Had a lovely night out near the mission and decided to take a walk to find a good burrito.   Came across this Salvadorian restaurant, and could not resist

It was pretty late so there was only one other table seated so it was fast service.  Skylark bar is next door, so if the loud music bothers you....don't come here to eat after 10pm.
author: Cassie B.

description:
I've been here a couple times and it's awesome for cheap veggie eats and cheap meat eats if you're into that too. I like the spinach, the bean and cheese, and the mushroom pupusas. My bf eats meat and he likes what he gets too. There are big containers of pickled veggies and salsa at the table so you can have as much of that as you want with your meal.

Yummy and cheap!
author: Amanda L.

description: This place makes the best pupusas I've ever had. The dough is soft and non-greasy yet so flavorful! Fork's cut right through them like butter. This is definitely my one and only pupusa spot! It's a great place to have lunch and just hang out. I love it!
author: Polett R.

description: Passed the food cart outside of the restaurant on the way to dinner and thought to myself, "Leave some room." Glad I did, because it was absolutely delicious. I've never had a pupusa before, so I wouldn't know what to compare it to, but I got mine with pork, beans, and cheese. The best way to describe it is an enclosed sope. I'm from out of town, but I would definitely make a stop there again. And you can't beat the $3 price tag.
author: Jess G.

description: First time eating pupusas and it was a fabulous experience. The mushroom and garlic is amazing, the atmosphere is so unique and the crazy wall/ceiling paintings are pretty cool too. Gonna come here forever for sure.
author: Jenni W.

description: It's always good when I'm craving pupusas de frijol y queso. I like the platanos too. Good prices.
author: Rico H.

description: Really good, got these delectable delights during the carnival festival and it was able to tide my hunger. I am glad I took the leap of faith and got the spinach pupusa in addition to the bean and cheese one. I will definitely try the zuccini next time. The beans and rice side to me isn't worth the additional cost though. They put the salsa in a little plastic bag which got really messy and the wait was forever, and given that there weren't that many people I was disappointed. It took 20 minutes from start to finish :(
author: Onika C.

description:
A hot doughy spinach, bean and cheese pupusa with dribbled on (or most likely piled upon) fresh crispy slaw and hot sauce is one of the best things you could treat yourself to on a long cold Saturday Mission bar hopping night.

Even more exciting is you'll probably savor and enjoy Panchita's tasty menu more -sober. 

While Panchita's is not exactly a secret in the area, people sometimes forget about it, so if you go right before the bars get out at 2:00am, you'll have no line, a seat, and a fresh cooked meal in no time.

Next time you're craving a bacon-hotdog after you stumble out down Mission street - try Panchita's instead. Their burritos are also pretty good.
author: Jessica T.

description: Fantastic papusas, 2 for $5 with tons of different types. I've only ever gotten them from the grill out on the street but after a night out drinking in the mission these are the best way to end the night.
author: Grace P.

description:
One thing I can definitely say about Panchita's....no matter how sober or drunk I am, the Pupusas are always amazing!

I highly recommend, the combination, beef and cheese, pork and cheese, just cheese, whatever...

  2 Pupusas, with a side of rice and beans and I'm satisfied, there's nothing like a home cooked meal to feed the face and the soul.
author: Edrian D.

description: I go to this place about once a week on lunch break.  What really gets me at this place is their variety of vegetarian papusas.  They have basil, chipotle chile (which has a very nice heat), mushroom and garlic, and jalapeno among others.  I also like how they give unlimited red salsa to go with it.  Two of these will fill me up.  The curtido changes a little each time I go.  Sometimes it's more vinegary then other times.  The seating is great too, nice large tables with self serve water.  My only problem with this place is that it can take a bit to get your papusas, especially if there are multiple orders ahead of you.  It's a one, sometimes two woman kitchen, so this is undertstandable, especially with handmade papusas.
author: Tyler J.

description:
Delicious anytime probably but with a beer and after quite a few beers...perfect. We had their pork pupusas (two different times in one night). They have the typical salsa and slaw to go on top. 

Next time I'll ask for some spicier salsa. That was all that was missing- a bit more heat.
author: Lizzy R.

description:
It is unfortunate that I have to do this as it has been a place I go to when I need a bite that's quick and easy.  

I arrived at the location to purchase 2 pupusas for $5 outside of the restaurant.  Usually the person(s) outside receive the payment, but today the woman instructed me to pay inside for a to-go item.  I proceeded to do so; and the cashier inside advised me it was $5.50.  

I was surprised that there was a 10% increase --- because I had just purchased the same order two weeks ago. I had asked her when the price increased; and she stated it had always been that way.  

Since I just wanted to get home I thought to myself --- Ok... maybe the increase happened recently.  --- And because I felt  she just wanted to get rid of me, I decided to simply pay the $5.50. 

I returned outside to wait for my order.  A couple minutes later as I was waiting for my order another person ordered two pupusas as well.  When the person was ready to pay, he asked the woman outside the price and she told him it was $5.  He gave her his $5 then went on his way. 

I couldn't believe that this was happening right in front of me.  When I asked the woman why she only accepted $5 when the cashier inside told me to pay $5.50, she looked confused and told me to speak with the cashier.  

I went back to speak with the cashier and she insisted that all orders are $5.50.  When I had told her that the woman outside only accepted $5 from the other customer (not $5.50), she insisted that she did not accept the $5.  But the thing is -- the $5 bill was still on the cart where the woman placed it!  

The woman/cashier disregarded my statement and said again that such orders have always been $5.50.  She then rolled her eyes at me --- and clearly was annoyed when I explained to her the situation. I knew I was not going to get any where with this woman. So I took my order and went on my way. 

Look - I really don't want to have an argument over $0.50.  And I am disappointed that I have to write this review.  But I feel on principle this incident must be shared.   

I think it is poor business practice to quote a customer a higher price then quote another customer who made the same order --- a lower price --- especially in front of the other who was, in plain words, cheated. 

I wish I had something better to report here.  But the prices are inconsistent and the cashier was rude.   I am really disappointed in the place.
author: Heather R.

description: Delicious!!!! I always get the cheese pupusas. Probably not the best place to be after clubs, cus everyone is drunk.. but everythings delicious!
author: Lily F.

description: Very average service with underwhelming food. I almost wonder if the high reviews are a result of hipsters thinking they are cool for eating here. My cheese enchilada, one of the few vegetarian options, was really nasty. Honestly and enchilada from the cheesecake factory would have been more satisfying and would not have had little pieces of iceberg lettuce on top and nasty white rice with it. My partner's chicken mole dish was so gross looking, in fact the mole was still crumbly and dry as it came from those bullion type cubes that hadn't even been dissolved. Yuck.
author: Mark S.

description: I love this place. They will make pupusas any way I want them. Even vegan. They are cheap too! Only $2.50 each. I love it in the evening when they have the grill at the front entrance if the store. The people that work here are very friendly and the pickles  for the pupusas tasty.
author: Denise L.

description: We first found this place on New Year's Day when another restaurant nearby was closed...so glad we went here instead! I love pupusas and this place does them well. The bean and cheese are my favorite but I also love the pork and cheese. (I have gotten the combo before, love their rice and beans.) Be sure to get their platanos and black beans with crema, so good! Seating can be tricky as the tables fill up quickly when they are busy. We always come back when we are in the area.
author: Nikki M.

description:
This is feedback from my experience today, June 11th, 2011. Biggest mistake ever to give this place a chance. 

We arrived in the Mission, thinking there would be a lot of different restaurants to try, and we decided to choose this one on a whim, and we were STARVING. And who doesn't love pupusas? Perhaps it could beat our local Salvadorian restaurant on the Peninsula. 

The "eatery" was run down with the whirring of their kitchen equipment over powering our ability to hear each other. But we thought that we should give the place a chance, since a lot of the restaurants reviewed in the mission seem to have some version of dirty attached to them. We seat ourselves and wait a few minutes just to have menus brought to us...should have taken that as a sign to leave. When the waitress comes back, we order our beverages and she delivers semi-warm beverages, stale, cold chips and sub-par salsa. We order our pupusas. I was so hungry that I ate most of the stale chips. Thirty minute later, we still have no food, two tables seated after us got their entire orders plus one guy with his little dog came in, (it looks like the server knew who they were, friends or family) placed a to-go order and got that before us!

We paid for our luke-warm drinks and left, hungry and frustrated. And that set our tone for the rest our experience in the Mission. It sucked. It was bad. And I will not go back to that part of S.F. unless I am paid five figures. Don't ever go to this place.
author: Justine P.

description: I love this place so much! The ladies who work there are so nice! The pupusas are addicting. Oh, and the bathrooms are always clean which I always appreciate.
author: Stephanie S.

description:
I visited Panchita's 2 on Monday August 8th, 2011 at approximately 4PM.  I was not greeted at the door.  There were two other people eating separately in the restaurant.  I went to the counter and asked the woman working if I could sit.  She said yes.  She eventually brought over a menu.  I ordered the Enchiladas Verdes, a Mexican dish.  The waitress brought me some chips and salsa.  The chips not so good.  The salsa decent.  My Enchiladas arrived about 20 minutes later.  They were too cheesy, but not terrible.  The dish also came with rice and beans.  The rice was crunchy and the beans were bland.  Sometime after my food arriving, the waitress disappeared for a very long time (to the point that it actually became comical to me).  I found her once again and asked for a coffee.  She brought it out with a smile.  

Overall, the food is cheap.  The service is friendly, but aloof.  Not a terrible place.
author: Lindsay P.

description:
So far, the best, authentic pupusas n' fried plantains that I have found in the Bay Area. My favorite go-to place in the Mission District. I looove it.

I admit, it's a greasy, hole-in-the-wall kinda place, but if you look past all that...you'll find that it's a gem. Trust me, you will not leave hungry.

My boyfriend and I always order the same spread: 1 pupusa de loroco, 1 pupusa de espinaca, 1 plato de platanos, y una horchata (Not including the big basket of tortilla chips that they give you at the beginning!) Oh, heaven.
author: Jen A.

description:
I dunno why there are so many good reviews on the pupusas???

I went there because of the reviews and was extremely disgusted with the pupusas de chicharon (pork). The pork was nasty and the mixed pupusas were not better either. I went there with my friend Giselle and it was so bad we considered to dine and dash lol but we didnt. The service was slow and the lady just looked like she didnt give a F

Idk how the rest of their food is but if you are going here for pupusas stay away unless you like to feel like u been raped out of your $$$ after you eat!
author: Eric S.

description:
I wouldn't bother with burritos here because there are better places close by but definitely have the pupusas and the avocado salad (which is pretty much guacamole atop lettuce).  It's got a bit of a truck stop atmosphere but with such tasty food and cheap beer prices it's a fair trade. 

To wit: It's good, it's cheap, and the location is great.
author: Julienne G.

description:
Alright. SERVICE MIGHT BE REALLY SLOW. They might also treat you a little better if you can speak Spanish.

These are everything I could ask for in a pupusa. They make me feel at home aka L.A. 

4 pupusas, 2 beers = $20

Oh man, service was so slow. LOL they also got our orders wrong, but it's cool. I was happy with my two pupusas.
author: Brian S.

description: The pupusas were delightfully fully of gooey cheese and vegetables. I got two awesome pupusas (spinach and zucchini)  with sauce and condements for $5 which is really unbeatable. I'll definitely be coming back for a quick bite here every once in a while.
author: Isaac R.

description: Absolutely good pupusas at a friendly low price. Matches the quality of LA pupusas. Which I cannot say for platano in Berkeley or the place outside of W BART. These are the first authentic and delicious staple
author: Daniel M.

description: Real great pupusas. Life changing experience indeed. I kid you not! I brought friends who are fellow foodies and they honestly like the spot as well.
author: Ahmed A.

description:
yes...i am somehow Latin in my blood cuz of Portuguese/Spanish colonialism. I know dat plantains and rice go oh-so-good together ( I used to eat green bananas and rice as a kid).

I ain't a pro, but i heard of them authentic pupusas as "non-greasy, and lightly filled", according to my Salvadorean room mate. Yeah, green carded like me. Yeah, let's face it. It's fuckin greasy as hell. But sometimes, bein a non-pro, I hella love greazzzy ass food, authentic or not. Just as long as the shit is hot, imma keep migratin when I get the munchies.

Plus this place ain't even about the pupusas. Lemme tell you what the star is: their buttery ass rice, and horchata.
I see the Mexican connections up in this heezy. Cuz that shit is like homemade milk shake...substantial and rich flavors of ...whatever dat shit's supposed to be made of. 
Can I preach a lil more? God didn't tell me nothin bout the rice. i mean, some things are buttery just for the hell of it...some restaurants take that shit for granted. JUST KIDDING! How can you take butter melded perfectly with rice for granted? that shit straps you up in leather and makes you say naughty, Power Exchange kind of sweet nothings to it...and it LIKES it. Needless to say, you're an auto-sub when it comes to the rice...it just is...no need to believe...

So let's just face it. We're a bunch of fat-assed Americans who love their food greasy-so. I'm not ashamed. I like my rice with a pair of love-handles...and admit it, so do you.
author: Jay M.

description:
Oh sweet heaven in all its delicious post pitcher of beer glory...

These pupusas are pretty tops though slightly pricey for the big 5 star rating!  At $2 a pop it's still not a bad late night snack.  Greasy, crispy, soft, and flavorful in all the right ways.  I love that the loroco is whole and flavorful rather than chopped in little bits and pieces -- this adds just the right touch of bitter spice to cut the richness of the cheese and grease.   They come with a heap of pickled cabbage and carrot with a tang of pepper.  There's nothing better after downing a few beers.
author: Sarah G.

description:
Panchitas makes me feel like I am back in El Salvador. Table decorations proudly display key tourist spots around the country.....fairly simple decor in other words!

The food here, however is Muy muy muy bien! Mi gusto mucho (i like a lot!).
 The Pupusas are to die for!  And they stock Kola Champan...el sabor de El Salvador.

Its not glamourous but feels authentic and its prices are right!
author: MARTIN C.

description: Pupusas 2 for $5 is nothing to argue with. I'm new to the Bay area and these are the best pupusas that I've come across. The menu is written in english for a novice central american eater. They do have pupusas revueltas and chicharron con queso (best in my opinion but not on menu). My only complaint is that the curtido (pickled cabbage) and salsa have been inconsistent and not good at times. They have beer to wash everything down.
author: Ozy S.

description: I really enjoyed this place. Tasty, reasonable food server quick-ish. There was a great energy to this place at midnight on a Saturday. The ladies drilling the pupusas on the plancha in the doorway to lure you in, the mix of people, and the dude playing guitar for tips.
author: Chuck K.

description: Papusas! I had the munchies while having drinks at the Skylark and saw a woman cooking next door. We ordered the steak and chicken papusas. They were fresh and made to order. Not too shabby.
author: Jessica S.

description: Worst pupusa that I ever had!  Wish I could give no stars.  Greasy and the cheese had a definite sour flavor so could not eat it after first bite. Unfortunately surly Cashier also was the cook, and her teenage daughters were talkative and eating with the soles of their shoes atop the seat benches.  We really miss El Zocalo in San Francisco! If anyone has found comparable pupusas to El Zocalo's when they were in San Francisco please let me know.  We also will not eat again at El Zocalo in South City.
author: Mary L.

description: HIGHLY RECOMMENDED How have I been missing this place for 25 years! HOT and REALLY good! This is a small family run business that deserves your support!
author: Jerry M.

description: Very tasty food. Pupusas here are great. The service is very friendly and provide a nice enviroment. Not bad.
author: Serge C.

description:
My wife suggested we try salvadorean food and Panchita's was the closest one. When I entered this place, i was worried. The look of the place wasnt that great... it had a shabby look, there were not many people eating there (at 7pm on a friday) so i was sceptical about our choice.

But the food BLEW us away! The pupusas were just right. A little crisp on the outside, cheese and meat perfectly cooked on the inside, served with some homemade nachos + salsa. 

Next we ordered the pollo encebollado (a MUST TRY!). It took a crazy long time for them to serve it but i forgave them the minute i put the first bite in my mouth. The chicken was grilled with some spice rub on it and it tasted amazing. The chicken was served with some rice (couldnt eat it fast enough) and some sauteed onions. All of the above was for $15 bucks.

this is definitely a restaurant on my 'Repeat' list. If only they fix the decor, the slow service and the unclean floors, I cant see why they wont have a 5 star review.
author: vilas v.

description: The carne asada burrito definitely hit the spot after an intoxicated evening of stumbling around. I personally don't enjoy rice in my burritos and this one had a lot, but I'm glad it was there to soak up the alcohol. I definitely think I have to give that burrito all the credit for a hangover-free next morning. Thanks for staying open late Panchitas!
author: Mymy N.

description:
What was the problem here? Could've been a few things:

1. I didn't get a pupusa, although after reading reviews ...  I should've gotten a pupusa. 

2. I don't think Salvadorians are known for their burritos like Mexicans are - but I still ordered a burrito. Bad idea. If you want anything besides meat in your burritos, you need to get a "Super". Their HUGE (that's what she said) and frankly, not that good! 

3. We ate in the restaurant and the service was a bit negligent too. 

All that said, I suggest NOT getting the burrito, but if you do then be sure you're drunk as a mofo when you walk in, b/c it probably tastes a hundred times better that way.
author: Sho B.

description: Not really sure what people are complaining about.  Pupusas are not bland.  I got the spinach, the chipotle, and the beans and they were delicious.  Would have given the joint 5 stars but I swear to god I was sitting for 30 minutes waiting for 3 pupusas.  I was by myself so I was chill but it started to stress me out that I came in at 7:15 before an 8:00 movie at the Roxie and around 7:40 I was starting to wonder if I would make it.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Ate there last night after attempting 3 other restaurants and long waits. I had noticed the plethora of Salvadorean restaurants in the Mission and thought it was high time to give one a try. This one looked a bit dingy, but I like my food authentic, so we decided to give it a try. 

They brought our chips and salsa right away - chips were a bit greasy, but the salsa was nice. We ordered the carne asada plate - overcooked beef, with flavorless beans, french fries, greasy white rice and a bit of salad; the cheese enchilada plate which had a nice green sauce, but far too much cheese and of course the rice and beans; and the pollo encebollado - overcooked well flavored chicken with onions, served with the previously mentioned greasy rice and salad. The service was decent and while not a miserable meal, definitely not a great meal - at least while we were there. 

The problems began quickly - first with my table mate who had the carne asada. He began feeling queasy before even finishing his meal. It was a long car ride home. I began with a headache (often a first sign of food poisoning for me) on the car ride home and was nauseous within an hour. Throwing up the remainders of my pollo encebollado within a few hours and still feeling pretty crappy 12 hours later.

Trust your eyes - there's a reason there was a long wait at those other restaurants.
author: Rachel D.

description:
not the freshest friendliest place in the world.  so what?  the food is so good you won't notice anything else.

the beans are amazing.  the rice is amazing.  the salsa is amazing.  the cabbage slaw is amazing.  and those are just sides.  add a pupusa and plantains to all that, and it's heavenly.

the menu selection is quite good.

i'm drooling.  really i am.  i must go again tomorrow.

on second thought maybe i don't want you to know about this place... need to keep the riffraff out.
author: Peter K.

description: Pupusas rule here! New fav place. Love that the pickled cabbage and salsa are served in big containers on the table. Yummmmmmmmmm!
author: Edgar N.

description: The chicarron con queso pupusas will make anyone with $2.50 feel rich, especially when served with the customary tubful of yummy curtido and liter of salsa.  Go two for $5 with the loroco con queso, and call it a deal.  Buen provecho.
author: Vin J.

description:
You know the best pupusas I ever had were at the defunct Westwood farmer's market before they built TJ's and move out to the Vet cemetery. They were made fresh and grilled by two of the sweetest ladies ever.  Panchita's? Their pupusas are pretty good, but they don't compare. Also the lady messed up my order, but it wasn't a big deal. Honestly, especially since I didn't check my order before I left the restaurant.

I got 2 pork & cheese and 1 spinach & cheese instead of pork, cheese, beans and pork & cheese, and spinach & cheese. So I didn't get my beans, but that's probably a good thing? Not sure, this sounds kinda fatty now that I've typed it out. hmmm. *stares at stomach* The pupusas don't seem extraordinarily large, but trust me. You will feel it, them, after ingestion. 

In any case, it's hard for pupusas to live up to my memory but Panchita's does quite nicely. They also have alfajores! Also not as good as my memory (this one from Argentina).  -__-" ignore me. 

In any case, I'm asian. I showed up by myself after the Giants parade. I didn't feel out of place at all. :: shrug :: this is San Francisco after all. Crowd seemed pretty diverse to me. I got my food to go. 

I will say that their salsa is pretty tasty. I wish I'd asked for more.
author: Andrea L.

description: Best pupusas in the entire Bay Area.  A while back I went on a pupusa binge and tried ALL of the places that serve pupusas in the entire greater Bay Area.  SF, East Bay and everywhere else I could find them.  This is the best. All the fillings at Panchitas Pupusaria are delicious, and seasoned perfectly with interesting combinations of flavors.  Chicken pupusas are the best, next spinach & cheese, then mushroom & garlic a close runner up.  They also have combo meal plates with rice and beans, and snacks like plantains.  Great place to get a quick and delicious meal for a very reasonable price.  Very casual ambiance, and sometimes loud late at night.  Good people watching.  I go for the totally fabulous food, I have dreams about eating there. YUM!  They don't have a fancy website, and the photos don't do them justice, but the food is truly excellent.  Must try this place! You will notice that every person at your table has a different color plate, some with crazy patterns, and none match. Every utensil is different and none match. I like it!   Also cool that the walls are artfully painted to look like the inside of a corrugated metal shed.
author: Kelina L.

description:
The tacos remind me of the tacos of my youth. None of this floppy corn tortilla business! They deep fry the tortillas, throw in a huge spoon of refried beans and cheese (or meat, of course), top it with lettuce, onions, and avocado. Someone please give Pancho Villa the memo on how to make good food!

I usually order La Cena Ligera (one bean taco, rice, beans and 2 tortillas for 5 bucks!), a glass of jugo de pina and put Como Te Deseo by Mana on the jukebox. Tacos, pupusas, enchiladas, and burritos can be made vegetarian if that's your preference. If you don't want meat in your tacos make sure to say what you want, frijol or queso.
author: bianca francesca o.

description:
Like MARTIN C said, "It ain't glamorous..." 

Well it sure as F ain't ugly either! 

This place is awesome. Every time I even think about this place, I feel my body getting all bloaty and full, which is the same way I feel when I leave this place. 

Yum... I can taste those pupusas' now. That's it, I'm on my way out there. Peace y'all!
author: John F.

description: Good food, good service. Wanted a quick bite while in the Mission. I had the yucca with chicharron. Yucca was cooked perfectly but chicharron was not so chicharron-y. It was just fried pork really, but no crunch. My partner had mole enchiladas, which was good. The refried beans though not so much, a little watery. Horchata drink was not the best.
author: Vol T.

description:
Oh Panchita's has seen the worst and best of me, sorry Panchita's for the time I came here crying my eyes out, drunkenly yelling my order in spanish. I'm sorry I drank almost a full bottle of vodka by myself at the bars. I didn't mean to... but I thank you for the amazing pupusas that filled my alchy tummy.

I also thank you for being great hangover food, or a good meal to fill your tummy up before you start drinking.

The pupusas are hit or miss sometimes. The last time I was there they were very greasy, but the first couple times I went they were amazing. I would go here instead of the santaneca, I like the vibe better. Plus the random bums that try to walk in here are funny, I like it.

The workers are oh sooo sweet too, I love them!
author: Debbie P.

description:
This place really does not deserve a four, but will get one just for being open on weekends until 3 and feeding me.

Location: Two blocks from my house, the perfect place for me to walk to drunk as balls and falling over. It's right in the heart of the ever so trendy 16th street and it's location could not be more ethereal. 

Space: It looks like your abuelita's kitchen in El Salvador.

Ambience: Super diverse. You'll see natives, hipsters, young people old people. Seriously, every one in the spectrum will eat here. Poor people, rich people drinking in the nearby trendy areas. Everyone. 

Service: Super mean and very Salvadoran style. Almost, lack of service. Like snarling, indifference, etc. It's all part of the experience. 

Food/Drink: Quite yummy. I can see the ladies rolling the masa in the back and it's delicious. They put a bit too much loroco in the queso y loroco pupusa, but if you like that, then by all means, order it. They're not that greasy, but just as delicious. Their tamal de elote is pretty fucking yummy. Then again, I will eat an arm at 3 a.m. drunk as tits.

Overall: I have a great appreciation and almost love for this establishment.
author: SF N.

description: Its awesome that the lady was just standing on the stoop outside making pupusas. So obviously fresh. The curtido and sauce were delish. Sadly the actual pupusa was nothing to write home about but its cheap so I'd prob go back, hah
author: Lúcia C.

description:
Unfortunately I have to give this place a 3-star. The food was great but the service was crap. Took the waitress forever to take our order, my friend, I and seriously 4 other clients where the only ones there. The others in the restaurant were already eating so there should have been no reason for such a long wait. So after about 10mins waitress finally came over to take our order. Ill give her the benefit of the doubt and just say she was tired since it was late in the night, but still she had some additute that was not needed. Im sure if she knew I spoke Spanish she'd be friendlier but I don't like talking in Spanish unless I have to. She understood English well and her English wasn't bad so there was no need for me to speak in Spanish. Well anyways enough of the waitress. 
The food took a bit to finally get to use but that was ok, it was well worth the wait. My friend and I didn't order much, but once we finished we ordered more cuz it was so good. Id come back again, but I really hope the service is a lot better than what I experienced the first time -__-
author: Joji V.

description:
I had never had pupusas before. 
Read on yelp Panchitas #2 were supposed to be the best in town.
They were delicious!
I will for sure be back!
author: jeffy e.

description:
Ended up at Panchita's "No 2" restaurant for a friend's birthday, and couldn't help but be impressed.

The food here, ie the pupusas, are jaw droppingly good. Not only that but at $2.50 a pop they are also super cheap. We mixed these with a gigantic beer for what was a fun evening out.

Overall, this place is recommendable. The service and actual location are so-so, but the awesome inexpensive food more than counter balances this.
author: Sami R.

description:
Finally ate here and I was not disappointed. The papusas were excellent, not that I'm an expert. Ordered 3 and only ate 2. The portion sizes were big enough to satisfy a hearty appetite. Plus the price was definitely satisfying. Only thing about being a Ma and Pop place (decor is nothing to brag about), service is slow. So if time is a cruncher than I don't recommend coming here also the location isn't in a great neighborhood.

This is the reason why San Francisco is one of the top foodie city. Restaurant like these are diamond in a rough!
author: Kathy T.

description: Can you say pupusa paradise? So yum. All the other dishes we had were pretty good as well. Get the steak dish, very tender. Stop by if you are craving some el salvadorian food.
author: Derrick W.

description: There's a little old lady in the back slapping corn masa stuffed with pork and cheese between her capable hands and putting them directly on the grill.  Great pupusas but not sure that I was crazy about anything else that was ordered. Seriously though, who cares what else is on the menu when you can get fresh pupusas and watch the crack ho's and hipsters passing each other right outside the window?
author: Jennifer G.

description:
Oh Panchitas...I had my very first pupusa here...and since then, I fell in love.  I continue to come here because 1. Pupusas, and 2. Good memories.

But the last few times that I been here...has been a disappointment.  We had to ask like 3 times to get more chips, water and salsa.  Our order (2 pupusas for me, and 3 pupusas for the bf) took more than 30 minutes.

The food is still good and cheap...they give you a lot of pickled cabbage (sooo yummy) but the service kinda is ehh...

I will continue to come back, but I must explore other pupusa joints...
author: nancy b.

description: first time wating moroccan food. absolutely amazing. instantly made me happy after a long stressful day. best tortilla EVER had
author: Kay G.

description:
Pupusas!  

I didn't even know I was hungry when we wandered in and then the smell hit me and I wanted one of everything on the menu!  It was really difficult to make a decision, so I went with what I'd heard was the best:  Pupusas!

While I waited, I chowed down on the just-right hot salsa.  Service was a little slow, which is the only reason this place gets 4 stars.  I really wish I could do 4.5!

Finally, my pupusa plate arrived.  The refried beans were a little too on the soupy side and the spinach pupusa was more cheese than anything, but still incredibly delicious.  My other pupusa choice was the meat, bean and cheese.  It had the perfect amount of filling.

The best discovery was the . . . well, I'm not sure what it was.  I thought it was coleslaw so I didn't touch it at first.  But I thought I should be polite and at least try it.  I was delighted!  It was definitely shredded cabbage but it was more like . . . a cabbage salsa.  I'm still not positive what it was, but I know I ate every single shred!

We ended our meal by sharing a plantain empanada.  It was not what I expected but very tasty!  The plantain was sweeter than I'm used to and there was a delicious cream also inside the pie.  Yum!

Panchitas is my favorite kind of restaurant.  It's cheap and so worth more than you pay!
author: Aunt B.

description:
Stop #3 on our food crawl, papusas. 

Seriously, the plain bean and cheese one is so good.  

I actually have a pretty funny story about this place.  I came here with a few friends back in 2008, we each got two papusas, and this was after we ate dinner, so of course we were a little full.
