We packed the papusas to go - my friend puts his in his pocket.  I'm not joking, we were just drunk.  

Off we go to polk street bars, where we never make good decisions.  After last call jell-o shots, we grab cabs and go our separate ways.  I get a text at 3am from my friend stating "I just found the extra papusa in my pocket, what a nice surprise. Tell your friends."  

I found my papusa in my purse the next day.  Always a good time at Panchitos no. 2.
author: Bhumika K.

description:
I was freezing and thought Salvadorean food would hit the spot, so we ended up here.

Both ordered the pupusa plate, which comes with 2 pupusas, rice, beans, and their pickled cabbage/slaw dish.  The salsa that came with our chips at the beginning of the meal was pretty spicy and good.  The pupusas (got the beef/cheese and chicken/cheese ones) came out steaming hot and were delicious. Especially liked the rice which had just the right mix of saltiness and proper texture that I hadn't tasted since...well, since back in the South.  Like my Grandma used to make, for serious.

It was a LOT of food...I couldn't finish it all.  The damage?  $12.50 total for both meals.  I could've just ordered 2 pupusas for around $2 each and saved myself even more money.  Or just eaten one and saved the other...in any event, yeah, you get a lot of food for cheap.  Most of the other items on the menu didn't go past the $9 range for the meals from what I saw.

I didn't think the service was that bad, but I was all blissed out from meditation so your mileage may vary.  But excellent, excellent eats.
author: Charlotte M.

description:
I had lunch at Panchita's Restaurant in the Mission.  First the not so good news.  Unfortunately what they say about the service is true.  I had to get up from the table twice to ask for menus and ask the waitress to take our order.  Since they are nice people, I decide to cut them some slack and keep my cool.

So we ordered the Chicken Enchiladas, the Chicken Tacos and a Bean & Cheese Burrito.  Each plate was served with rice and refried beans.  The rice was the best Mexican rice I have had in a while.  The refried beans were delicious too.  The seasoning of the meat made the enchiladas and the tacos very good.

For drinks we ordered the horchata and pineapple.  The pineapple is sweet and the horchata is refreshing.

It's a good idea to practice your patience when dining at Panchita's Restaurant.  You will greatly be rewarded with tasty and satisfying dishes!
author: Janet H.

description:
Since most of you will never make it to Chez Maria D's Momma, come to Panchita's instead for the Next Best Thing. The bistec encebollado (steak w/ onions) is very, very close to my mom's version, but please, never tell her that. My mom thinks her cooking is a unique snowflake but she is oh so wrong. They even have her ice berg lettuce salad w/ Italian dressing and some avocado. Almost like being at my mom's house. Except at Panchita's, we were not given a 2 hour Dominican history lesson, which is what you would be subjected to at my house. 

Panchita's also has  best pupusas I've ever had (thick & cheesy, not tiny like some other Mission pupuserias) and really wonderful refried beans. The horchata is really interesting, like a thin mexican chocolate milk. I usually don't order it, but my dining companion did and then the matronly waitress basically ordered it for me. See, just like being at Mom's house!
author: Maria D.

description:
Wikipedia says, "The Salvadoran pupusa (from Pipil pupusawa) is a thick, hand-made corn tortilla (made using masa, a maize flour dough used in Latin American cuisine) that is stuffed with one or more of the following: cheese (queso) (usually a soft Salvadoran cheese called Quesillo), fried pork rind (chicharrn), chicken (pollo), refried beans (frijoles fritos), or queso con loroco (loroco is a vine flower bud from Central America). There is also the pupusa revuelta (with mixed ingredients of all three)."

Charlene L. says, "Pupusas are tasty bastards you can get at Panchita's #2." This is where I fell in love with the tasty treat, and highly recommend it! I like the cheese and refried beans, and you can expect the place to be filled a la San Francisco: punks, families, suits and earth mamas. So you'll feel at home. Even at 1 in the morning.
author: Charlene L.

description:
If you're impatient, call ahead - there's a reason why there's a 2 pupusa minimum.  

If you want your drinks before your meal, just say so, I'm sure they'd oblige (they have $7 Regia beer - not great, but the price is right and the large bottle easily serves two).

Also note that what initially appears to be a sorry excuse for salsa with a spoon in there for no reason makes a kick-ass enchilada/pupusa sauce - once the pickled cabbage (El Salvador's version of kim chee?) shows up with your pupusas and you realize just how good all three are together, the light bulb will go off.  The chips that come with the salsa are good, but the salsa doesn't go very well with them.

I got the chicken/cheese and the bean/cheese pupusas, and my friend got the revuelta (pork, bean and cheese) and the spinach/cheese pupusas - we both agreed that the revuelta was the best one, but couldn't agree on the rest.  No matter though, they were all excellent and extremely filling - I have part of a bean pupusa awaiting me in my refrigerator.  

***Before I finish this review, I need to turn this over to my inner 11-year-old boy for a sec:

Hee hee, pupusas, heh, that sounds like, hee hee, like because pupusa sounds like, well, you know...and it also kinda sounds like a girl's well...hee hee...pupusa.  *giggle snort giggle*

***Okay, I feel better now.

Cool little spot to go if you're in need of pre-drinking sustanance but aren't in a hurry (emphasis on not in a hurry).
author: Sus... B.

description:
I've got exactly one word for you:  Amazing pork and cheese papusas.

Oh yeah - I also once saw that spiky-haired Asian dancer from the first season of "So You Think You Can Dance" in there with a bunch of his friends.   For whatever that's worth.
author: Joe C.

description:
The super tacos are REALLY big here. Don't order 3. Even if you've been drinking for 4 hours and haven't eaten in 8 hours. They are good but don't order 3. In order of the best meats, I'd pick carnitas, then carne asada, then pollo. 

I might have just been drunk and excited to get back to DYL but the check seemed to take FOREVER. We were there for almost an hour in total. Which two girls, both starving, ordering tacos shouldn't have taken an hour.
author: Ali R.

description:
Usually whenever I find myself in joints like Panchita's, I have maria d., my latin passport, with me. Which usually gains me some cred in the ordering department, and it's probably a figment of my imagination, but I also think it nets us a few extra fried plantains. Anyway, the pupusas here are a fantastic food. Crusty, cheesy, satisfying. Also, very cheap. 

And the aforementioned plate of platanos fritos is generous and tasty. Fried plantains are my favorite thing in life, as you may know.

My favorite part about establishments like these, that are basically like some auntie's dining room more than a restaurant, is that right here at the corner of 16th and Rapidly Gentrifying, the neighborhood drunken stumblebum can stumble on in and get a warm plate of food, and stumble right back out without paying, and nobody so much as raises an eyebrow. That's what it means to love thy neighbor, people. Think about that while you're holed up in your $700,000 condo behind a barricade of iron gates and electronic locks. Your neighborhood is full of love.
author: Megan W.

description:
"3 stars?"  
Yes. 
"Why?"

 I'd give it more but I don't remember ever going there.  Have you ever heard a Blitzed Brotha trying to speak Spanish to the Latina behind the counter?  You should have been at Panchita's.  I said things like Nachos and Tacos and whatever else was on the menu...  I think someone even told me, "Gabe she speaks English."  and I still kept trying to speak Spanish to her.

My tacos were delicious/my nachos hit the spot/if Panchita's was my girl/we'd drop it likes it's hot!

It is one of the best.... but then again, I don't remember.

Ok, so now that I remember, I give them 4 stars.  ;0) tacos taste so goooooooooooood!  Just ask Kristine J. ;0)
author: Jamal G.

description:
Oh man. . . .
The pupusa will be my downfall.
All those a.m. hours logged on the treadmill watching 'rock of love'.
The time accumulated throughout the year in down-ward dog.
Wooosh! 
Down the drain,
Out the window.
All because of those wonderful cheese & chicken 
or cheese & spinach pupusas. 
Top it with the "slaw" and hot sauce and your golden.
I've been here many times at 2:30am after drinking with the girls.
The wait can be a little steep sometimes as these little gems
are made to order by authentic El Salvadorian grandmas.
The restaurant being situated only a block from my house
provides the catalyst for a dangerous affair.
I have uncovered the weapons of mass destruction.
Mmmm, mmm, good. . . . .
author: Kia B.

description: My first pupusa experience definitely set the bar high. We walked in around midnight and had a great little conversation with the adorable man working the counter. Ooey-gooey beans and cheese wrapped in a delicious corn pocket saved me from certain alcohol death that night.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Emily H.

description:
Ou Em Gee.  You must try their pupusas!  My friend and I ordered four kinds of their pupusas (pork, beef, chicken, cheese, beans ingredients), and they were excellent.  

FYI: 2 pupusas minimum order (but at $2.50/each, you will be tempted to go for all 3 (and yet I advise against that, as two is plenty for most average people)).  

NB: I insistently advise to try it in the traditional style - with the cabbage and tomato (somewhat spicy) sauce mixed on top (included with pupusas).  

Didn't notice the service - we were too much into our conversation, but the owner who served us was very pleasant and unobtrusive.  I'm sure it helped that we conversed in Spanish, but he spoke perfect English, too.  It did take a while for our pupusas to get there - and they weren't super busy - but we really didn't mind and spent time yapping away to the faint voices of some Salvadorian folklore CDs.  

What I liked about this place is its warmth, neighborhood feeling, focus on food and it authenticity, and the simplicity of decor (or lack of thereof).

I'm totally coming back for more!
author: Stan S.

description:
Last night a papusa saved my life.
No for reals though, that shit was good. Not really fine dining atmosphere, but you prob didn't expect that anyway if you came here.

I had the bean & cheese and then a spinach & cheese one.  Papusas are not really a meal for the health-conscious.   When you are craving something fried, cheesy, and gooey, they are it tho.  This place does 'em right (even my roomie says so, and she's from El Salvador.  booya.)  

Must comment that if you dine in, service is sloooooooooooooow.  I mean, server moved like a turtle   -- and not just any turtle, but one that is ill and one of the oldest turtles in the history of the world.  My friend Brandy told me I was mean and suggested that the server may be depressed.  My apologies if that is the case!
author: Sid D.

description:
Since my roommates (Si-Eun and Tarry) wanted to head home, the rest of us (Ce, Stan and Kitty) downed a second pitcher of beer at Zeitgeist on beautiful Friday night.  Then, my two companion got hungry.  We decided to go to the first decent restaurant that we see on our way to the car.  Panchita's is what we agreed on.  

I had to use the bathroom after drinking so much beer so I ran to bathroom as they ordered food.  Kitty got some cheese and spinach pupusa and Stan ordered a steak burrito.  I wasn't that hungry so I just picked off their food.  Both dishes were delicious made with fresh ingredients -- I especially like the melted cheese...it was so good!  The salsa and chips were decent, I couldn't have too much of the salsa because it was a bit too spicy for my taste buds, but the chips were perfect.   The horchata (cinnamon rice milk) is refreshing -- I love it :-)!

As we finish up, Stan goes to the bathroom while Kitty and I munched on the chips.  A second later, I hear two gunshots, "BOOM BOOM"... everyone in the restaurant drops down the the ground, including the workers.  I sat there in shock not knowing what to do.  I finally realized that I should get away from the door/windows so I scurried towards the back by the bathroom.  I get on my cell phone and call one of the roommates.  Less than five minutes after the gunshots, there were already cops, ambulances, and firefighters blocking the intersection of 16th and Valencia and that's when we decided it was a good idea to to leave.  

Good news: The three of us got home safely and I will continue to hang out in the Mission (the bars here are awesome), even though I freaked out for a second after hearing gunshots.
author: Celeste M.

description:
Pupusas are my new food of evil. It used to be fried chicken and waffles but I think I've discovered a whole new world of bad. Load me up with a pair of these bad boys and you can see me toss my healthy eating restrictions aside without a second thought.

crispy on the outside, chewy with stretchy cheese (and your choice of filling if you so choose) on the inside, inexpensive and you can lie to yourself that you're eating veggies if you get the version with lorroco AND load them up with the pickled cabbage/carrot slaw that comes with it. Yes, I am great at denial.

The main draw for me at this place wasn't actually their pupusas if you can believe that- no, it was their sopa (soup) to be honest. I hadn't been feeling all that fantastic the last several weeks- I think I kept catching the same stupid cold over and over and a girl gets tired of the same ol' pho ga/chicken matzoh ball/udon/avgolemono rotation. I needed a new soup flavor and this place spoke to me.

JR had the sopa del res (beef soup), me the pollo (chicken) and we had the same pupusas as the ones from Tita's for consistency's sake-one lorroco and one chicharron. 

The soup arrived steaming in a gigantic bowl loaded with meat (I think mine had over a quarter of a chicken in it!), a corn on the cob,  carrots, zuchinni, and god knows what else. I think Roger's came with chunks of yucca too, but the verdict's still out on that one. It came with a side of rice which wasn't all that intriguing on it's own and I can see how people would be unhappy about it if that's what they got with a plate of other stuff, but with the soup it went just fine. There was just so much food in the bowl I immediately felt guilty knowing I wasn't going to finish as much as I wanted. It was delicious and with a few squeezes of lemon, hit the spot for Typhoid Morty.

The pupusas weren't as well constructed or as flavorful as the ones from Tita's in Buttonwillow, and their masa wasn't as fragrant and didn't hold together as well either, but I still can't shake a stick at melty oozy cheese. The lorroco didn't have as much flavor as Tita's either but I let it slide. One big thing I really missed was that fresh tomato sauce though. hot sauce just doesn't cut it (especially if you have ulcers like me!). 

Roger had a pineapple liquado which turned out a little sweeter than I expected, and I had a tamarindo which was so delicious I am still antsy to have another. A perfect balance of sweet and tart with the distinguishing tamarind flavor, the only suggestion I would make is to thin it out just a skoch with some more water.

I'll be trying other places in pursuit of a better Bay Area pupuseria, but the sopa and liquado search ends here for me. Arriba a Panchita's!
author: Mortiche W.

description:
On my second attempt to introduce great South American food and some strong margaritas to British tourists we ended up here.  Puerto Alegre was an hour and a half wait and we were all too hungry for that craziness. So, you know what that means...no tequila for Lilly, again!

Despite that disappointment we were happy to find Panchita's. Almost empty on a Friday night was a little scary, but the food was pretty good. I tried everyone's dishes with the guise of needing to give a credible review. The carne asada and chicken burritos, tostadas, pork/bean/cheese pupusas and spinach/cheese pupusas were all delicious. There was coke in a bottle which doesn't make up for no tequila, but helps a little.

Bad things about it:
-nasty rice
-slow service (although extremely friendly people)
-the view of a crazy woman's bare ass through the window for half of my meal...actually I think that was a good thing
author: Lilly O.

description:
Growing up eating pupusas, this is by far the best pupuseria in the Mission. They may not have as much choices as other places but what they lack in choices, they make up in flavor.
I highly recommend the revueltas with a beer or salvadorean horchata.
author: Brenda I.

description:
Pupusas are my latest food obsession! 

So I only have limited experience with pupusas but the ones at Panchita's #2 are sooo tasty.  They are seriously fried/grilled  on the outside, more so than some of the other pupusas I have been eating - I am not sure if that makes them more or less authentic but it does make the extra hot and sort of crispy..... mmmm..... I wonder if I should run out and get some right now....

Plus the burritos at Panchita's are really good too.  Not very spicy but great rice and beans and they grilled the outside of the tortillas once the burritos are rolled and I Love that.
author: lisa g.

description:
Stopped in here with my mother and grandmother after we found out that Ti Couz doesn't open until 5pm. It was 2pm, we were hungry and didn't want to wait 3 more hours to eat even though I raved about Ti Couz to them for forever.  I asked them both if they ever had a pupusa. My grandmother has but my mom doesn't even know what the hell a pupusa is. I've never had one either but the words "pupusa" and "pupuseria" are awesome so we walked on in. 

There's a two pupusa minimum upon ordering so I get the spinach/cheese and beef pupusas.  My mom ordered two chicken ones along with a tamale.  

This is El Salvadorian food and I guess the way they make their tamales are different than Mexico.  Instead of wrapping it in corn husks its wrapped in banana leaves and they use potatoes instead of corn meal.  These tamales are extremely delicious!   My grandma orders a HUGE bowl of chicken soup that is seriously the way that grandma makes it!  The pupusas are greasy but sooooo yummy. 

 I wish they made a Panchita's in Oakland, or least a pupuseria near my apartment building.
author: Nikki M.

description:
Went here for a quick eat. Had my first pupusa here but was sorely disappointed. It was pretty bland and greasy. I tried the beef and cheese and the mix pupusa (pork, cheese and beans). It was OK for me. Apparently, some people put those pickled vegetables ontop of it and drizzle the salsa on it, too so I tried it. It was alright. 

I had ordered a glass of their horchata and it was surprisingly refreshing. Totally different in taste if you get it at a mexican taqueria but their horchata was creamier and less sweet. I liked it. 

Panchita's reminds me of having dinner at an old aunt's house. Don't come here for the ambiance, come here for the food and especially the prices. We spent $18 on dinner which is NOT BAD but I wished their pupuas were more flavorful.
author: Mika D.

description:
What an awesome surprise down at 16th/mission. The tasty bean pupusas were an excellent start, the $2 domestic beers could not be beat, but what I will remember, and return for, was the burrito. I'd been on an unlucky streak with my burritos lately, always questioning if that was really chicken they were putting in there, and at Panchita's #2, that was definitely grilled, white, delicious chicken. So good. To have a spot like this, cheap, tasty, filling, and a block from where you live, is what makes Mission living so awesome.

More dinner here: http://www.yelp.com/biz/panchitas-3-san-francisco#hrid:UxVzlyutcitfaUTEIGespA
author: Jason B.

description:
Hiya

This restaurant is on the corner of 16th and Valencia street.
It's accessible by Bart (16th street), 14, 49, 26, 22 bus lines.
The restaurant is right next door to a corner store, and a coffee/smoothie place.

This is also near a New York Style (sell by slice) pizza place, Pancho Villa, Sunflower Vietnamese, We Be Sushi, and a couple of cheap produce places...so you're near practically everything.

Do you ever have a LOVE/HATE relationship with a restaurant?
I know many people do. 

You either: (A or B)
a) Absolutely LOVE the service (attentive, efficient, fast, super friendly, always refill your bread and water without you asking, and treat you like a king or queen as soon as you walk in the restaurant)
But you HATE the fact that their food quality and taste is only mediocre but leaves you full.

b) Absolutely HATE the service (snail slow service, never refilling your water or slow to bring your water or any drinks or NEVER bring you water at all so you're left parched and bringing your own water that you hide in your purse, food takes forever to come out, unfriendly or bored looking servers). But you absolutely LOVE the food. The food leaves you speechless, every bite is an absolute taste of heaven that tantalizes your tastebuds and leaves you craving for more.

With Panchitas,  I HATE the service, but actually LOVE the food, 
and here's why.

So after my workout I decided on having a late lunch. And coming here made me eat even LATER.

I walk it and the place is busy, (about 12 people). There is an older woman server and another late teenage girl at the register. I grab my own menu and make my way towards the end of the restaurant. After ten minutes, the teenage girl finally walks up to me (she doesn't look happy to be there and bored and displays a look that I interpret as "Uh huh, what do you want, I hate being here").
She has her pen and pad and is ready to write, so without any preamble, I smile and say "I'd like to get the shrimp cocktail,
home made tortillas, and a small sopa de res."
Server:  "Drink?"
Me: "Pina?"
Server: Yeah we have it (sigh)".
Me: Ok Pina and ice water. Thank you very much (with a smile)
Server: Uh huh

So after 15 minutes of looking at my cell phone, examining the decor (or lack of) of the restaurant, and looking at their two way mirrors, the teenage server girl brings me my pina drink and iced water and a fork, spoon, and knife with a napkin. After another 10 minutes I get a basket of chips (crispy, well salted) with a small bowl of homemade hot sauce. I'm really famished at this point and already thinking of Yelp and what I would write. So in the beginning we were at zero stars, and then after another 10 minutes the tortillas arrive, and that's when the food starts to win me over.

Their version of hand made tortillas (not the store bought thin crappy ones) is wonderful. The tortillas were thick and so fresh of the griddle that I burned my hand on the first one. They were so hot and delicious and melted in my mouth. 

After 10 more minutes, the shrimp cocktail I ordered was more like a prawn cocktail services in a huge goblet. There were 8 large, tender (cooked perfectly) plump and juicy prawns swimming in a wonderfully spiced tomato broth with thinly sliced onions, tomatoes, cilantro, small chunks of fresh avocado  with a hit of garlic and lime (not overpowering or sour).  I took one bite and had to marvel at the well balanced flavors of the tenderly cooked prawns in that sauce. This is a must have for any yelper who loves prawns. 

After 15 more minutes, they finally brought out the sopa de res.
Sopa de res is a braised beef and vegetable soup. This is good for hangovers, the common cold, and to be eaten on a rainy cold day like today. The small sopa de res is really huge. It arrived in a huge white bowl and was steaming hot. It had a huge amount of TENDER boneless beef, tender carrots, tender corn on the cob, tender zucchini, tender yucca (think mexican starchy veggie like a potato) celery, and chayote (think of a mexican version of a zucchini). The broth was wonderfully flavored and had a very rich flavor that no salt was needed.  They serve the soup with a small plate of perfectly cooked white rice with a touch of butter and salt. It really goes well with the soup.

In the middle of my meal, I noticed another gentleman coming inside to eat, and after 10 minutes of not being acknowledged, or getting a menu, or anything to drink or any chips, he left. (He'll probably write a yelp review, you never know).

The prices are considerably inexpensive for the type of food and quantity you receive.  

So if you come here, you'll need alot of time on your hands. Bring some friends to keep you company or a large book to read. This place is good for college students on a BUDGET who like to study and eat undisturbed.
author: Charlene C.

description: I always stop by for their pupusas, coz they cook them right on the street.
author: Sans S.

description:
Pupusas here are the way to go!  Grilled, soft, tasty round pockets of joy.  Great homemade flavor, and quite authentic, judging by my limited Salvadoran culinary experiences.  (I looked it up...I guess the right adjective is Salvadoran).  The chicken tamale was great too...much more moist than the Mexican variety.  The place was dead on a Saturday afternoon but we still had to wait a while for the food.  Eh, small price to pay for freshly prepared goodness.  

For the price ($2 each), a couple of pupusas and a tamale definitely filled me up nicely.  Got it to go and made a picnic out of it with a few friends at Dolores Park, washed down with a Suprema beer...it was epic.
author: Louis M.

description:
Bar/club hopping with good friends can make this fella super hungry. Okay, even if I didn't do that I'd still eat like a mofo.

Panchita's was super crowded at 1:30AM, with all the drunks congregating for one of the few open joints in the midst of rain.

One of my boys actually almost got into a fight with another dude a few tables away. They were both drunk obviously because alcohol somehow escalates small things. The other party heard a few comments they thought were directed at them. Oh, you know it's ON!

The melee was prevented though because cooler heads prevailed. The sober ones in both parties mediated common ground and we all shared chips n' salsa later. By the end of all this, I was starving so I had to getS my grubS on yo!

The five of us ordered:
*Cheese quesadilla
     +Grilled to just enough crunch, melty mozzy and cheddy
*Cheese and spinach pupusa
     +This is usually a winning combination to me
     +Spinach didn't seem like it was frozen, which is a peeve of mine
*Chicken pupusa
     +Shredded chicken, juices trapped in the bread
*Steak and pork pupsa
     -The chicken is better; the steak and pork had a foreign redolence to 
     it, no bueno!

Final Call:
While I wouldn't make a specific trip here, I'd visit again after an evening of fun in the area. Spinach and cheese pupasas makes my tummy growl!
author: Chuck N.

description:
I come here for weekend brunch. Pupusa plate or huevos rancheros, regular old coffee. Squeeze through the crowds of hungover hipsters outside the Pork Store, and you'll sit right down at an open table and spend less dough. The food is good but service can be slow, the cranky may want to pre-coffee.

It's my understanding Panchitas #3 is run by the same family, but I don't need any of that upscale nonsense. If you want chi chi food, don't come to sweet, delicious Panchitas #2.
author: Gus J.

description:
I didn't get the papusas... i probably should have... i got combo 3... it was terrible... just a big plate of tasteless food... and it all had the same taste... bad...

cobo 3 

1 enchilada
1 taco
1 tamale
1 chili reanno
rice + beans

others in my party were pleased...
author: N S.

description: Thank you Panchita's for being open late all those nights we be drunk in the mission. I apologize for my friend muttering "where's my F**cking tacos?" over and over. He went home slightly more sober thanks to your delicious papusas!
author: Nikki M.

description: The homely decor is secondary, the pupusas and authentic central American things are supremely delicious in a home made kind of way. It's also very cheap. Wonderful!
author: Mike L.

description: I've never had papusas before so I can't speak to their authenticity, but YUM.  As other reviewers mention, it does take longer than you would think to make such a simple dish, (10-15 minutes) but you know everything's made fresh and not sitting around. At night they put a grill out on the street and pump out 3 or 4 popular flavors, so that can be faster. At $2.50 each I like the price.  Lots of vegetarian options.
author: Rami M.

description: Delicious pupusas, friendly service.  I had the lengua...yes, tongue. It was tasty but on the salty side...still, I enjoyed it.  I would easily come back here for some delicious Salvadorean food.
author: Nilu r.

description:
This Salvadoran joint smelled like a urinal hockey puck. The 3 pupusas we ordered- a Salvadoran staple consisting of a greasy corn tortilla stuffed with spinach, loroco, or pork - were pretty bland. As were the platanos fritos - fried plantains, beans, sour cream. 

Still, I love comfort food and the giant bowl of chicken soup we ordered was just that, single-handedly redeeming our meal. Veggies and nearly an entire chicken were simmered in a delicious broth, resulting in a belly-warming concoction that staved off the looming winter chill.
author: dave y.

description: Yucca con chicharron and Pupusas!!!! what more do you want?
author: Angelito R.

description:
Perhaps it was because of the holiday  weekend and they were short of staff, but we were really disappointed with the service.

*We waited and waited to get our menus, so we helped ourselves after 10 minutes.

*After another 20 min. of trying to make eye contact with a server, my friend walked right up to the counter to ask if we can place our order...

**we should've just gone a couple doors down to a taqueria, but we were trying really hard to be nice.**

*after another 5 min. of waiting, we finally placed our orders (a simple 3 burritos)...got warm crispy chips, salsa, and waters shortly after.

*after another 30 min. (and another basket of chips) we inquired about our 3 burritos...we were told it would take another 6 min. saying they were backed up on their orders (as we looked around at a restaurant less than 1/3 full).

*we hungrily looked over at the next table as the guy left...eyeing his chips.

*Finally got our food after about an hour's wait.  Pretty good.  But at that point everything tasted great.  

*My friend bumped into a former colleague.  As we were packing up to go, he asked to have our left over chips...
author: Cathy K.

description:
On Saturday nights (at least) this place stays open until 3 AM!!!

Though the restaurant itself (and especially it's bathroom) is dingy, the food is delicious.  Pupusas are probably the best food ever for anyone in a state of inebriation.  They are hearty, greasy, and stick to your ribs.  I highly recommend the curtido here too - it's that delicious Salvadorean take on sauerkraut - and it pairs really nicely with the cheesy, bean filled delightful pockets of pupusa goodness.
author: Katina M.

description:
My boyfriend had the pupusa and let me try it, I wanted to snarf all of his food down at once. The mixed one with pork that he got were amazing. I on the other hand wanted something breakfasty since it was brunch time. I ended up getting eggs and chorizo which I usually love like crazy, but the  chorizo was so super greasy and hard to chew. In fact it made me cringe a little bit biting into hard chunks of masked fat. I've never had that fatty or gross of sausage. I was really disappointed. 

I also felt kind of bad for the woman who was serving people too. She seems like the mom type. She was taking orders (only one) as well as bringing food back to tables. I figure there was probably one guy in back cooking too, if not two. Either way, it was a bit of a wait to get our food. And word to the wise, when you're done, go up to the register to pay. We were kind of sitting there wondering what to do about getting the check as we wanted to get out and go for a walk to check things out around the area. It was a little gross to see the server woman dropping food or water on the floor once in a while though (on accident but still she was too busy to really go clean it up) it just made me feel a mini bit gross eating there.

I would return for some pupusas though for sure.
author: Chris W.

description:
One of my favorite late night stops in the Mission is Panchitas.  Authentic Salvadorenan food is always a good addition to any good buzz or attempt to detoxify/sober up after a late night out. The pupusas are out of this world and the chips and accompanying salsa (which hits just the right degree of spiciness) are great complements to the main meal.  

The place is also a great venue to practice your espanol!  It is not the cleanest establishment, but food is very cheap and tastes good.   I have never contracted any illness after many visits, so I trust the employees and food.  It's also just fun to sit and watch all the different people coming to, fro and pass the restaurant.  Great place!
author: Megha S.

description:
I want to like this place-the pupusas are good and hearty & tacos are huge and cheap. 

Stay away from the Regia beer-it tastes like stale, bottom end, domestic light beer. Definitely not worth the $7.

My issues with Panchita's is that I always leave with a terrible stomach ache, but maybe that's just because I eat too much.
author: Peter O.

description:
I went last night with a buddy because we noticed that they had chimichangas on the menu in the window. I haven't found a REALLY good chimi near my crib and we decided to go in. For some reason, I decided against the chimi and went for some other food (pork chop, rice and beans) my buddy got some pupusas.
We waited, no joke, an hour for our stuff. 
I had ordered a side pupusa and they brought me that and brought my budd'ys pupusas (wrong ones, but he said fuck it cuz he was hungry)

One of the local groups of mustached musicians came in and played but weren't very good, but were incredibly loud. I had seen the dudes before and heard them play better, but this was just bad.
Maybe its not Panchitas fault for my dissatisfaction.
A woman came in to pick up some food and smelled like rank piss that just stayed in there long after she left.
I was sitting right next to the counter and that smell just stayed with me through my whole experience. It sucked.

Pupusas were ok. I d be down try the other ones they offer.
The service SUCKED!
Way slow, and forgetful.
author: Fernando M.

description:
My one cardinal rule when dining: ten minutes after being seated and no order has been placed, I take off. This very rarely happens of course. But when they do, I'm true to my word. Sometimes customer service is all an establishment has. And until you're Gary Danko, or Barneys New York, you cannot take for granted the quality of your customer service.

6:00pm. I walk in. Alone. I see a good five or six people inside. Barely occupying two or three tables. I was asked to take a seat. I picked a table for two. A family of three walks in. Now three or four tables occupied. I wait five minutes. Nothing. I picked up my own menu from the counter, the lone server has disappeared at back. She reappears to distribute menus to the party of three behind me. I pick up a book. Another five minutes. The book goes back into my tote, preparing for departure. Just in time the server takes my order. Another five minutes. She returns with water and complementary chips and salsa. I return to my reading. I savor the chips slowly. I didn't want to spoil my appetite. I look down from my book, the chips gone. Family of three well into their entrée. Several more people walk in and wait at the counter, awaiting phoned-in to-go orders, waiting to be seated. I look back down on my table. Nothing. 6:45pm. I got up, walking toward the door hoping for a chance at a disapproving smirk at the server. No one there. I pushed the door open the knob hitting the glass wall to its side. It caused a sharp thud. I left the door open, swinging.

Perhaps I was unfair and impatient. Volatile. But forty-five minutes for Salvadoran hole-in-the-wall-quality grub is not worth that long a wait!

The pupusas kept them in mind. But I can just forget about it now. Forget about this ridiculous place.
author: Rho-p O.

description: From the minute I walked in, ordered my Papusa plate en espanol and scarfed down a pair of pork, cheese and beans papusas, I was in heaven. Topping it off was El Salvadorian rice and beans with a side of tamarindo agua fresca. Having been to El Salvador and having tried to get those yummy papusas elsewhere, I am relieved to find a place so close to my work that can recreate the local yumminess of that wonderful Central American country.
author: Greg G.

description:
My love of papusas blossomed here.  They'll make 'em any way you want: beef, pork, chicken, cheese, beans or some combination of these ingredients.  It's cheap ($2/per papusa), greasy deliciousness!

The restaurant often has that sticky-plastic feeling, and, if you are waiting outside smoking a cigarette while they're making your papusas (as I often am), you may have to contend with the typical 16th street "transient", or a meathead from the Skylark club next door.

All the more reason to order those bad boys "to go"...
author: Karen F.

description:
The perfect place to grab a quick, cheap bite when you're drunk in the Mission & in need of some latenight eats. There's nothing like some papusas w/cabbage. And yeah, why not, I'll have a nightcap too. Make it a Pacifico.

A down-home place with delicious food & some occasional sketchy characters. But having a homeless guy walk in & attempt to take money out of the tip jar (only to be threatened by the cook holding a meat cleaver) only adds to the character of the place. I'm serious, this place is no nonsense.
author: Pete J.

description:
I first experienced pupusas at an overpriced food stand at Jack London Square on the 4th of July -- oh well, a universe away from a village store in El Salvador, but I was swept off my feet anyway.  

Then I was steered to Panchitas, where pupusas *were* good, but left me wanting a little bit more (not in the quantity sense).  One big plus with Panchitas is the fact that they do offer loroco as one of the filling ingredients, which I've been told is sorta hard to find outside of Central America.

I'm actually more impressed by the bistek Salvadoreno.
author: Alfonso E.

description: My favorite Pupusa place in the city. They really made my day when they expanded the fillings, while I still only get bean and cheese I love the idea. A great new remodel of the interior has made the location even more attractive to hang out at. Love this place. Panchitas has a long tradition in the Mission District that should not be missed.
author: Luis P.

description: I absolutely love this place! They have the best pupusas ever :) plus the workers are all super friendly and nice.  I took my grandma and mom here and the bill came out to only $20 and we were stuffffffed! All the pupusas are only $2.  Also, a convenient location at night *ahem* when you're too drunk to get in your car, feeel like you need some food to absorb the alcohol, PANCHITAS is it! Basically the best pupusas I've had since El Zocalo, so I stopped going there & devoted myself to this place.
author: Christina O.

description:
For casual and very affordable El Salvadorian this is my pick.  You've heard me sing the papusa praises of #3, and they are just as good here - Grandma's Family Recipe no doubt! But let me tell you now about how yummy the Mole Enchiladas, house made chicken soup, and a little treat known as a Plantain Empanada is!  (Plantain wrapped around a smooth cinnamon rice pudding and caramelized within an inch of its life... Yum.

Every time we go we know it will not be a quick meal.  We will wait; we will sit back and happily munch on our chips and salsa until the food comes.

Great for low key, great cheap eats, when what you really hanker for is a slice of home...maybe not your home, but someone's home indeed.
author: Alicia W.

description:
For the price, the food is fantastic.  I order to go and take it to San Jose.

The pupusas are cooked just right so they're crisp, yet soft.  I recommend the chicken & cheese.  

I'm surprised I don't see everyone raving about their tamales.  I ordered a chicken tamale & a corn (plain) tamale to go.  Once I got to my car I couldn't resist.  The chicken tamale was wrapped in a banana leaf, super-hot and almost liquid.  It melts in your mouth.  If I ever get dentures, I'm coming here first!  You have to lick your fingers before you touch the steering wheel.  The corn tamale wasn't so great the next morning... dry & tasting like cream of corn.

It's true, the service is very very slow but friendly.  I'll have to try calling ahead for to go orders.  

Ambiance is "hole in the wall" (which could be a "great find" for out of towner's on Prozac).

P.S. the bathroom door locks automatically so don't look for a button.
author: Ed D.

description:
I love this place - it's a hidden gem. This family owned eatery is staffed with friendly people.

 The papusas are super yummy and very cheap- 2 will fill you up easily and you'll spend under $5. The chips and salsa are yummy too.

I highly recommend checking them out. Great for lunch or an afternoon snack.
author: Melinda Q.

description:
Best horchata ever!  Very creamy, very flavorful, and not at all watery.  

I love to go in for a horchata, and the Salvadoran enchiladas, which are more like sopas.  Topped with picked cabbage, veggies, and flavorful meat, YUM!
author: C H.

description:
Panchita's is the epitome of "family restaurant." A picture of their son, who was murdered two years ago, hangs on the wall above the register. People walk in and up to the kitchen window, place their orders in Spanish, and sit down. If you're looking for that type of restaurant, than this is the place for you.

The pupusas are fantastic. At $2, their price is unbeatable. I've tried their tamales and other dishes, and while I wouldn't say I was disappointed, I wouldn't say I was "wowed" either.  

For those unfamiliar with pupusas: a thick tortilla stuffed with toppings (meat, cheese, beans, or whatever) and then fried. Pupusas are usually served with a pickled cabbage and hot salsa, which combined is mmmmmmmmmmm.

SFCritic
author: David J.

description:
The spinach and cheese pupusas here are my new love. Top them off with the curtido, crema and some of the salsa that they serve with their chips and I'm a happy camper. 

don't forget to order tamal de elote (skip the crema with this one) for something sweet after.
author: Joyce S.

description:
Don't remember the food being remarkable.  But when you're drunk, and you see some of your friends finishing a meal at 2am....it's a great place to scavenge.  

And by scavenge, yes, I do mean: eat what's left on everyone's plate, thereby passing up the line and saving some currency.
author: Robby T.

description:
This is strictly after drinking food... when you have had a borderline amount of sangria's... this will help soak some of it up... may provide you with a coronary... but then again... you had sangria... red wine will help counter act that... right? 

This place has slow service, the food is not the best... but it is open late and it can provide tons of entertainment after a night of fun. 

It is also very cheap...you do get what you pay for though.. 

A
author: Amelia M.

description:
Oh sweet plaintains, how I love you...

Tastes like homecooked food. I love the rice dishes. The salsa with the chips have the right amount of spice in it. I am a Sriracha addict to give you a perspective of my standards. The lomo saltado is to die for. Great for the wallet too. The only con is that the service is a little slow but it's definitely worth the wait.
author: Jacinta H.

description: Ended up here on a latenight (not too late) hype for some good grub. We wanted to stay somewhat local and despite the hipster fuckery in the Mission, we agreed on Panchita's. I didn't really think about what else to eat coz my homie recommended the lomo saltado. You didn't even have to tell me twice. Good choice for some authentic comida Salvadorena!
author: Ivan F.

description: I like the Caldo de Res and Caldo de pollo -- generous portions at lunch.   The fried plantains w/ cream amd  frijoes negros is a tastey snack. Not very healthy but tastey. Nice personal if somewhat slow service at lunch.
author: Bert K.

description:
For 4 pupusas My pal and I waited 30 minutes to get them.  Their take out is basically in foil and in plastic bags.  Overpriced while other places charge like 75 cents less and their takeout is more neat and well packaged.  I've had much better service at a better price!

Overrated and overpriced!!!
author: R C.

description: Panchita's #2!  Que Rico! Always pleasantly surprised at the combination of value and quality found in the food here. Economical and delicious Papusas, a nice and unusual salsa picosa (most tomato sauces for papusas I have tried are quite mild, Panchitas breaks that mold wide open) and a nice cabbage garnish with just enough Oregano. The sauce here is much spicier than at other Salvadoran places. They use Salvadoran Masa and I love the family that runs the place, they are totally sweet. Service is Latin American Style. For all of the white folks out there who do not grasp the finer points of international relations, here is a crash course: #1) In certain cultures it is considered rude to be in a hurry at a restaurant and meal and #2) It is considered rude to drop the check to a customer before they ask for one. If you are one of the slack-jawed anglos who think you have been getting bad service; review differences in cultural values before making public comments that make you appear ignorant.
author: Kimberley M.

description:
.


PUPUSAS !!!! That Revuelta (pork, bean and cheese) pupusa is guileless. 



.
author: Steve H.

description:
Any story that starts out with "on Easter Sunday I went to a Salvadorian place" is probably not going to end well.  Unfortunately, this one is no exception.

Now, eating catholic food on Easter Sunday should have rung out a loud red-alert klaxon.  Yet again, unfortunately it did not.

Horribly understaffed, unimaginative vegetarian menu (not a surprise), and a burrito that tasted like it came out of a can.  Ugh.

I should have braved the line at El Farolito.
author: Nelson A.

description: Panchitas is family, working hard to make a living. This comes out in the delicious food they serve. Try anything I think most things there are better than average.
author: Tad D.

description:
I was intrigued by a friend's description of menudo, tripe soup with hominy (not the sort of thing that everybody wants to eat in the morning, but definitely up my alley).  So, we headed over to Panchita's at brunch time one weekend and were presented with two very large bowls of menudo.  It was more delicious than I could have imagined and satisfied my craving for tripe completely.  I've been back since to try their other dishes, the more usual fare such as burrito carnitas, the supertaco, the beef quesadilla.  The burrito carnitas had too much rice for my taste, but the beef quesadilla is wonderful, blending the right texture of a crispy tortilla and cheese ozzing over the beef.  

The prices are reasonable, their servings large, and the food delicious.  The only reason not to give 5 stars is their lacklustre service.
author: Sooj O.

description:
After walking from Market and 16th, past a sea of lesbians (yes, I'm serious) that were part of Saturday's march, we settled down for some pupusa love at Panchita's.  The restaurant was fairly full with parties of 8 or more, so we were lucky to snag a table for four at the front of the restaurant right by the window. 

Service was a little bit slow, however, to get us place settings, chips, or menus for that matter.  It took about 10 minutes for them to finally take our order, as well, but I was in good company, so it really didn't matter that much to me. 

I ordered my usual 3 pupusas revueltas, a fried plantano, and an horchata.  The pupusas were awesome.  Nice and crispy on the bottom and the filling spot on.  The plantano was freaking awesome and had a nice cream fried along on the inside (it seemed, anyway).  The curtido was, eh, curtido, and I was a little disappointed that there was no sauce to go along with it.  So, I was left to eating it with just the curtido.  Sad.  I know.  

Now, this would have been a three star review if it weren't for one thing ... the horchata.  It was the real deal, kids.  It was made from real rice where I could actually taste the grittiness, and seasoned really nicely with some cinammon and sugar.  For that alone, Panchita's deserves an additional star.  Yum.  Yum. 

Prices for the evening were extremely reasonable.  For the four of us, it only cost $35 (that's including tax and tip!).  Definitely worth a try if you're in the area!
author: Eugene F.

description:
Hi carnitas burrito! Hi! Come over here, come sit with me. I won't hurt you, I promise. 

I lied. Crispy, seasoned, not dry carnitas, wrapped in the tortilla with all the fixins and then grilled. Grilled tortilla = crispy delicious heaven. 

The salsa that comes with the chips is equally lovely. Spicy and smokey. MMmmmm
author: kristen b.

description:
Pupusa revueltas with a side of platanos con crema and the centroamericano coleslaw aka curtido -  that's good eatin!

The other food is good too, but I've only had it once and it was a long time ago.  The frijoles are super duper rica!

This isn't a 5 star place because they're really a bit on the sluggish side when it comes ot getting stuff to your table - though slow, the service is very friendly and they love to explain to you what the other people are eating.

(The soup the guy in the corner was having last night was Mondongo, which has three kinds of meat - i don't remember the other two but one was Pata which I think means duck, but it could mean pork feet I don't remember and I can't find my dictionary).  

It's a nice quiet respite from the Friday night chaos on the street outside.
author: Robyn C.

description:
The food was pretty tasty when it finally came out.  I didn't really dig the salsa or the horchata (tasted burnt but I was assured that it was just me) but the salvadorean steak was delicious.   

Super slow service and there were only 3 parties in there.  One of the parties wasn't even eating anything.
author: Shyam P.

description:
Hands down the best burrito I've had in a long time.  I had the Carne Asada burrito.  Now, I will say that the first time I visited this place was after midnight and after a few drinks.  And really, what food isn't great at that time and in that state.  So to make sure I wasn't imagining how great the burrito was, I had to go back the next day and try it again (well, technically I guess it was the same day).  Sure enough... still a great burrito.  But then i thought to my self, "maybe it was just good again because I was hung over and starving."  So, I went back again the next day and, it was still a great burrito.  The next day I didn't question my opinion of the burrito any longer, but i still went back for another.

For those keeping score, thats 4 burritos from Panchita's in 3 days.  Must be good.
author: Jeff S.

description: The fried pork that came with the fried yucca was goooood.  As was the pupusas.
author: Wakako U.

description: I love how the salsa is hott, and the chips are warm. It feels like you're in someone's home. Inexpensive, authentic, and delicious.
author: Michelle W.

description:
I walked in on a Saturday morning and the two grannies in the kitchen made me four pupusas (thick, made  to order, piping hot and delicious), threw in a bag of cabbage salad (not quite cole slaw - crispy with lime juice, not creamy and limp) a bag of chips and I was out the door for $8. 

The pupusas were still scalding hot on my table ten minutes later, and I was so excited that I happily burnt my fingers trying to eat them! Just divine, particularly if you fancy Mexican food but seldom try other American cuisines. Places like Panchita's give me a warm-ish feeling about stinky, barfy 16th street.
author: G Z.

description:
I'll be honest, the atmosphere is lacking.  However, the yummyness of the food and the low prices is totally worth it.  Service is pretty decent, considering the setting.
The pupusas con queso y loroco and the casamiento are my favorites, but everything I've had here has been great.  I am only denying them the 5th star because that belongs to Los Cocos.  This is a great place to stop if you need to sop up some alcohol from the bars.
P.S. Do not confuse this w/ Panchitas #3!
author: Jessa C.

description:
Generally speaking, I wouldn't feel compelled to order 'fresh' crab enchiladas in a location with worse lighting than the liquor store next door.  Dining with a regular, I trusted the owner's recommendation on the freshest menu item and will definitely go back for more.   My enchiladas showed up without being completely drowned in sauce, and overflowing with undoubtedly fresh crab.   

The setting is well suited for late night grub, post-drinking binge...when you're too drunk to remember the definition of atmosphere, or are getting grub to go.  But don't be dissuaded from sober dining here, the food is equally satisfying and the owners happily locked the door to keep crazy guy from running in and out.
author: Laura S.

description:
Service was pretty awful, my food arrived ten minutes before my dining companion's and the waters were, um, not bottomless. Since it's not cheaper or as delicious as El Zocalo, I probably won't be back

--BUT--

Creepy tributes to dead 19-year-old (one looks a lot like a holiday window decoration) and totally unappetizing pictures on the menu, which was covered in salsa and bean crust, make me think this place could be a hit with the Salvadoranean Goth foodies. If I ever date one, this is where we'll go.
author: Margaret F.

description:
SF Food Inspection Score: 96

So they definitely don't specialize in burritos but my co workers had some pupusas and said they were "off the hook".

Really nice service, fairly quick especially if you call in ahead of time. Otherwise, from what I hear, they'll take a while since it's restaurant style. (Rhyme time!)

Will be back, esp since I work in the mish now.
author: Kristina C.

description: I wouldn't have come unless it was for late night grubbin after hitting up the bars. Pupusas are alright.
author: Melanie E.

description:
Is it authentic? How should I know? I'm just a dorky white-bread chick from the red states.  Is it tasty? I can give that a definite yes.  The pupusas are dirt cheap and extremely satisfying. I always have the cheese and spinach pupusas and I am never disappointed.  The salsa is delicious, and according to my tablemates, so was the shrimp they ordered.  

The service is veeeerrrryyyy slllloooowwww.  But that's okay, I'm out eating on a weekend evening, not running a race.  Try Panchita's.
author: Jamie C.

description: I want to cry when writing this review, because I have been to Panchita's many times before and loved it.  However, after coming back after a year, my husband and I were very disappointed.  It was like they had just given up on the service and the flavor.  Maybe Monday is not the time to go, I might try to go on the weekend by myself, since my husband said he will never go there again, to see if things are better.  I hope, I hope, I hope.
author: Laura V.

description:
A great place for breakfast after a nite of lamp-shade wearing hijinks. Great beans and rice and a pork pupusa is just what a body needs after trying to kill it with whiskey.

Seriously though, their food is really good.
author: Andrew L.

description:
This place is great,
great burritos, though usually on the over juicy side... it is still very filling and packed with all ingredients, the flavors are well blended.

Ponchovia next door is over rated, every time I walk pass and feel like a burrito, I'm just glad that Panchitas is right next door and serves good and double amount of food that cost the same.
author: Kevin S.

description: It's difficult to break out of your pattern of places to eat in the Mission, since it's a mecca of delicious food, but we finally did and it paid off. I really enjoyed the chips and salsa that came before the meal, the chips were super crispy and the salsa was tangy and spicy, it went quick. I had a pina drink and my coworker had the horchata, both were amazing. The pina had chunks of pineapple and reminded me of a boba drink mixed with aqua fresca. The horchata was great, super creamy! I had bean & cheese and spinach & cheese pupusas, both were fantastic. The outside was crispy but dense with plenty of cheese and fresh spinach! I liked that the bean pupusa was filled with refried beans rather than whole black beans. The best bite consisted of a little of each and lots of salsa. Some negatives were the slower service and their cabbage topping, it wasn't as good as other places however their salsa more than made up for it. You cannot beat $5 for 2 pupusas with yummy salsa and great drinks.
author: Cori W.

description:
On a philosophical note, and then on a practical note.

Philosophically, the pupusa present a conundrum. It's a great on-the-run food, because it's filling, cheap, and easily improved with the use of cheap condiments. And yet, unlike its cousin the taco, it takes FOREVER to make one.

And so a hungry diner finds himself staring into space at Panchitas, munching melancholically on chips and awful, tomato-paste-quality salsa. The pupusas themselves here aren't bad, and I liked the empanada de  platano. But this is the Mission. I don't come to the Mission to eat awful salsa in an ugly restaurant while I wait an eternity for so-so food.
author: Mike B.

description: Super Yummy.  The rice tasted EXACTLY like my grandmas, and the pupusas were perfectly crispy on the outside,and soft ad smooshy on the inside.  I got one cheese and one chiccharon.  The cordito was super crispy and just enought spicy to make me happy.I also got a horchata, and it was very delicious. There was enought food for me to bring left overs home.  Don't expect a warm and caring waiter..hes there just to bring your food and take your order.
author: Janet R.

description:
My first pupusa experience, and my what an experience it was!

Arrived nice and drunk on a Thursday night, looking for something to soak up the margarita, screwdriver, hard cider, and raspberry champagne martini thing (our bartender made on the fly) sloshing around in  my belly. 

We ordered 2 pork, 2 chicharron, and 2 spinach and queso pupusas. They were all ON POINT! I can't describe to you how perfect the corn was. Crunchy on the outside and soft on the inside, and the filling so yum yum yummo!

And The JUKEBOX! If you have an appreciation for latin music the selection is quite rawksome, from chente to Aventura. 

The service is great as well, nice lady that humored me with my drunken, crap spanish.
author: Polly F.

description: Meh.  I went there a few months ago jonsing  for pupusas.  Was hopping for a mean meal to match the 1980's, mom and pop decor.  But I was sadden with their over salty pork pupusa coupled with a drowned and over seasoned cabbage side.  Boo.  Not bad- but not that good.  Sorry to those die hard Panchita's fans.  The cook must have had an off day.  Not to mention a can of coke there was three bucks.  Laaaame.
author: Carolyn H.

description:
i've been here several times but i wouldn't go out of my way to come here. 

1. the very first time i came here there was table service but i guess not anymore. you have to order at the front and wait for food. i've experienced long waits.

2. the pupusas have been great and they have been bleh. they tried to trick me once and gave me chicken when i asked for pork. i also overheard their conversation in spanish about how they were out of pork. yeah, i may be straight up asian but i can speak and understand spanish. sneaky, sneaky! also, the salsa roja and curtido (coleslaw) are both in large plastic jars and just sit on tables as customers rotate in and out, eating from it... no refrigeration whatsoever and doesn't seem like much cleanliness/sanitation. i've also gotten the pupusas plate (2 pupusas, beans and rice) before and i'm def not a fan of the beans or rice. first time, the beans looked and tasted like they were from a can--all clumpy and thick. the rice was fried and super buttery. this was late at night so i'm guessing they heated up the rice on the grill or something and the beans were just leftover. the second time the beans were better and the rice wasn't buttery or crispy but it still wasn't fantastic. this was in the daytime. no consistency in taste whatsoever.

3. i don't recommend the burritos. there's nothing "super" about the super burritos and they're def not worth the prices. you're better off elsewhere for burritos...

4. service sucks so don't expect anything spectacular.

5. bathroom is gross.

6. just come here when you're drunk. you'll be hungry and anything will taste good and you won't give a f*ck. :)
author: Hwan L.

description:
Went here last night because my bestie was too hungover to go much further than here and back to her place *cough*Natalie N.*cough*. Being the great friend that I am, and being so hungry I could eat a hobo, I didn't mind. I love me some pupusas and I REALLY love me some platanos con frijoles y crema (plantains, refried beans and sour cream to you gringos/as). 
So that's what I ordered. Platanos con frijoles y crema and two (they make you order a minimum of two) pupusas, pork and cheese and cheese and lofrocata (some kind of edible flower that tastes kind of like broccoli). 
Then we waited for like 15 minutes for our food.
Once we got it, we walked back to Natalie's to watch a Tivoed episode of "Intervention" cuz it makes us feel really good about ourselves to know we may be fucked up but we ain't THAT fucked up.
My pupusas were greaseballs. Seriously...SO greasy. That's not to say it's a bad thing but....actually yeah...it's a bad thing.  I didn't care for the one filled with lofrocata flower or wtf that green broccoli-ish thing was but that was my own damn fault. The pork and cheese was awesome but, again, very greasy. The platanos con frijoles y crema was meh which made me really sad. The beans sucked and had that grayish brown color that I have never seen outside of cafeterias or those red Banquet frozen dinners they sell 10 for $10 everywhere and that taste like ass. 
OMG did Anthony Bourdain just liken the taste of something to "taint"? Sorry...now we are watching "No Reservations" but that comment really applied to my frijoles.  The sour cream was not that great either but the plantains were awesome.  Just perfect.
John Stewart, you are so funny it's almost criminal!
Anyways...obviously now watching The Daily Show.
I guess this place is okay but I still think the best is El Santaneca for pupusas and platanos con frijoles y crema.
However, Natalie N.'s house still gets 5 stars for best use of Tivo!
author: Jill D.

description:
Excellent food.  Really good popusas. Prime Time locale. 
I've found it to be relatively quiet inside this place despite the carnival of party people and drunks parading outside the window.

The only problem is that they are a little slow on bringing the food out.  And i doubt they'll change that.
author: Arthur K.

description:
food is totally a 5
service brings it down to a 3
order it to go so you don't get frustrated watching the servers walk slowly by u numerous times refusing to acknowledge to fact that you ordered a negro modello 20 minuets ago.
author: courtney l.

description: I wasn't really thinking straight when I ordered the tacos.  I really wanted to try the pupusas but that will have to wait for my next visit.  The tacos were great though!  The horchata and pineapple aguas fresca drinks were even better!  They get extra credit for the mirror in the bathroom that makes you look skinny even after a big meal.
author: Julie D.

description: They make some pretty tasty pupusas here, and the atmosphere is warm and kind of family-ish, but you're going to wait ages, and if you told your girlfriend you'll be back in twenty minutes she'll be PISSED. So only come here if you're single, or if it's girls night out and you've got all damn evening to wait for pupusas.
author: matthew r.

description: I'm giving this place two stars for customer service! The lady is rude and we had to walk to to take our order because she wasn't paying attention... then we had to walk up to pay. She didn't even bring us water! NO TIP obviously!
author: Josie M.

description: this place does take forever, but if you can eat here during non rush hours, do it! This place is like my 3rd favorite taqueria and i would suggest it. their burritos are pretty messy and their tacos are huge. its pretty cheap too. but service... not so excellent. cheap and good tho. cant get everything you want
author: Michael N.

description: Panchita's is the place to go if you love pupusas, dining on a budget, or simply trying to satisfy your appetite after eating expensive appetizers (see my Mission Street Food review). I love how I feel like I just walked into someone's house. The owner's don't stress off the decor but you can tell the cooks put some love into their spinach con queso pupusas. And for $2.50 a piece, it's on. Panchita's also serve some bomb caramel cookies covered in powdered sugar for desert. I would go in there just to buy a few more of those yo. So it's economical, delicious, and to top it off, they serve 40 water. Yes, 40 oz. bottles of Salvadorian brew.
author: Cel C.

description: Always great for a late night snack of Salvadorian food, such as Pupusas.  Very tasty here and they make them fresh so be prepared to wait a bit.
author: Mitch A.

description: Haven't tried the plantains yet (that will be the ultimate measure of course), but the pupusas rock my world!  I even ate a beef one by accident last night (we bought a bunch of assorted pupusas for a work event) and suffered no illness or retribution from the vegetarian gods.  Can't wait to go back!
author: Emma K.

description: I got the pupusa plate.. oh man, new favorite food.. I cant believe I went so long without having pupusas, my life is changed
author: Ian H.

description: I had my last two consecutive meals here.  Best veggie burrito I've had in SF... grilled with all the right fillings (rice, MASHED beans, cheese, lettuce, tomato, sour cream, guac).  Their "salsa" looks kind of like watery ketchup but is also really good (although I wish they also had the green hot sauce accompaniment like many taqs in the area).  I agree that service here is sloooooow, but it's probably because they're back their carefully grilling my veggie burrito to perfection.
author: seema s.

description: I love pupusas and this place delivers. For those not in the know about pupusas, they are Salvadorean in origin and usually eaten with a side of spicy coleslaw. The coleslaw here is good, but not spicy. My favorite pupusa is the chees and pork, although the bean one is a close second.
author: isaias J.

description:
ooh.  oh..  o face for Panchita's.

We stood there in a drunken state on the corner of 16th and Valencia pondering which taqueria to stumble into.  It was 11:00 pm on a Wednesday night and Panchita's looked promising.  It had quite the crowd going inside so it felt like a safe bet. I ordered a chicken quesadilla - not even on the menu - and they said "hokay."  My friend ordered the vegetarian burrito.  It took a while to get our food but they served up some yummy chips and salsa to tide us over.  I got a little nervous about the chicken that was going to be in my chicken quesadilla cause you never know with these places.  I got even more nervous when I looked over and this guy was picking away at a whole fish, head and all on his plate. Scary.

Ok ok, enough suspense (although you've already seen my 5 stars).  My chicken quesadilla was the best chicken quesadilla I have ever eaten, experienced and/or had the pleasure of meeting.  It was cheesy, it was saucy, it was accompanied with guac and sour cream.  It was all you could ever ask for and then some.  The chicken was white, shredded and delicious.  My friend had what she described as a delicious vegetarian burrito, despite the fact that all we could see in the burrito was lettuce.  

I don't think being drunk had anything to do with our mexican o faces.

I love this place.
author: Derek B.

description: Very Yummy pupusas but super slow and poor service. Took me forever to receive my sprite and water but damn the spinach/cheese and beans/cheese were good. Next time, I will try to call an order to go and see how long that would take.
author: Zannie S.

description: Oh, Panchitas #2. Home of some damn good pupusas and the best chicken soup in SF. Since leaving the City for Oakland, I realized what a gem this place is. Service can be slow, but its usually friendly. I go for the food, not the atmosphere.
author: GHADA Y.

description:
We just stumbled upon Panchita's on our way back to BART from Red Bull's matchbox car race. All the tables in the restaurant were full so we thought we would give it a try. Right when you are seated we got chips and salsa...then we waited about 5 minutes before we decided to grab our own menus and then waited about 10 minutes before we decided that it would be faster to order at the cash register as takeout.  We were hungry and getting testy by the minute, as were the other patrons. While we were waiting, we realized why the restaurant was full, no one had been served their food yet. It was brought out one plate at a time, which was really strange to us. We contemplated leaving, but 1. they took our money when we ordered and 2. we were not in any hurry. We thought we would give them the benefit of the doubt that maybe the staff had not anticipated the increase in business from the Red Bull event.  However, they had the event's flyer in the window...so that was a bit strange.

The food came out about 45 minutes after we had walked in. I know this review started out negatively, but we were really happy with the food. I ordered the pollo encebollado. It was very tender and tasty and came with beans and rice.  My husband loves pupusas but rarely comes by them, so he ordered 3 at $2.00 each. He was excited about how cheap they were and how large each pupusa was.  They are served with a pickled cabbage salad that balances the heaviness of the pupusa perfectly.  Our friend ordered the quesadilla suiza and enjoyed it as well.

By the time our food came, there was a line from the cash register out the door.  We thought to warn them about the wait but decided against it because the food was pretty good. 

After reading the reviews, I see that the service is regularly extremely slow.  My thoughts on this is that as long as you know what you are in for, you won't be as upset. The food is really good, but just know that you will have to wait for it...and even be a little proactive about grabbing your own menu and utensils and even ordering from the guy at the cash register if you haven't seen the waitress in a while.  Note: this also gets you served ahead of the other patrons who came before you but don't catch on as quickly.  I will be going back, but I also know to call in my order ahead from now on.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
just thinking about this place makes me sad

ill keep it short and simple:

the decor -- they have RIP signs of the fallen
the food -- barely passable even to drunk people

i really only came here to pee
author: justin t.

description: my sister introduced me to pupusas...lemme say I haven't been the same since. when the weather starts getting nice, I dream of fried cheesy goodness with a pacifico preferably, watching the drama of 16th and valencia unfold. The plaintains are ok, same with the horchata, but the pupusas are the reason to go.
author: Marie W.

description: The pupusas here are fantastic, and soooo cheap! The salvadorean tamales are also pretty damn great. Missing a star for service, which is markedly better on days when they are busier than on days when you are the only customer. Strange.
author: Carissa R.

description: Panchita's is the perfect way to soothe one's aching stomach after consuming massive amounts of alcohol in the Mission. I ordered some type of burrito (I don't remember - I was intoxicated), and it was great! I remember the house salsa being ferociously spicy, but I didn't mind. It forced me to drink more water to sober up. Despite its doors being open until 3 AM, Panchita's is a sit-down restaurant, not a ghetto burrito stand with college kids. I loved Panchita's, and I'm pretty sure the staff loved me right back for my drunken outbursts. Cheers to that!
author: Christine N.

description: You can't beat Panchita's enchiladas suiza with a stick. I braved the not-so-clean restaurant at least twice a month when I lived in the Mission to get my fix. It's the questionable cleanliness that keeps me from giving the full five stars. By the way- the guy with the silver teeth is very sweet!
author: Laura F.

description: A lot of food for the buck. The food is pretty good, but greasy. The pupusas were ok, kinda bland, but given that I have never had a pupusa before I can't really comment on them. The chicken mole was a little tough but the chicken with onions was really tender & tasty. Between Ki and me, we figured what we ordered will last us another 4 meals, in other words 6 meals for $28.
author: Divya R.

description:
Food is great, prices are  great, hours are great- but there is hardly a wait staff and takes awhile to get out of there.

Pupusas are a good price and addictive in their cheesy greasiness.

The taco platters are generous at $8.
If you live in the mission this is the go to spot for late night food.
author: Hal C.

description:
I had a great meal. It also helped that I had a few beers right before at a Happy Hour Event at Sports Basement on Bryant. I came in there with my gf and went all out. The papusas are $2.50 and if you want to get a Papusa with Been and Rice it's $6. The papusas were excellent. THey were good sized and they filled me up. I also ordered a damn good CHicken Tamale and a Puffy Taco Dish which for some reason was an Enchilada. I guess that's how they do it at El Salvadore? Maybe it was a cordito? I'm not sure but either way it was very good. THe one advice I have for people who come to this place is not to order the Mexican dishes unless you get a Burrito. The Burritos are huge and you get what you pay for $7. The other Mexican meals did not look particularly that great. I would stay in the Appetizer/Papusa section and there's nothing you will regret. The waiter (or the guy in the counter) was very friendly too. He kept convincing me to order more as I'm sure he knew I was drunk. So I kept ordering and I kept eating. Then he thought I would like a Corona so I got one too. The result was me feeling hella full and sleepy. I went in a Cab Ride and then got home and collapsed since I was so full.
The only thing I wish was a bit better was the salsa. To me it seemed like Tomatoe Juice with Spices.
author: Nir B.

description: We went to the city looking to have a torta and burrito at La Cumbre, but stumbled onto Panchita's which was around the corner after they had no more bread for Tortas at La Cumbre.  It looks kind of beaten on the outside, but we were willing to give it a chance, looking for authenticity.  My Wela Bella had the pupusas and the pork and cheese were incredible, like most of the reviews say.  I had the menudo.  I'm a big fan of menudo, but it is unlike the authentic Mexican menudo.  If you're willing to think outside the box, the menudo was delicious, but what blew me away was the Lengua plate.  By far its the best I've had and would go back for more.  Just be careful with Abuella, she can be tempermental....
author: Coach C.

description: Pupusas.  That's why I come here.  The nature of the beast is that it takes a long time to make these things, but when they are done, they are delicious.  There are thousands of civilizations that have come up with a way to wrap bread around meat, cheese and vegetables.  Everyone has an opinion on the best way to do it.  I don't know anything about that, all I know is that this place's pupusas rock.
author: Corey V.

description:
ten pm on a wednesday:
* no music. oddly quiet.
* strange smell.
* walls & tables & floor & everything blandly white w/ bits of yellow. 
* strange clientele staring around the place. 
* largely ignored by service, tho they were not rude when then did come to the table. 
* food ok, fairly good, not spectacular not awful. very few vegi options.
* bathroom door had no lock.
author: Jade P.

description: Not the best papusas in town, but downright delicious alonside their cordito. I also love the plantains with beans & crema! The rest of the menu is fairly decent & Latin families pack the place, so you know its ok. Nothing special about the decor, it's all no nonsense Salvadorian.
author: Colleen B.

description: GREAT FOOD FOR GREAT PRICE. I always get the super steak burrito here. It's so good!! I can only finish half of it. It's humongous. Food is made on the spot.  The service is pretty slow. Everything takes forever. Forever to take down your order, get your food, and get the check because there's only one or two people running the front. They really need to hire a cashier/ waiter to make the restaurant more efficient.
author: Esther G.

description: Solid papusas, empenadas, etc.  It's good, authentic, ingredients are not of the highest caliber, but charming nonetheless.  Now the service must be deliberately bad, you can't do this on accident.  Don't be shy to stand up and walk over to ask for stuff... the hardest thing to get was the bill, which is good I guess.
author: Josh M.

description: The chicken tamales are tasty and the chicken filing is succulent. The papusas de chicharones is a little too salty for my liking. The lomo saltado is a little and salty but the pesco frito is surprisingly good. The food is probably 2.5 stars but the low prices make it's a 3 star value.
author: Andy L.

description: Kinda dodgy and the orders usually come out at different times, but who cares with $2 pupusa deliciousness!!!  Goes up 5 stars when hungover.
author: Jules M.

description: Pretty good pupusas, decent Mexican plates (although their speciality is salvadorean). Service can be brusque, and the atmosphere is bright and sterile.
author: anita c.
