description: A consistently good, cheap, family-oriented El Salvadorean place that seems to me to be pretty authentic.  If nothing else, it's got a loud Spanish jukebox vibe.  Try the pupusas (beans, cheese, meat inside a thick tortilla pancake, topped with cole slaw)!
author: Katherine W.

description: Loved the pupusas and the filet.  Great beer as well, we had a big bottle of "Regia" I believe.  Nice casual ambience.  The waitresses are very engaging and enjoyable.
author: Derrick V.

description: This used to be my favorite late night burritos spot in the Mission. I don't know what happened, but since they put on the fresh coat of paint here, the food has gone way downhill. Last time I went here, I waited close to twenty mintues for my food, and I was one of five people there early on a friday night. My rice was still crunchy, too. They have good chips and salsa. But I'd avoid eating in. Grab a couple of their still amazing pupusas and a quart or Regia and be on your way.
author: Tim T.

description: The pupusa is good comfort food.  Just the right level of crispy on the outside.  The rest is hit and miss.  The servings are very large.  Though I dont understand what the staff are saying they seem friendly when they notice that you actually exist.
author: H C.

description: It was nearly 1:30 PM and the only thing I had eaten all day was a handful of cashews.  I'm a guy who gets hungry 30 minutes after eating, so needless to say, I was ravenous.  After passing up a crowded taqueria, I wondered into this empty place and ordered the first thing I saw on the menu: the El Salvadorian Steak.  It was amazing!  I consumed my meal at record speed and I was in Heaven the entire time.  Our server was a very friendly, jolly guy.  I would eat here again without hesitation!
author: Patrick N.

description: Another refreshing authentic find for us.  We were just wandering around the mission district looking for a pre-hold'em snack when a question struck me, "just what does El Salvadorean food taste like?"  Well, we certainly found out.  Not knowing what was good, we did a random order and was pleasantly surprised.  Next time I'm around there, I'll have to try the infamous pupusas.
author: Chris C.

description:
while apartment hunting last year, my soon to be roommate thought we should go out for dinner to lift our spirits. (things hadn't been going to well...) she brought me to panchita's 2.  HER favorite restaurant at the moment. i now thank her every morning as we sip a hot cup of cafe au foldgers in our underwear.
on my first trip, i had the Polo en salsa and it seriously brought tears to my eyes. i literally had had to look through the kitchen window to see if my grandma was back there cooking away. she wasn't. BUT, panchita herself was! my roomie and i spoke briefly with her as we paid for our meal. what a humble and sweet woman! if you pay with a card, they do this funny routine of picking up the phone and letting it connect to the machine. classy.

lunch time there is a whole different experience too! 
make sure you try both lunch and dinner before making a yelp decision.
author: alexis g.

description:
Papusas are the sh;&!

The powdered sugar caramel cookies are good too!!'

Love it!!
author: Marie R.

description: Good location for sedating liquored up friends. Cheap but greasy. I've had better pupusas at Balompies and Brisas de Acapulco.
author: Frankie S.

description: Ok. Everything is just ok. Pupusa plate is ok. The pupusas are freshly made but my order could have been cooked a bit longer.The place feels familial and like a local pupusaria, nothing too impressive. I would come back just to meet up with friends for a cheap lunch or late night snack.
author: joolia f.

description: It's hard to understand all the 5-star reviews for this place. The pupusas are mealy and the beans have so much lard that you can see a layer of grease floating on top. My guess is that, despite the similar names, the various "Panchitas" are not operated by the same folks, because P. #3 is waaay better quality.
author: Jo R.

description:
This place is a 3* but the slow service knocks it down a notch.

It is average. It is not bad, it is not good. Nothing special. 

I just don't have that much to say about it, because the place did not "wow" me. They did have a spicy hot sauce they served with the chips which was quite good. 

I dunno. Perhaps, it was just a bad day.
author: Rahul T.

description: I LOVE this restaurant! The food is always great, never a disappointment, everything is made to order so please have some patience when you order, especially if there is a full house, but believe me it is worth the wait! They are very friendly and willing to make you something special. I love the salvadorian food, and the chicken soup is amazing!! good prices, and the occasional cher song coming out the jukebox :)
author: Alesha K.

description: Love this rink-dinky place. It has good food and nice people who provide satisfactory service.
author: jamie c.

description:
This was my restaurant of choice for a good 3 months at the 16th and Valencia intersection. Their food is inexpensive, the portions large, and the employees nice & friendly. 
One time I went in there with my friend and his veggie girlfriend. They messed up and got meat in her pupusa and she got sick. I dont know what the correlation is with that though. I was strict veg. for 6 years and my stomach didnt mind a bit of accidental meat from time to time. She was puking though.
I wrote that off, but then another time I got a carne asada burrito from them and the meat tasted soapy and rancid it was both disgusting and at the same time tragic, as I was so hungry. So hungry that I took a few more bites than I should have to see if maybe it was just a bad spot...like on a bannana. 
Anyway, I was still going to this place, but not ordering the carne asada when I just got sick and tired of waiting so long for my food. 
I probably would go again for dine-in, but no more take-out for me. 
I miss you Panchitas.
author: Andrew B.

description:
I was introduced to the wonderful world of pupusas a couple of years ago.  I was at the Union Street Fair and one of my friends, from El Salvador, suggested I tried a pupusa as a snack.  It was good, but it wasn't $10/pupusa good.

Some months later, after a night out in the Mission, my friends and I were starving.  We decided to check out the pupusas at Panchita's.  What a good call!  I ordered the Pupusa Revuelta and a side of sweet plantains with beans and sour cream.  The... best... meal... ever.  I am aware that it is not the lightest meal you can have, but even my most health conscious friends crave pupusas from Panchita's every once in a while.  And my Salvadorian friend is a fan too, so there's your proof of authenticity.  

Some people complain that service is slow, but they do give you chips and salsa to keep you "entertained" while you wait.  And there is a jukebox with a pretty good selection of oldies, but goodies.  The first thing that one of my friends does when she walks in is select Total Eclipse of the Heart.  Next thing you know, all customers are singing along.  

I highly recommend this place if you love pupusas or want to give them a try for the first time.  God knows that no matter where in the city I might be hanging out, at the end of the night I always gravitate towards Panchita's.  Just make sure you get there before 2am.
author: Marlon J.

description: For the price, it was pretty good eat! And people are friendly, and you can eat good Salvadoran food withouth paying for the ticket!
author: zoe w.

description:
I've only tasted the pupusas, but they were delicious. It's like a latin american pancake, filled with cheese, chicken, spinach, pork, or any combination of the previous items. They take a few minutes to make, but they come out of the kitchen hot and taste completely home made-- served with hot sauce and cabbage topping, and at only two dollars a piece, you've got a real gem here. 

Highly recommended, I've been here both late night post festivities, as well as mid day, and the pupusas held up to my highly critical culinary critique.
author: mitch h.

description: struggle between high quality vs. lacking service.....standard mission style mexican taqueria....hit-and-run of water, menu, chips and salsa....flavorful 'n' mostly seeming pristine....tortilla chips glisten..fresh out of fryer...smooth tasteful salsa....mild-medium level heat....seemingly difficult to get attention....water refill almost impossible....self-serve napkins, water and utensils if needed....order of wet puerco burrito....others having pupusas, burritos 'n' unknown...pupusas being the popular pick....a note...puerco es pork chop en ingles....si....yo hablo espanol ...poquito.....panchita packing slow cooked tender whole chunks of boneless pork chop meat with usual sf fillers....rice 'n' beans.....requesting no beans...yet..finding the thick brown paste inside..urgh...still finding the meats flavorful...wishing next for all-meat burrito...large and filling.....smaller can be good in this case....again..timing of meals served atrocious...blatant ignore of requests....tops the worst service ever experienced...a relatively empty late evening night.....no excuse!
author: Hen A.

description: i cant speak for all the food, since all i would get is the papusas. they were delicious! and not greasy like other places. and very reasonable prices! i would come back to this place when ever i find myself in the neighborhood.
author: Silvia C.

description: great prices and a large selection of options too. several vegetarian options as well. i enjoyed the spinach papusas with rice and beans on the side. the pickled cabbage the papuas are served with is great as well.
author: Leuwam T.

description:
great drunk food, great i'm hungry and need to fill up on $6 food.

the pupusa revuelta plate, throw some of the salsa on it; if you're feeling particularly hungry, go for the nachos too. won't disappoint
author: John L.

description: this place is slooooow, but service is friendly, and i very much enjoyed my pollo frito and plantains.  maybe if i was in a rush, it would be a 3, but i'm in a chipper mood today, so i'll give it a 4.
author: Jill k.

description: Oh my god, YUM! The variety of pupusas... the most perfect, candy-like plaintains... and I wish I knew what that hot sweet corn drink is called, but they make the best version of it I've ever had!
author: Erica T.
